review: I read the first couple chapters of this a while ago, and I was excited to see more of Inkasisa. There was magic and Bolivian history and politics andI read the first couple chapters of this a while ago, and I was excited to see more of Inkasisa. There was magic and Bolivian history and politics and some pretty stark realities we don’t see often in YA fantasy (like food shortages and ration lines). But all of that seemed to melt away pretty quickly and the story devolved into a trope-heavy and predictable offering from this genre.I’m not sure if this has been given a name, but there’s a particular type of plotline that I think of as ‘captive in luxury’, which I’ve become increasingly exasperated by. It’s typically a young woman who is held against her will in a lavish setting with servants, elegant gowns, an abundance of decadent food, etc. But she is very angry about being forced to sit around & eat bonbons all day and takes it out on whatever poor sap has to be her keeper. She lobs sarcasm at anyone who crosses her path and feels bad about being surrounded by all that opulence for approximately two seconds before indulging in another bubble bath. I know this is a pretty cynical take on this type of character, but it’s just been done so much and I dread it every time it starts to happen. There’s this vibe that’s not unlike a bunch of rich celebrities or corporations singing about ‘coming together’ while the rest of the world is suffering. I dunno, maybe I’m just sensitive to that kind of thing at the moment. As for the book itself, Isabel Ibañez is not a bad writer. The characters are grating, but her descriptions are lush and inviting. The magic system isn’t elaborated much on, so you just kind of have to go with it. It’s not really explained how moon dust makes you sleepy, but also lets some people see the future and can be used by others to weave magical tapestries? I wish we had gotten more of Bolivia and the setting as opposed to whatever bullshit Ximena is getting up to with her Stockholm-Syndrome family. And even though there’s a lot of death, you don’t really form emotional attachments to the characters, so they’re no biggie. I’d still be willing to pick up more from Ibañez, all that said. This one just disappointed me, despite the pretty cover. Oh publishers, why do you do this to me?? ...more

title: Homegoing
author: Gyasi, Yaa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One of my Top 10 Books of 2020!I don’t know how anyone could finish reading Homegoing and not find themselves changed afterwards. What a triumph oOne of my Top 10 Books of 2020!I don’t know how anyone could finish reading Homegoing and not find themselves changed afterwards. What a triumph of a debut from Yaa Gyasi. If there ever was a work of fiction that would be beneficial for American high school history students to read, this would be it. Homegoing is as expansive as it is devastating. Following one divided family, Gyasi traces the lineage of two half-sisters as they diverge from the Fante & Asante nations to the United States and modern day Ghana. Every chapter is a new branch of alternating generations, and we get to watch how each new character introduced is shaped by the traumas of their past. Even those that they may have no memory of, their generational pain rippling.Yaa Gyasi does not pull any punches or dull any edges. Her writing is beautiful, but I can’t imagine anyone sitting down and reading this in just one sitting, despite the shorter length. It felt like every chapter was crafted in order to find a different way to break your heart. The parts with the most levity happened when you’re least expecting them. I loved seeing the life and actions of one character mirror another on the other side of the world. They were seeking different types of freedom, for themselves and descendants they may not have even given any thought to yet. If you have yet to read this, prepare for tears, some smiles and a whole lot of tenacity.I’m now even more eager for Transcendent Kingdom, coming 9/8/20, in case anyone hasn’t already added it to their TBR....more

title: An Ember in the Ashes        (An Ember in the Ashes, #1)
author: Tahir, Sabaa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After multiple enthusiastic endorsements from the likes of Samantha Shannon, S.A. Chakraborty & Tomi Adeyemi, I couldn’t really overlook this series aAfter multiple enthusiastic endorsements from the likes of Samantha Shannon, S.A. Chakraborty & Tomi Adeyemi, I couldn’t really overlook this series any more, could I? It’s an interesting combination of YA fantasy & adult fantasy elements, and while some parts are fairly predictable, An Ember in the Ashes is still compulsively readable.I’m trying to find an apt comparison series so people who haven’t read it might be able to gauge whether they’d be interested in this one, but I’m coming up empty handed. Not because it’s unlike any other series, but because it resembles pieces of so many. For me, I’m not looking for anything like Throne of Glass. I didn’t like Celaena or her excessively-voweled name, and thankfully the heroine in this series, Laia, is nothing like her (except for the vowels). She’s not tHe GrEaTeSt aSsAsIn iN tHe wOrLd, just a regular girl who lives under an increasingly brutal regime. Elias is a bit of a Marty Stu (is that the equivalent??), though we never really apply that title to male characters who are just the best for no reason....but I digress.The plot is action-packed and there’s little time spent before we’re thrust into the middle of it. Most of the story involves spying and fighting, though there’s definitely magical elements. I think I would prefer if Sabaa Tahir went deeper into that lore instead of the 20 year-old-killer Hunger Games we got in this one, but I’d imagine she will in later books. The novel is at its most YA when the characters are acting on their romantic feelings. Or not acting, just longingly staring at one another. Basically everyone is horny and nobody knows what to do about it. There’s also, inexplicably, only one girl selected in each class of over a hundred boys, and I roll my eyes every time I think about it.Speaking of the one girl...Helene. Tahir did her dirty. She’s supposedly a ruthless fighter and ‘tougher than any of them’, but for some reason turns helpless whenever Elias needs to be the hero of a scene. He is constantly throwing her over his shoulder and it’s grating how often the other characters deride her by saying she’s “acting like an actual girl“ as if it’s insulting or surprising. I just don’t like how she’s infantilized in this damsel role whilst being lauded in faux-empowerment. Female characters don’t have to be stripped of femininity in order to be strong. I just think she could have been handled better.The villains were also pretty cartoonishly evil. I’ve never seen a character say “I’m going to rape you” explicitly, but I guess Marcus isn’t one for subtlety. The Commandant is your typical severe Ice Queen, but even more malicious. Some of the cruelty she enacts is what almost makes me not want to categorize this as strictly YA. I’m looking forward to the more complex motivations of the upcoming Big Bads that we’re given a taste of near the end of the book. All in all, I liked it. I’m probably going to pick up the next one once my TBR calms down a bit. I just got more of the Witcher series made available at my library and have The Poppy War waiting for me on my Kindle, so maybe I’ll stagger A Torch Against the Night with those. Plus I need to get back intoThe Bone Season. And I’m about to start The Gilded Ones. Ugh, I’m so tired. ...more

title: The Gilded Ones        (Deathless, #1)
author: Forna, Namina*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Now a Goodreads Choice finalist in Debut Novel AND Young Adult Fantasy and Science Fiction!Wow, this was incredible. If the pub date hadn’t been pNow a Goodreads Choice finalist in Debut Novel AND Young Adult Fantasy and Science Fiction!Wow, this was incredible. If the pub date hadn’t been pushed back a year, it would have easily been one of my top YA fantasies in 2020. But maybe it’ll end up being a good thing, having The Gilded Ones debut in 2021. There will be time to build excitement and get the word out on this brilliant start to a series. That’s going to be the biggest drawback to this book, waiting for it to officially come out next February. Maybe Namina Forna will have the next book in the Deathless series ready by then? Possibly? Please??I’ve read a loooot of fantasy books starring young female heroines, ones who fight against an oppressive system. This story still feels new even in the face of all of those. It follows Deka, a young woman from a small, religious village in the northern province of the country Otera. Every year a new crop of 16-year-old girls has their blood let to prove “purity”; if they bleed gold they are sentenced to death. Deka ‘fails’ this test and is given a choice: subject herself to further torture at the hands of her former community or leave to fight for the empire. It’s not a particularly difficult decision.“Never forget: the same gift they praise you for now they will kill you for later.”The Gilded Ones grapples with a lot, colorism, tribalism, religion, racism, etc. But the greatest struggle the young women in this book face isn’t the monsters they have to fight, the Deathshrieks, but an overwhelming amount of misogyny. Women are forced to wear masks in public, they cannot go anywhere unaccompanied. Girls are the only ones who are tested for ‘purity’ and have little to no options for their lives besides marriage and children....and those are the ones with non-magical blood. The alaki are little more than fodder for the Empire, a government that instituted the blood ceremony and Death Mandate that condemned them to this fate.The author, Namina Forna, writes in a letter before the start of the novel how both her experiences in Sierra Leone and the United States informed her depiction of Otera. I’ve grown tired of excusing “dEePlY pAtRiArChAl” societies as anything other than ingrained sexist bullshit seeking cover under the guise of tradition, both in the US and abroad. Forna does an excellent job writing within one of those societies, while expertly critiquing it. Sometimes it can be exhausting having to read about institutional trauma over and over again, but here it’s handled in a way that doesn’t feel gratuitous or glossed-over. “Legend is what humans call the things that they do not understand.”The world-building in the Otera is exceptional, and this is a great foundation for the Deathless series. It was easy to read and almost impossible to put down. I honestly don’t know how I got approved for an eARC before the quarantine forced the release date back, but I’m incredibly grateful that I did! The characters are vivid and both their triumphs and pain is palpable. It’s an amazing story and I’m calling it now—in eight months The Gilded Ones will be published and it will be a revelation.*Thanks to Random House Children’s & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

review: This one felt like a lot of preamble. I gave some of the slower parts in Blood of Elves a pass because it had the more difficult task of transitioningThis one felt like a lot of preamble. I gave some of the slower parts in Blood of Elves a pass because it had the more difficult task of transitioning from short stories to novels & being the first in the novel series, but what’s the excuse here?? The entire first half of the book felt like nothing was happening and wow it just draaaaaagged. And maybe I was just zoned out for the relevant stuff, but by the time the big second-act battle started up, I had no idea what was happening. I didn’t know who anyone was or why they were fighting or who was winning and which side I was supposed to be cheering for. Geralt, as usual, decided to sit on his hands when it came time to make ~*~dEsCiSiOnS~*, so I ended up just going along with whatever name I recognized. Oh, Triss! I know her! Get em, Triss! Wait, that’s Tissaia, I know her too! Are Triss and Tissaia fighting? Now I’m confused. IdkAnd I am unable to not keep pointing this out—Sapkowski doesn’t grasp how women interact with one another. The way the enchantresses spoke and moved around that party in the third chapter was just cringy. “‘Oh you men . . . You don’t understand anything. How can you show off your dress or figure if you’re hiding behind a table in the glow and smoke?’“ Like, what woman would say this type of thing? Out loud?? To other humans??? They’re supposed to be all-powerful and brilliant! Unless, of course, they come across some jewelry or eyeshadow, then they devolve into squealing, vapid tarts, amiright? I also absolutely hated the way he wrote Yennefer as a jealous, petty bitch and Triss as a skittish animal in need of a good kicking. Geralt comes off as absolutely pathetic here, like a lost, horny boy that’s never seen boobs before. How can you tell a fantasy series is written through the male gaze? No woman would end a description of a dress like this: “Fashion demanded it be split halfway up the thigh, but Sabrina wore hers split to halfway up her hip. And a very nice hip at that.” These errant thoughts are eyeroll-inducing, but hard to miss once you begin to notice them. There was good stuff too, lest you think I’m just gonna rag on it the whole time. Dandelion playing interpreter for Ciri during Geralt and Yennefer’s fight was a bit of unexpected sweetness I didn’t know I needed. Dandelion, that little weed, has definitely grown on me. Yennefer when she’s not being possessive is wonderful, and I love Ciri’s feralness. Geralt was kind of lame in this one. (view spoiler)[My favorite chapter is weirdly the one where Ciri is wandering around a desert with a Unicorn, eating bugs and being friends like Timon & Pumba. It was tedious, but I also couldn’t get enough???? (hide spoiler)]At this point, I can’t really help imagining each scene as it would play out in the TV series. I just think Lauren Schmidt Hissrich is going to really nail some of parts where Sapkowski floundered, like the aforementioned party. I’m also going to need Netflix to announce some upcoming casting decisions ASAP so I can start pairing names with faces—hopefully that’ll help me keep some of these Polish names straight....more

review: The author, Maxine Mei-Fung Chung, is a psychotherapist, so I was excited to see what she brought to the ‘multiple-personality psychological thriller’The author, Maxine Mei-Fung Chung, is a psychotherapist, so I was excited to see what she brought to the ‘multiple-personality psychological thriller’ sub-genre, but I was left mostly disappointed.The language was overly descriptive and stiff, which I would guess comes from her highly academic background. The medical insight was interesting, but that didn’t make up for the way the characters spoke and acted. They were like if aliens tried to infiltrate Earth by binging thousands of hours of reality TV and then tried to speak to regular people like that. They just came off as hollow and artificial human interactions. Plus multiple personalities can come off as kind of gimicky if it’s not done right. I didn’t really buy Daniel Rosenstein as a medical professional based off of a number of issues, least of all breaching doctor-patient confidentiality, which was surprising considering Mei-Fung Chung’s background. Alexa was an interesting character, but there was too much other stuff going on for me to really connect with her. And like others have said, the sex trafficking angle felt like a massive misstep. I hope the author keeps at it, though, and maybe her next one will work better for me.*Thanks to William Morrow & Goodreads for an advance copy!...more

title: The Court of Miracles        (A Court of Miracles, #1)
author: Grant, Kester
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’m not sure what this had set out to be, but I don’t think it got there in the end. There was so much clunky plot, all linked together with just the I’m not sure what this had set out to be, but I don’t think it got there in the end. There was so much clunky plot, all linked together with just the barest whisper of continuity, that I had a hard time taking anything that was happening seriously. Which is really a disservice to the setting because there’s so much that’s supposed to be taken seriously. There’s sex trafficking and child abuse and death—plenty of the nastier side from Revolutionary France, but the stakes didn’t feel real. Everything was clipped. The author jumps from one huge plot point to another with no real explanation or breathing room. There’s fast-paced, and then there’s The Court of Miracles. Too much happened too soon.I liked the dynamic between the characters and there was a lot of potential, but where it reaaaaally dropped the ball was with the world-building. Maybe 80% of the dialogue was exposition? And there was no tension that wasn’t contrived. The initial conflict, Nina’s sister being sold into prostitution, is skipped over quickly, and I guess now she’s older and trying to protect some random girl? That she planned to do the same thing (sell into sex slavery) to, only to get cold feet at the last possible second? It’s a premise so flimsy it’s almost goofy, which is not how I wanted to feel reading about such a grave subject.What caught me the most off-guard was how much Grant seemed to really want to emulate a handful of other books. When the description said ”Les Miserables meets Six of Crows“, I didn’t think it would be those two stories literally smashed together. I actually had to stop reading at one point and double check this wasn’t a retelling or fanficton or something like that. Turns out, it kind of is? But I didn’t see that detail mentioned anywhere except in user s. And other than the time, place and assorted character names, I struggle to see how this would be classified as a ‘retelling’. I’m curious to see what others think as the s keep trickling in, but there’s still some buzz around this one and I can understand why. The marketing is beautiful and the blurb is attention-grabbing, and I actually really like her writing style. But I went into this wanting to love it, to be swept away in a new fantasy series, and I don’t think that’s going to happen at this point.*Thanks to Random House Children’s & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Rule of Wolves        (King of Scars, #2)
author: Bardugo, Leigh*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Congrats to the 2021 Goodreads Choice ✨WINNER✨ in Young Adult Fantasy & Science Fiction!And at last, here we are. Returned to the mesmerizing worlCongrats to the 2021 Goodreads Choice ✨WINNER✨ in Young Adult Fantasy & Science Fiction!And at last, here we are. Returned to the mesmerizing world of the Grishaverse, and just in time for the new Shadow and Bone series on Netflix! Two long years since the last installment, and we’ve all been anxiously awaiting Leigh Bardugo’s seventh dalliance into Ravka, Fjerda, Ketterdam and the like. Now the only thing left is to see if she was able to live up to the incredibly high bar she set for herself.[image]No pressure, though!!!!!I did have the benefit of reading with my good friends Natalie Paige & Madison which was a great way to unpack all of the thoughts I was having while moving through this 600 page chonker. We’d been hyping each other up in the weeks leading up to the release and could not wait to rip into Rule of Wolves once it appeared on our doorsteps. In the end, I think we may have bought into the hype a little too much, and it didn’t quite reach our high expectations. The biggest running grievance in this book would probably be the way that Leigh Bardugo seemed to ignore a lot of the previous rules she’d established in the last six books set in this world. Many of the main characters were suddenly overpowered and a lot of the storylines felt underdeveloped. A few could probably have been dropped altogether and it would have made the story stronger. I just had a difficult time getting as fully invested in the new and even some of the old characters plot lines because the stakes felt so artificially raised.The characters from the main trilogy who haven’t really been present in the recent books, that made appearances in this one felt markedly different from how they were originally written. And on one hand, while I loved seeing familiar faces from Six of Crows, they also felt shoehorned in at times. This book was equal parts fan service and fan disservice, and there was one death in particular that was so pointlessly cruel that I might not be able to forgive Leigh any time soon. (view spoiler)[David. His death served no purpose except as a cheap gut punch in a series that has been overwhelmed with suffering. I don’t understand Bardugo’s obsession with punishing Genya at every turn. It didn’t even make sense for David to be where he was or die the way he did. I feel like she did this for shock value and nothing more, which is disappointing. (hide spoiler)]It’s hard to pin down the exact focus in a book with so many revolving points of view, but if King of Scars was about Nina’s grief and Nikolai’s ascension, then Rule of Wolves is where Zoya experiences both those and more. Even with huge number of perspectives, all more spread out from each other than we’ve ever seen from Bardugo, it’s still it’s hard to see this as anything other than the Book of Zoya. She’s got new powers that she has to learn to control and embrace, and a long list of friends and allies that she hasn’t really given herself the space to mourn. I enjoyed witnessing her transformation, but found the end point of it to be stretching believability.And maybe believability isn’t the most important thing in a fantasy book, but I just expected the author to pay more attention to logistics than she did. Things happened not because they made sense, but because she wanted them to end up that way. There was a secret whisper network that wasn’t elaborated on but provided a stunning amount of information and passed messages with the ease of sending a text. Characters almost seemed to teleport with how fast they traveled huge distances. What took years for every other similar character to master was learned in weeks because it would be more convenient that way. I just wish Bardugo had leaned more into the plausible struggles over the manufactured ones.If I sound like I was more than a little disappointed with this book, that’s because I was. It was as readable as ever, but could have taken serious editorial cuts. I wouldn’t say this is anywhere close to Bardugo’s best work—that remains the untouchable Six of Crows duology. And though there’s no concrete plans of when either series will continue, what is obvious is that they will ~eventually~. My only hope is that if and when she revisits Ketterdam and the Dregs, that Leigh doesn’t inject whatever she’s been doing in the King of Scars series into the next Six of Crows book. I’m only interested in it if she’s able to continue the original magic of those books PLEASE.[image]Don’t make us find you Leigh ...more

title: Take Me Apart
author: Sligar, Sara*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I could not pull myself away from Sara Sligar’s debut, Take Me Apart. I probably sound like a broken record every time I laud a slow-burn suspense novI could not pull myself away from Sara Sligar’s debut, Take Me Apart. I probably sound like a broken record every time I laud a slow-burn suspense novel like this, but it really was that good. Her writing is both expressive and smart, with characters that are so distinctly human that they probably resemble actual people you know. There’s so many things I loved about this book; this  is probably just going to be me listing them out for you here. This is the first thriller I’ve read in a while where someone isn’t murdered in the first few chapters. So if you’re expecting the story to start with a bang, you may be kept waiting a while. Instead we follow Kate, a former journalist, now an archivist, who takes a job in the California Bay Area in order to get away from her old life and career. There’s a lot that’s left murky surrounding her past, and as she slowly peels back the layers of the family she’s now working for, we get to uncover more of what Kate’s kept hidden.My primary draw initially was to Miranda Brand, the famous artist whom Kate is now chronicling. She’s a fascinating character, and some of the best parts in the book are her transcripts, diary entries and letters that come at the end of each chapter. Kate becomes increasingly entangled in the enigma that is Miranda Brand, but also by her son, Theo, and his two young children, Jemima and Oscar.I was struck at how thematic this mystery was. Through the flashbacks to the late 80s and early 90s back to present day, Sligar really delved into some heavy topics, and did so with immense skill. Take Me Apart covers mental health, both the realities of and the stigma surrounding it, public image vs private life, nature vs nurture and more all while keeping and building tension. There’s even a peek into the utter tediousness and ineptitude of the US healthcare system.This is definitely a post-#MeToo novel. So much of Kate and Miranda’s lives are shaped by the men around them. Sligar uses her ‘strong female characters’ as an indictment of the world they live in. Through Miranda’s work specifically, we’re asked to examine the way that female pain is monetized and romanticized as a consumable piece of art. We believe so much has changed, but has it really? I’m not sure, but I find it hard to imagine this story being written in the same way even five years ago.But beyond all of that, this was just a really addictive book. My pulse started racing when the characters’ did, and I couldn’t turn down my frenetic reading pace until I finished it. I haven’t had my mood shifted in this way for quite a while, and I’m excited to see what Sara Sligar comes out with next.*Thanks to Farrar, Straus and Giroux & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: You Are Not Alone
author: Hendricks, Greer*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a weird game of cat and mouse that was interesting at times, but I really didn’t connect to. I would probably classify this is as some sort oThis was a weird game of cat and mouse that was interesting at times, but I really didn’t connect to. I would probably classify this is as some sort of Suspense novel, because there wasn’t much of a mystery in sight. The dueling perspectives didn’t really work for me here. There’s no reason for it and all it ends up doing is getting exposition out of the way. Flipping back and forth between Shay and the two sisters, Cassandra & Jane, as well as flashbacks to each member of their ‘group’ took me out of the story every time. All of the tension leaks out when we know the sisters and their squad are nefarious from the get-go. It’s not even just hinted at, we hear from Cassandra and Jane themselves how they plan to screw over Shay almost immediately. Maybe if it had been set up where we start only seeing things from Shay’s perspective, then have a Gone Girl-style tone shift it would have worked better. So much of the initial conflict in the story comes from miscommunication and misinterpretation, which is a pet peeve of mine. For people who apparently ‘think of everything’, Cassandra and Jane have laughably bad intuition.I’ve read An Anonymous Girl, also by author duo Greer Hendricks & Sarah Pekkanen, and I had similar middling feelings about it. Ever since their joint debut thriller, The Wife Between Us, they’ve had monumental success in the genre. I don’t begrudge them that, but perhaps it’s time I start looking outside of the same dozen or so familiar (and predominately white) faces for something different in the Mystery/Thriller category. I’m always open to suggestions!...more

title: The Cousins
author: McManus, Karen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Now a Goodreads Choice finalist in Young Adult Fiction!Karen McManus is always my cure for a reading slump. There’s something about her YA thrilleNow a Goodreads Choice finalist in Young Adult Fiction!Karen McManus is always my cure for a reading slump. There’s something about her YA thrillers that immediately pull me in and keep me compulsively turning pages until the end. Though a little different in tone from her previous hits like One of Us Is Lying and Two Can Keep a Secret, The Cousins is no exception to that rule.Milly, Aubrey and Jonah Story have never met their grandmother, Mildred Story, before. She mysteriously cut off contact from their parents twenty-four years ago, and hasn’t seen any of her children or grandchildren since. So it’s strange that all these years later she’s reached out and invited the three of them to visit her estate on Gull Cove Island now that they’re all nearly grown. Even stranger, they all accept and spend their summer living and working at one of her hotels, each seeking out something different from their elusive grandmother. As always, McManus uses a roving perspective, moving between the distinct voices of Milly, Aubrey and Jonah with ease. As the cousins get to know each other, they also begin to learn more about the history of the island they’re now living on, and by extension their grandmother. Gull Cove Island is a little-known east coast getaway that features local residents and wealthy vacationers alike. There’s layers of mystery and decades-old unanswered questions for the Story cousins to unravel, especially when they find their own parents at the center of it.I liked this book, but it felt a good deal slower than McManus’s previous works, especially in the beginning. I’m used to her books hitting the ground running and with The Cousins you have to wait for the story to come to a boil. The ending also felt a little rushed, probably because of the slower pacing in the first part. That said, I’m glad that the author is trying out something different from her last three books, and I hope she feels like she can branch out even more in the future. Karen McManus also has an upcoming book in 2021, You'll Be the Death of Me, which is sold as Ferris Bueller’s Day off meets a YA Murder mystery. It sounds amazing and EXACTLY up McManus’s alley, so I’m extremely excited to read that one![image]*Thanks to Delacorte Press, Random House Children’s & NetGalley for an advance copy!**For more book talk & s, follow me on Instagram at @elle_mentbooks!...more

title: The Sun Down Motel

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Part murder mystery, part ghost story, this was a fun thriller and first introduction for me to the writings of Simone St. James. The Sundown Motel isPart murder mystery, part ghost story, this was a fun thriller and first introduction for me to the writings of Simone St. James. The Sundown Motel is face-paced and full of surprises, if a little unrealistic. Still I thoroughly enjoyed this ride while it was happening.The story bounces between Carly Kirk in 2017 and her aunt Viv in 1982. Carly is investigating the mysterious disappearance of her aunt from the Sun Down 35 years ago, which was never solved. She drives to the town of Fell in upstate New York and finds that not much has changed in the time since her aunt has been there. The fact that almost nothing has been altered, including the dated rooms and phone lines, adds a sinister quality to the setting.The people Carly meets while investigating struck me as kind of weird. All of them seem too eager to help and too perfectly set up to give her whatever she needs at any given moment, like housing, information, etc. I don’t like characters introduced primarily as plot devices, which would be about three-quarters of the ones St. James included here. Carly and Viv are compelling enough, though, and it’s interesting to watch one retrace the footsteps of another, both intentionally and unintentionally, in search of answers.A nitpick I had: some of the names. Every time I saw Carly’s full name written out I misread it as Charlie, which is blech. (view spoiler)[And I don’t know if Simone St. James watches American Horror Story, but having one of Hess’s fake names be James March (in 1982, no less) seems a little on the nose, as he was a fictional, murderous hotel owner. (hide spoiler)]It’s a good, engaging thriller. Nothing groundbreaking, but still a great time. The supernatural elements may be a dealbreaker or dealmaker for some people, but they didn’t matter to me either way. It didn’t enhance or diminish my experience, but I thought I’d mention it in case it does for any potential readers....more

title: The Only Good Indians
author: Jones, Stephen Graham*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I haven’t read much written by Indigenous authors, unfortunately, so I was very excited to get my hands on The Only Good Indians. Stephen Graham JonesI haven’t read much written by Indigenous authors, unfortunately, so I was very excited to get my hands on The Only Good Indians. Stephen Graham Jones is an esteemed Horror writer, which makes someone like me, a big scaredy-baby, a little nervous to be honest. The plotting of this book is interesting. I’d say the majority of the time is spent on character development and relatively benign interactions of regular Native people living their lives. It almost hits you like a sucker-punch when everything starts going off the rails. Seriously—one moment I was reading about a guy obsessed with his ladder, and pages later someone has their head caved in. Part one in the novel, The House That Ran Red, didn’t have that much tension through the beginning and middle. But after a mid-book bloody climax, there’s a discernible current of it running through every seemingly innocuous action or phrase uttered by a new character. I ended up being pretty shaken thereafter.Not sure if I can say much else without giving stuff away. I went into this book blind, something I don’t normally do, but it left me caught off guard with the way the storyline progressed. I can see it’s getting some mixed s, but for those who are uncertain if they want to read it for that reason, I’d say it’s worth your time.*Thanks to Gallery Books, Netgalley & BookishFirst for advance copies!...more

title: God-Level Knowledge Darts: Life Lessons from the Bronx
author: Desus
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not the typical book the Goodreads community flocks to, but Desus & Mero are becoming more and more mainstream as time goes on. I guess until they getNot the typical book the Goodreads community flocks to, but Desus & Mero are becoming more and more mainstream as time goes on. I guess until they get all the way there though:Trying to locate the Bodega Hive on Goodreads...[image][image]After this point I’ll just assume whoever is visiting this book’s Goodreads page is already familiar with the comedy duo Desus & Mero, so I won’t spend time explaining either of them or their unique communication style. I’m reading from an eARC I received pre-quarantine, so I can’t speak to the finished print copies, but Mero’s portions of the book are written ENTIRELY WITH CAPS-LOCK ON, just like his tweets. Desus uses normal syntax, but the font was actually significantly larger than the standard size. Perhaps the editor wanted their words to be more visually distinguishable? I’m not sure. The book isn’t that long, with nine chapters plus a preface and introduction. The topics covered include things from drugs to relationships to toxic masculinity, and whatever else pops into either of their heads; there’s really no set rubric here. And if there was ever any doubt: this book is written 100% by Desus & Mero. I don’t know if I’ve ever read a nonfiction book written more thoroughly in the authors’ voices. I will say if you’ve never seen their show before, it might be a little jarring at first, but that’s all part of their charm. The tone of God-Level Knowledge Darts is similar to a podcast, where each take turns, sometimes interrupting one another, discussing a general topic. I haven’t listened to the Bodega Boys podcast, but it feels very off the cuff. Mero is frequently high while writing (something he brings up multiple times), but that doesn’t take away from the conversation the two of them are having; it only enhances it. I kind of wish I had an audiobook copy narrated by the authors instead, but this was still an enjoyable read for me to take a break from some heavier ones.If you’re a fan of theirs, you’ll be a fan of this book too. If you’re not, maybe check out clips from their Showtime show on YouTube and see for yourself. I’ll leave y’all with this quote from Dark Desus himself:“So take that final breath, laugh a muffled, choking laugh, and as you pass out, let your final words be, ‘The brand is brolic.’”*Thanks to Random House & Netgalley for an advance copy!**For more book talk & s, follow me on Instagram at @elle_mentbooks!...more

title: Transcendent Kingdom
author: Gyasi, Yaa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A debut like Homegoing, so massive in scope, was always going to a a difficult thing to follow. I can appreciate the pressure Gyasi was under to measuA debut like Homegoing, so massive in scope, was always going to a a difficult thing to follow. I can appreciate the pressure Gyasi was under to measure up to that book, and I think the direction she decided to go in with her sophomore novel was a smart one. Like how an actor who comes out of one distinct and identifiable role may want to pursue a next one that is completely different in order to avoid being type-cast in the future. While Homegoing was a novel spaced out over more than a half a dozen generations and two continents, introducing a new character focus and time period with each new chapter, Transcendent Kingdom doesn’t try to expand even further beyond that. Instead, it turns inward. The story follows Gifty, a woman in her twenties who is, and I’m going to take this directly from the description as the nuances of academia are beyond me, ”a fifth-year candidate in neuroscience at Stanford School of Medicine studying reward-seeking behavior in mice and the neural circuits of depression and addiction.” Essentially, she is observing and experimenting on mice in order to see if they can learn impulse-control. I’m a vegetarian for ethical reasons, so this wasn’t exactly my favorite portion of the book. But what I was able to glean from the scientific parts seemed interesting enough.What Gifty grapples with in Transcendent Kingdom, though, isn’t really anything to do with her work. The real focus here is on Gifty and her family: her mother, father and brother, Nana. Since leaving Ghana for the United States when her brother was a baby, Gifty was born several years later after the family had settled in Alabama. They struggled financially, with Gifty’s mother working long hours as a caretaker and her father unable to secure much work at all. It’s an added strain on a family already dealing with the stress of immigrating, the racism of their newly adopted community and the difficulty of raising two children in an unfamiliar place. A lot of these details are revealed through flashbacks woven into the modern day narrative of Gifty while she’s working at her lab. For Gyasi, the timeline wasn’t as structured as her last book, and I did get thrown off a few times. What’s apparent right away is that both Gifty’s brother and father are out of the picture and her mother is reeling from something yet to be named. Eventually more of these histories are revealed, and there’s a quiet devastation in finding out why Gifty and her mother are the way they are. Because of the nature of her studies and some of her family turmoil, a lot of the story centers around substance abuse. I’ve read several books this year where addiction, particularly the opioid crisis in America, is at the root of the narrative. It honestly doesn’t get any easier to read about. All the same feelings of hope flattening into despair and directionless frustration come flooding back as if they never left. And I guess they don’t have much of a reason to leave, really. What have we as a society done to help the people struggling? Which of the parties responsible have been held accountable? The answers are next to nothing and none.Much of the internal conflict within Gifty is that battle between religion and science. I wouldn’t call myself a religious person, and I didn’t have the stringent Christian upbringing that she did. But I can empathize with that struggle between what you’ve been taught and what you end up discovering on your own. It can really unravel some fundamental truths you may have held about who you are and what your place in the world is, so it’s hard to blame those who end up avoiding that personal confrontation all together. It’s difficult and a bit of a leap of faith to unlearn something when you’re not yet sure what’s going to take its place.By the end, though, I felt like I was still missing something. I’m having a hard time deciphering what Yaa Gyasi’s overall thesis of the book is. I think Transcendent Kingdom is well-written and heartbreaking, but it didn’t make me feel leveled in the way that Homegoing did—the peaks never reach as high and the depths never quite so low. It’s still an accomplishment for Gyasi, and indicative that she still has plenty to offer with her writing. I’m looking forward to any and all future works from her....more

title: The Glass Hotel
author: Mandel, Emily St. John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It’s clear Emily St. John Mandel is an exquisite writer and storyteller. I had no idea where this novel was headed at any point, but I still was incliIt’s clear Emily St. John Mandel is an exquisite writer and storyteller. I had no idea where this novel was headed at any point, but I still was inclined to let her lead me there, wherever it may have been. Even when it clocked in at 90% completed on my Kindle, I still didn’t feel like I was seeing the entire picture. But truthfully, I don’t really think I get this novel, even after finishing it. It feel about The Glass Hotel similarly to how I feel about Lana Del Rey. They’re both artful and smart, I can somewhat enjoy the aesthetic and I appreciate why people like them....but something, somewhere goes over my head. And that’s okay! Actually, the fact that neither are real ‘crowd-pleasers’ in some sense might even strengthen the appeal for those that are already fans.I have no real meaningful critique of the writing, so I won’t offer that here. My biggest struggle was with who exactly I was supposed to care about. Vincent? Maybe? Not her brother or any of her love interests, or any of the people involved in the financial scheme. I felt removed from the characters we were supposed to be following, kind of like I was watching some of the videos she would take of the scenery around her. The book had a surreal quality I just can’t quite put into wordsI found the beginning to be disjointed and a little difficult to get into. I kept coming back to this book’s Goodreads page to see if I’d find a  that would clue me in on how I was supposed to be reacting to the events of the novel, but for the most part all I found was general gushing or complaints of being boring. For anyone wondering, yes it’s a little boring. Some parts are interesting, I guess, but I didn’t find anything particularly engrossing. I feel like most of the complaints I’ve levied are ones that normally don’t dissuade me, but for some reason something in The Glass Hotel didn’t click into place. I’m excited to read Station Eleven, though, as I’ve heard really nothing outside of positive feedback on that work from Mandel. Still, I’m a little bummed that I don’t have the same warm, fuzzy feelings about this novel that it seems so many others do....more

title: Burn Our Bodies Down
author: Power, Rory*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well this one definitely threw me for a loop. I‘ll admit I was pretty cocky and thought I knew exactly where this book was headed, but even when I wasWell this one definitely threw me for a loop. I‘ll admit I was pretty cocky and thought I knew exactly where this book was headed, but even when I was on the right track, I got the degree very, very wrong. At one point when I was maybe halfway through reading I commented on Chelsea’s status update that I was “waiting for everything to go off the rails”, and through time and space Rory Power HEARD me and decided to grant me that request. Be careful what you wish for, y’all!!The story starts with 17 year-old Margot and her mom, Josephine, barely getting by in their small apartment and meager income. Beyond poverty, there’s a massive amount of simmering tension between the two of them, at near-constant risk of erupting. Eventually this leads to Margot seeking out the family that her mother has always kept hidden from her.I’m always down for a complex family dynamic. I appreciated the relationship between Margot, her mother and grandmother, Vera, and loved dissecting what each microaggression (or full-on aggression) lobbed at one another meant. There were plenty of secrets that we get to uncover along the way, especially since none of the women are particularly forthright.“Does understanding her mean I have to forgive her?”I also adored Power’s writing. She captures these really specific, human moments between her characters just beautifully. My Kindle copy is filled with highlighted passages, and I’m guessing anyone who’s had even a somewhat-toxic relationship with a family member will be struck by her insights. I ended up skipping Wilder Girls last year and clearly that was my mistake. I know people were guuuushing about the cover, but I hope that the book itself ends up being just as engrossing.That said, I still feel like the story was missing something. Parts just felt underdeveloped. Tess was promising, but both her and Eli seemed like they were added as a means to and end. I never quite understood Josephine, and I think some of her ‘quirks’ needed to be explained a little more. It felt a bit rushed, especially by the end, and I wish Power had taken more time to elaborate on this really creative premise. And it felt pretty dark for a YA novel; I get that the heroine is a teenager, but I don’t know if I would market this to teenagers. In all, there was a lot of good stuff to work with, but it still felt unfinished. I am absolutely interested in reading more from her, though, and I can’t wait to see what she puts out next.*Thanks to Random House Children’s & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Valentine
author: Wetmore, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “She is a flash of lightning and its aftermath, a fire bearing down on a copse of juniper and mesquite.”Here is another story about the strength and r“She is a flash of lightning and its aftermath, a fire bearing down on a copse of juniper and mesquite.”Here is another story about the strength and resilience of women. This time set in Odessa, Texas in the 1970s, where an oil boom has rippling effects for all who reside there.Sometimes I feel exhausted after reading yet another book where women and girls are tread over and over again, and I decide maybe I’ll take a break from them for a while. But then a new one with a pretty cover and main character with just as much resolve as personality comes barreling into the world and I just...can’t resist. They never stop being relevant, so I guess we can expect even more novels of this nature going forward.As a debut, Valentine is a sound offering from Elizabeth Wetmore. She writes scenery beautifully and women with an abundance of depth and complexity. Theres little in this West Texas setting that you can’t see sprawling before your eyes, dust you can taste, sweat you can smell. Everything is atmospheric, for better or worse, and the inhabitants feel so alive they might as well be sitting in the room with you.Where I started to fall out of the story was with the style. I’ve read books before where there’s no quotations around dialogue, like Girl, Woman, Other, that didn’t take away from the plot like this one did. The characters start speaking in the middle of paragraphs, constantly, and it removes you from what’s happening. All the tension leaks out like a slowly deflating tire.I also just feel like this story was missing...something. There’s all these powerful moments that amount to nothing. No characters have changed over the length of the novel, at least not for the better. A couple are worse off than they were at the start and most remained static. There’s no real comeuppance, no lesson, just harsh reality. I might have had a better reaction to this type of ending if there seemed like a point that was trying to be made to the reader, but I couldn’t find even that. What was Wetmore trying to get across? That bad things happen to girls and women? That people don’t care? That it’s worse for marginalized communities? I feel like if you’re the type of person to pick up this book, it’s likely you already know all of this. So when I ask, ‘What was the point?’, I don’t mean it petulantly. I just want to know her line of thinking when she decided to write this novel. And on a kind of separate note...basically every misgiving I’ve had about having kids and crossing over from ‘woman’ to ‘someone’s mom’ is laid out here. And I think most women regardless of their current child count will be able to identify with much of what these characters experience. While those who are already parents will probably find their choices affirming, as someone without kids who doesn’t plan on having any, I feel like my reaction is the opposite of what the author intended. The loss of identity coupled with the (still present) societal pressures just further my belief that that’s not what I want.I don’t mean to discourage people from reading it, because I enjoyed my time with Valentine overall. But I feel like I read three-quarters of a book and the resolution was lost somewhere. Maybe someone else who absolutely loved this one will be able to explain to me what I’m missing, I don’t know. The cover really is gorgeous, though....more

title: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes        (The Hunger Games, #0)

review: Liiiiiisten, I love a good unsolicited sequel. I still stand by my opinion that The Testaments was a good follow-up to The Handmaid's Tale. I’ll alwayLiiiiiisten, I love a good unsolicited sequel. I still stand by my opinion that The Testaments was a good follow-up to The Handmaid's Tale. I’ll always read weird offshoots of a series I liked, even if they don’t contribute much world-building or character development. Like Midnight Sun, the companion novel to Twilight from Edward’s point of view? I’m there, man. You don’t have to convince me that a book is ‘necessary’; it just has to be interesting enough to keep reading.And that’s why The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes was such a bummer. I listened to the audiobook, which is the only way I would have been able to finish it......passively listening at 1.5-2.0 speed. I don’t really have a lot to add to the discourse here, but I just want to underline what I found to be the most disappointing. The worst thing was that it was so, so dull. The second worst thing was the way Collins turned a female tribute into the romantic interest for a soon-to-be-tyrant. And the third worst thing was reading everything from Snow’s perspective. No characters presented in this novel ended up being worth exploring, which is kind of sad. Panem and its inhabitants felt entirely colorless.I hate to pile on, but it is what it is. Also Santino Fontana has a beautiful singing voice, so why the fuck did he chant all the songs (there are several) in this book? And his ‘woman voices’ are awful. I love him, but he could not make me love this story, unfortunately....more

title: Against the Loveless World
author: Abulhawa, Susan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was first drawn to this book by the beautiful and eye-catching cover, but after reading the synopsis I immediately added it to my TBR. It could be dI was first drawn to this book by the beautiful and eye-catching cover, but after reading the synopsis I immediately added it to my TBR. It could be due to American media and news coverage, but I haven’t been exposed to much of the experiences of the Palestinian people. Any Gaza & West Bank related news in the US has typically been filtered through a strong pro-Israeli lens, which paints an uneven picture of the ongoing conflict in the region. Told as flashbacks between present day Nahr as she is imprisoned in The Cube, an in humane solitary cell in an Israeli prison, and Nahr as she comes of age and into adulthood, Susan Abulhawa gives readers a peek into the struggles refugees face when they are deprived of the safety of their community and home. Moving from Kuwait to Jordan to Palestine, Nahr is forced to grow up fast in order to provide for herself and her family amongst that instability. She goes through a lot, and it’s painful to read at times. There could be some trigger warnings on this book, (view spoiler)[sexual assault, abuse, torture (hide spoiler)], but these details are not added flippantly; they’re included in order to give a realistic depiction of what someone like Nahr could feasibly experience.I think what struck me most while reading was how restrained Nahr’s actions were throughout the novel. I was expecting her to have a darker outlook, a more “radicalized” ideology based on the multitude of injustices and indignities that get thrust upon her again and again. But almost everything she does is for the sake of survival, and even when she occasionally lashes out beyond that, it’s with the expectation that she’ll be hit back ten times as hard in retribution—and she always is. I’m not sure if this is due to to Abulhawa’s ability to write an incredibly sympathetic character or because the treatment of Palestinians is so abhorrent that there’s no way to possibly root against the characters. Honestly, it’s probably a combination of the two; a triumph for an author in the midst of writing devastation. I’m really interested to read more of Abulhawa’s work, especially Mornings in Jenin, which has received some glowing s. There’s something to be said about educating through empathy, and if reading fiction about a place and people which have been historically disregarded helps teach us about Palestine’s over fifty-year occupation by the Israeli military (since 1967), then I’m all for that. The description of the conditions political prisoners live in, the annexation tactics to drive Palestinians from their homes and the actual war crimes that individual soldiers as well as the military in its entirety engage in are breathtakingly despicable. And I’m glad authors like Abulhawa are here and writing about them.The structure of the book worked for me on the whole, but I think the pacing could have been more consistent. I also tried to listen to the audiobook version, and it wasn’t as good as it could have been. Susan Abulhawa narrates her own book and while I appreciate when authors do this sometimes, I don’t think that was the best choice in this case. She spoke so quietly, I had to blast my phone’s speakers in order to make out the words. For works like memoirs and essay collections, it makes more sense for the author to double as a narrator, but for fiction....I don’t know. I think it’s generally better to leave it to the professionals. Maybe she couldn’t find an available narrator of Palestinian descent? Whatever the reason, I preferred reading the physical book to listening to it.Thanks to Natalie for sending me a copy of this book! I told you I’d finally read it ...more

title: Blood of Elves        (The Witcher, #1)
author: Sapkowski, Andrzej
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After two collections of short stories, I’ve finally arrived at the first novel in The Witcher series. Though this is marked as book #1 in many placesAfter two collections of short stories, I’ve finally arrived at the first novel in The Witcher series. Though this is marked as book #1 in many places, including Goodreads, I really can’t imagine diving into this world without having some background knowledge and context for the events occurring. Whether that’s from The Last Wish and Sword of Destiny, the several video games or the first season of the Netflix show, I wouldn’t recommend having Blood of Elves be your introduction to Geralt, Yennefer and Ciri.For one thing, there’s so many time jumps! The chapters are massive, so they’re broken up with a few line breaks, but you really have no idea what time or place Andrzej Sapkowski is going to pick up at. I wish that he was more clear, but at this point part of reading a Witcher book is being confused halfway through it until whenever Sapkowski decides to explain what’s going on. It’s just part of the journey! We’re all Dandelion, wandering around, singing about earning coins until Geralt comes swooping in to save the day.Speaking of, Dandelion (Jaskier) is much less insufferable this time around. I take back my wish from my last  that something would eat him. And only two (!!) women completely lose control of their faculties and throw themselves at Geralt for no discernible reason. It’s still ridiculous, and so obviously written by a dude, but at least he didn’t leer at any rogue nipples this time around.The highlight in this book comes in the last chapter, where Ciri and Yennefer are sequestered alone with one another. They are a riot and have some of the best interactions of the series. Solely for that selection of 60-odd pages I will give this one five stars, though the rest was pretty solid as well. This book sets up a lot of events that are going to happen down the road, and I’m highly anticipating those future payoffs!...more

Galatea then comes to life and eventually bears a daughter, Paphus. This story doesn’t provide all of that information, but it’s not necessary to understand what’s happening. If you liked Circe you’ll like Galatea, both the characters and the stories. Though her story is much shorter, many of the themes echo one another and in the end you’re left with the same vengeful triumph....more

review: So I started reading this just before the protests started, and I was surprised how relevant the subject matter ended up being. The initial conflict, So I started reading this just before the protests started, and I was surprised how relevant the subject matter ended up being. The initial conflict, which takes place in the prologue, involves explicit police brutality and has some devastating consequences. I’m not usually someone who will avoid or seek out topical books to read, so this coinciding with real-world events didn’t really affect my reading either way. That said, I wanted to give people a heads-up before diving in because the description provided doesn’t mention that as far as I can see.I haven’t read anything by Joyce Carole Oates before, so I had no idea she wrote these absolute tomes when I requested this one. Truthfully, it’s difficult for me to stay focused on something so long, unless it’s a faster-paced plot. This one was a little too meandering for me to fully absorb, so I’m not going to leave a rating for it. But for those who are already fans of Oates, you’ll probably like this. The characters are complex and well-developed, the writing is beautiful and though it may be a ‘family drama’, the tension feels real and earned. A lot of ers I follow and who’s opinions I value really loved  Night. Sleep. Death. The Stars., so don’t discount this one just because it didn’t work for me!*Thanks to HarperCollins & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Holdout
author: Moore, Graham*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had a really good time reading The Holdout. Sometimes I feel like we’re barraged with thrillers and it’s hard to pick one to read next based off of I had a really good time reading The Holdout. Sometimes I feel like we’re barraged with thrillers and it’s hard to pick one to read next based off of a blurb and hundreds of similarly-styled covers. I don’t remember why I ended up picking this one, but I’m glad I did. Here is a twisty legal thriller about the murder of a white teenage girl (of course), but with a lot more self-awareness than I’ve come to expect from the genre. Jessica Silver is the 15-year-old daughter of a billionaire who has vanished under suspicious circumstances, with her former teacher having been charged with the crime. The book primarily follows present day Maya Seale, a juror from the 2009 case, but also flashes back to her fellow jury members’ perspectives during that time. In trying to draw parallels between this fictional case and the real world, I went looking to see if I could find an equivalent to the character of Lou Silver, if such a man actually exists.He does, if you’re wondering. “The Man Who Owns LA” as the New Yorker called him, in real life would be Philip Anschutz. He’s not exactly the same, obviously. For one, Anschutz is a conservative Christian, not Jewish like Silver. Additionally, he doesn’t have one teenaged daughter, but three grown children who presumably could have teenagers of their own. Is this information relevant at all to the story? Nope, not at all. But he’s a secretive American billionaire that owns just as many assets & businesses, if not more than the fictional Silver family in The Holdout, and I thought that might be interesting to people.My only detraction comes with the ending. It’s not bad, I just wish it had some more elaboration and consideration. (view spoiler)[I wanted the fact that the end result is two innocent black men dying to protect a rich, white family to be emphasized more. I also didn’t think Elaine needed to deliver that huge information dump at the end. Graham Moore had the opportunity to deliver a real Sharp Objects-style ending, and I don’t think he quite got there. I understand the jurors all rallying in the end, to a point, but they way in which they decide this is just a little too neat. It also didn’t feel like Maya or any other characters learned anything, there wasn’t any growth. Again, it was the two black men who paid the price for white women who were protecting themselves. Maya didn’t really even seem to finish drawing the comparison between herself, Jessica and the character of Mayella, who falsely accuses Tom Robinson in To Kill a Mockingbird. I feel like Maya sees herself more as Atticus Finch, who is precisely the opposite of her. I don’t know, it didn’t sit just right with me. (hide spoiler)]As a thriller, it’s easy to get sucked into and is a lot of fun if you don’t think about it too much. There’s plenty of red herrings and Moore writes from multiple points of view with ease. This is probably going to be one of the better in this category for the year....more

title: Sword of Destiny        (The Witcher, #0.7)
author: Sapkowski, Andrzej
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For those who are reading these books in order to get a better handle on the adapted series on Netflix (me too!), allow me to make it a little easier:For those who are reading these books in order to get a better handle on the adapted series on Netflix (me too!), allow me to make it a little easier:The Last Wish:2. The Witcher (S1, Ep 3)4. The Lesser Evil (S1, Ep 1)5. A Question of Price (S1, Ep 4)6. The Edge of the World (S1, Ep 2)7. The Last Wish (S1, Ep 5)Sword of Destiny:1. The Bounds of Reason (S1, Ep 6)6. Something More (S1, Ep 7 & 8)You’re welcome. Now while the last set of tales were mostly introductions to some of our main characters, such as Geralt of Rivia and Dandelion the bard, in Sword of Destiny we get to go deeper into relationships between these characters. There’s a good amount of world-building that I’m sure will make reading the first novel of the series, Blood of Elves, that much easier to understand & delve into. And instead of just a list of creatures Geralt either will or will not kill, we meet non-humans who are just as intelligent and sentient as man, but are hunted or hated by most humans. Geralt can relate to the disdain they receive and tries to find amicable resolutions to whatever conflict has arisen—to...somewhat mixed results.[image]The stories this time around aren’t based on traditional folktales, so there’s more freedom to explore without being confined to any preset storyline. But with dragons, dopplers, mermaids and dryads, most of the new magical races introduced are at least somewhat familiar to even casual fantasy fans. The Law of Surprise, which show watchers are probably familiar with, is elaborated on beyond what appeared in The Last Wish, and we finally get to spend more time with young Ciri as she makes her way towards her destiny. [image]I was also happy to see more of Yennefer in this collection. We were introduced to her in The Last Wish, and since then I’ve absolutely fallen in love with the character and the actress who portrays her in the Netflix series. The show has given her more autonomy, and since the show-runner is a woman, there’s less of that leering-male-fantasy aspect at play on screen. The book, however, just had to undercut any moment of power she had almost immediately. In the first story, The Bounds of Reason, she’s stripped almost naked, tied up provocatively, threatened with rape and then a ’good guy’ male character ogles and salaciously mocks her, refusing to look away when she tells him to. (view spoiler)[Seriously, Dandelion is such a fucking creep. Adore him in the show, but I hope he’s eaten by a cockatrice or zeugl in the books. (hide spoiler)]Though the female warriors are just as formidable as Geralt, if not more so, it’s almost like the author can’t let them ‘get away with’ that. They must be brought down a peg, and are sexualized and fetishized in the typical way men write women with a sex drive. One minute ferocious and hardened, then suddenly a giggling, pliable sex kitten. It’s so common to the genre that many readers may not even register it, but it’s just another way to undermine any woman given the slightest bit of agency, and it never stops being disappointing.I don’t want these criticisms to come off like I’m not a fan of the series; I am. In fact, I wouldn’t  something so thoroughly if I didn’t care for it at all. But more and more lately any complaint or even a comment not overwhelmingly positive on a piece of writing or media is taken as a petty condemnation of the work as a whole by someone with an axe to grind. It’s not wrong to want more from the writers and creators we love, especially when it could simply be a blindspot in their point of view, not an intentional exclusion. Feedback works—granted an author is open to it. Someone like Brandon Sanderson, who in interviews has been reflective on his past works and has admitted faults in his previous attempts at writing women. Though I haven’t, many who have read his books noticed a measurable difference.Anyways, I vastly enjoyed these stories, but they do feel like a prequel to the major events of this series. I’m excited to begin the ‘official’ first book, as soon as the copy my library just ordered arrives. In the mean time stay sexy, Henry Cavill, and don’t you DARE leave us to go back to DC. They don’t deserve you....more

title: They Called Us Enemy
author: Takei, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As charming as it is demoralizing, They Called Us Enemy hits you with the emotional heft that could only be experienced through a child’s eyes during As charming as it is demoralizing, They Called Us Enemy hits you with the emotional heft that could only be experienced through a child’s eyes during a war perpetuated by men. Beautifully illustrated by Harmony Becker, this is a graphic novel that follows the time the author, acclaimed Japanese-American actor George Takei, spent in American internment camps as a child during the Second World War.It’s a lesson in history that becomes a patriotic rallying cry. There’s plenty of parallels between the internment of immigrants at the southern border or the ban on Muslims entering the country. We acknowledge one injustice just in time to commit another. But despite the appalling conduct, the underlying message is one of hope. The reader is challenged to not just sit by passively, but to take an active role in shaping the way our country is run.Takei’s story is deeply personal, especially when speaking about his family. Woven throughout is a love letter and a thank you to his father, who guided their family through tumultuous times whilst being uncertain himself. It’s a bittersweet realization that not everyone who suffered received even the small vindications offered by the government years later.“Shame is a cruel thing. It should rest on the perpetrators, but they don’t carry it the way victims do.”Every classroom in America would stand to benefit from reading and teaching this graphic novel to their students. It’s both comprehensive in scope and individual to Mr. Takei’s life. It’s easier to follow a child’s story as a child, even into some dark places. I didn’t learn much about Japanese internment in school, but I know I learned more than my parents did. We have a long way to go in recognizing the demons and mistakes of our past, but we must or we’ll fail to stop ourselves from repeating them....more

title: Gone at Midnight: The Tragic True Story Behind the Unsolved Internet Sensation
author: Anderson, Jake*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Centered around the death of 21-year-old Elisa Lam, a Canadian student visiting Los Angeles who seemingly disappeared from the Cecil Hotel on January Centered around the death of 21-year-old Elisa Lam, a Canadian student visiting Los Angeles who seemingly disappeared from the Cecil Hotel on January 31, 2013, Jake Anderson relives the utter fascination both he and the public at large had with the strange circumstances surrounding this missing persons investigation.I think many people who begin this book, like me, will have at least some idea how this case ‘ends’, in a sense. We know generally what happened to Elisa Lam, so is there a point in reading in detail what befell a young woman with her whole life ahead of her? Here, Anderson is attempting to make the case that there is value in examining not only her life and death, but the way we as a true-crime-obsessed society respond to the loss of a very real person.I would generally agree with that assertion, but I still had trouble getting on board with this book. I don’t really think it accomplishes what it set out to do. I’m not going to spoiler tag this piece of information because I feel like at this point it’s common knowledge, but there’s no real evidence of any foul play in the case of Elisa Lam. There was a TON of speculation, which Anderson pours over in detail, even the completely batshit stuff. But the question becomes: Can you write an effective True Crime book if there was in fact no crime? I’m not so sure, and Gone at Midnight didn’t do much to change that impression.Some of the best books in this genre are ones where the author is embedded in the story. They either have a role in the investigation or are somehow connected with the people and events being investigated. The book ends up being a natural extension of their involvement, and this is a distinction I wanted to make with Anderson. He may personally feel as though he’s a part of Elisa’s case, but he is not. Countless people all over the world are drawn to particular crimes, some to the victims themselves. This doesn’t mean they have more of a claim on writing about them at length. Anderson desperately wants to be on the inside of this investigation and clearly deeply identifies with Elisa, but the narrative he’s trying to weave here falls short because, in part, he’s outside of it.To make up for the lack of facts he has to present the audience, Anderson seems to wander off on several tangents that have little to do with his chosen subject. Other infamous crimes are recounted to spice up a chapter or two. He fixates on elements like drones and tracking dogs which the police did not use in this case. He gives credence to the idea that there was some kind of paranormal intervention...i.e. ghosts. It makes him all the more difficult to take seriously. He also has a petty disdain for the police and investigators in this case, seemingly put-off because they wouldn’t give him, a total stranger, access to sensitive information about a woman’s death.I just didn’t care for this book. I wouldn’t say it’s malicious in its intent, just there’s an exploitative quality I can’t quite ignore. Anderson talks a lot about his own mental health, especially whilst reading Lam’s social media posts where she references her own. Perhaps he could have used a similar platform to compare his own struggles with hers instead of trying to commodify it.*Thanks to Kensington Books & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more
