author: Bardugo, Leigh*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really struggled to get into this initially. I don’t know if it was something with pacing or I just didn’t take to the characters quickly enough, buI really struggled to get into this initially. I don’t know if it was something with pacing or I just didn’t take to the characters quickly enough, but I just couldn’t get myself to go back to it once I’d put it down. I think the time jumps really worked against the story. I know Leigh Bardugo likes to write this way, but I don’t know what narrative purpose it had beyond withholding for the sake of...being withholding. Some of the big revelations were glossed over so offhandedly that I had to go back and re-read passages in order to catch up with where the characters were. I’m totally onboard with the entire premise and most of the plot now, but I don’t blame people who got frustrated early on and gave up on it.The other problem I had is probably going to show my biases, but...I found it hard to care about people at an elite institution within another elite institution. I understand Alex, and even Dawes and Darlington to a point, isn’t like the other entitled members and is an ‘outsider’, but the Chosen-One force propelled her to higher society whether she wanted it to or not, (view spoiler)[and the poor, disposable girls died in the end with the nobility still going largely unpunished (hide spoiler)]. I just find it hard to empathize with organizations that have built their entire foundation on being exclusionary. Rich people fucking around with regular peoples’ lives for entertainment is going to be a tougher sell going forward in 2019 and beyond.But like I said earlier, I’m sold on the Alex Stern series and will take all the Bardugo I can get....more

title: American Dirt
author: Cummins, Jeanine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think I’ve typed and deleted the intro to this  approximately a hundred times, so I’ll just skip the preamble I was hoping would materialize. I think I’ve typed and deleted the intro to this  approximately a hundred times, so I’ll just skip the preamble I was hoping would materialize. I’ll even put the verdict up at the top here so you can get on to reading the dozens of other s for the Controversial Book of the Year®: It’s fine, but not worth the hype. It didn’t live up to the exaltation initially received or the condemnation that came later. It’s not even worth the hate-read. I struggle to understand the strong emotional response to the actual work itself, both positive and negative. I mean, the main characters, Lydia and Luca, were so grating that I had to really dig deep and power through the first third where the story was focused primarily on them. Luca is an 8-year-old human atlas and prodigy. He speaks perfect English, has memorized the entire North American continent to where he can direct traffic better than GoogleMaps and talks to his mother like he has a whole team of TV writers feeding him dialogue. This kid would have been an unrealistic adult, but as a young child dealing with trauma it’s just obnoxious.Lydia is just so clearly written for suburban books clubs that it’s almost kind of an insulting assumption by Jeannine Cummins to so obviously pander to her audience like this. She’s an upper-middle class indie bookstore owner who read Tolstoy to her baby and has such an irresistible personality that the local cartel boss fell in love with her (more on that later). If Liam Neeson in Taken is an action fantasy for suburban men that just ‘need to protect their family’, then Lydia is the female version of that—an unrealistic audience surrogate thrust into a situation that’s rooted in some reality, but is not to be taken as a representation of that reality.And that’s where this book initially started to receive backlash, with how it was marketed. American Dirt shouldn’t be treated like literary fiction or as a ‘true immigrant experience’, because it’s not. It’s not the next The Grapes of Wrath. Personally, I don’t think it deserved the huge advance that Cummins was given, but publishers can spend their money however they want. What I think a lot of the people who are defending this book, the backlash to the backlash if you will, are missing is that the original marketing for it was grossly inadequate and took space in an already tight industry from better representations of the current South/Central American migrant experience. That’s without mentioning how Cummins and Flatiron misrepresented her own background or the huge missteps like those barbed-wire centerpieces.The frustration with the publishing industry was warranted, and there’s probably still more to come. But it’s not really about American Dirt itself, at least not entirely. This book is clearly written for white ladies who Cummins wanted to entertain first and foremost, and possibly ‘enlighten’. She wanted us to have that Oprah A-Ha moment (and she got it!), but it didn’t end up being what she expected. And on a more personal point, I kind of resent the way a character I’m supposed to relate to (as a white lady) was shoehorned into this real crisis. The part that saved this book from being a DNF for me was the two teenage girls from Central America, Soledad and Rebeca, who Lydia and Luca meet along the way. I don’t need a character to have the same interests and socioeconomic background as me in order to empathize with them. The story of the two girls was so much more engaging and I found myself caring about them far more than who we were meant to be following. It feels like the author broke a huge writing rule here: don’t underestimate your reader.Also, the cartel was a joke. You will honestly find a better depiction of Mexican drug smugglers and gangs in Narcos: Mexico on Netflix. The local cartel leader was the same type of literary snob as Lydia and their interactions were laughable. Their weird pseudo-romance was like a bad Hallmark movie but with references to beheadings, plus the message was pretty messed up. Just for the record, do not refer to a brutal mass-murderer as, “This tortured poetic soul, full of remorse. He’s funny. He’s kind. Maybe things could still be different.” Ugh, gross.This  is already stupid long, and I didn’t even get to half the stuff I could have, but you get the idea. Not everything is awful, the brief acknowledgement of Indigenous people fleeing and the dangers of women traveling showed Cummins did some research for this novel. But I just don’t know that there is an amount of research that she could do to make up for her lack of firsthand experiences; if there is, she did not make a strong case for it. The whole thing just felt like it was trying too hard. I didn’t hate it, but I wouldn’t recommend it. I can’t really even pan it with a low rating, because it just didn’t leave a strong enough impression either way. It’s got a pretty face cover, but not much substance underneath....more

title: The Better Liar
author: Jones, Tanen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There’s nothing worse than a boring thriller. Luckily, Tanen Jones’ The Better Liar isn’t one of those books. There’s something about the two main chaThere’s nothing worse than a boring thriller. Luckily, Tanen Jones’ The Better Liar isn’t one of those books. There’s something about the two main characters, Leslie and Mary, that hold your attention with a vice grip. I couldn’t read anything else until I finished this one.Apart from the literal first and last chapter, not much actually ‘happens’, per say. Leslie finds her sister dead, befriends a local woman in Las Vegas and they both go back to her hometown in New Mexico. But from the first interaction you can tell something just feels “off”. There’s so much that’s just desperately waiting to be revealed. I love stories where everyone might be lying and you can’t take anything at face value. In this way, I agree with the comparisons to Gillian Flynn, Megan Abbott and Paula Hawkins; these women could easily be some of their characters.There’s plenty of twists, with a ‘big one’ near the end. The ending even gives you a final thrust of the knife, so to speak. I was totally engrossed with this book and loved speculating about the tilted lives of the people who inhabited it. I’m definitely going to be looking for more from Ms. Jones going forward. Also—anyone who’s interested should check out the Author’s Note at the end. It helped put a lot into perspective and really mirrored some of my own feelings and fears. But it could technically be considered a spoiler, so save it for after you’ve finished!*Thanks to Random House - Ballantine & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Legend        (Legend, #1)
author: Lu, Marie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: File this one under Incredibly Popular YA Series That I Somehow Did Not Get The Memo On. It even came out during my last year of high school. Ugh, 17-File this one under Incredibly Popular YA Series That I Somehow Did Not Get The Memo On. It even came out during my last year of high school. Ugh, 17-year-old me, what were you DOING?! Honestly, probably transitioning from The Hunger Games to Divergent movie adaptations, which puts the Legend series right up my [former] alley. I’ve been nervous to go back and read some of the YA books of my, ahem, youth for this very reason. I don’t know if my 26-year-old, very *~cultured~* brain will be able to appreciate them in the same way my angsty teenaged one did. Truthfully, this book kind of confirmed this fear has some merit. It has some of the tropiest tropes in the genre and I found myself rolling my eyes quite a bit. That said, they weren’t the peeved eye-rolls I might give a book that was obnoxious or played too much into stereotypes. It was just predictable and a little sappy.There’s all the YA fan favorites: dystopian future with evil government overlords, teenagers of immense and inexplicable skill fighting the power, the same mega-adept teenagers falling into a meekly passionate romance. On that last point, I was amazed at just the amount of blushing and brushing against one another and oh my god the stolen, longing gazes they threw at each other. Was Twilight like this? Twilight was like this, wasn’t it. Damn it.And I get it, they’re all super-geniuses with military special forces tactical training and the thieving abilities stolen from an Ocean’s Eleven remake, but I’m sorry, YOU CAN NOT LOOK AT SOMEONE AND KNOW THEY ARE NEARSIGHTED. Or whatever other weird thing the protagonists ‘just noticed’. That’s dumb and wrong. The obsession with the idea of ‘innocence’ and compliments like “perfectly symmetrical, a mix of Anglo and Asian” are strange and fetishy, but damn if this wasn’t incredibly easy to read. I just flew through it. If you’re looking for a fast fix of the Young Adult persuasion, this is your guy!It’s obviously not the worst offender of the bunch and I enjoyed reading it overall. Am I going to pick up the next one? Eh, probably not, but it’s fun and will likely be the perfect fit for the age group it’s targeted for....more

title: The Institute
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can’t say I have much of an acquaintance with Stephen King’s backlog, only having read a few of his short stories. Despite that, it’s nearly impossiI can’t say I have much of an acquaintance with Stephen King’s backlog, only having read a few of his short stories. Despite that, it’s nearly impossible to move through the world without being aware of his work. He’s permeated our population with his writings at an unmatched level of cultural relevance. So while this is my first full-length novel of his, it’s hardly my first experience with the twisted imaginings that dwell in his head.King was recently on some late night show promoting his book, and told the host the plot was inspired by the children imprisoned at the USA-Mexico border who had been taken from their parents. Maybe some people prefer their entertainment to be separate from politics, but I’d argue those people have a poor understanding of both literature and politics. There is no divorcing one from the other. Not when one person’s ‘job’ involves the complete devastation of another person’s way of life. Writing and reading can be escapism, yes, but it’s never really just that. Fiction helps us process harsh realities through someone else’s narration, even though we may not be aware of it at the time.And not everyone has the luxury to pretend that there are not people suffering. That was the most unnerving part of the children’s imprisonment in The Institute. The adults in charge—caretakers, administrators, even doctors—are completely unbothered by the abuse inflicted on their charges. They lie and gaslight, making these scared kids doubt their own sanity. There’s so much cognitive dissonance and straight-up delusion, that they’ve convinced themselves that the kidnapping, torture & worse they inflict on children daily isn’t just necessary, but a good thing. This attitude isn’t an invention by King, it’s relied upon by the real-life, human monsters that skulk near positions of power. Add in those complicit in enabling them and you have what we in the business like to call, an administration.It’s a scary book. Though more horror in the front half and thriller in the back, the story is fast-paced and engrossing. Some of the ways the kids talk to each other seemed a bit off, and for the love of GOD, Stephen, why do you describe preteen girls this way: ”the girls in skirts and leggings, their bosoms just beginning to bloom,”But after a little bit of a slow start, I was totally hooked and the 550+ pages just flew by. He’s lauded for a reason, and even at 72, doesn’t show any signs of slowing down. Lucky us....more

title: Chase Darkness with Me: How One True-Crime Writer Started Solving Murders
author: Jensen, Billy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'll Be Gone in the Dark: One Woman's Obsessive Search for the Golden State Killer is the book that got me back into reading last summer. That, in conI'll Be Gone in the Dark: One Woman's Obsessive Search for the Golden State Killer is the book that got me back into reading last summer. That, in conjunction with Gillian Flynn’s Sharp Objects adaptation on HBO, pushed me from true crime and thrillers back into the book world that I relentlessly follow today. Billy Jensen, along with Patton Oswalt and Paul Haynes, were the crucial force that put this book in my hands, and I am perpetually grateful to them for that.A lot of this book is stop and start, and that’s by design. Jensen depicts the moment to moment frustration when after finding a case and throwing out a line, you’re left simply waiting and hoping that someone takes a bite. There’s so many cases discussed that I don’t know how he keeps them all straight. But he does because he feels an intense connection to not just the victims, but their loved ones—the people who have been left behind.In this way he mirrors Michelle McNamara quite a bit. There’s an outpouring of empathy they both exhibit in their fervor to uncover answers, and in the outrage they feel at the overall situation that has to go mostly unexpressed. As a reader, you feel it too. It’s not fair. And that’s just not something you can say without sounding petulant and hearing an irritating voice from your childhood smugly retorting, “Well life’s not fair. Deal with it.” This is Michelle and Billy’s righteous calling: to try and tip the scales. You shouldn’t get to destroy someone’s life and keep on living yours free of consequence. So we follow people like McNamara and Jensen and hope that by dragging some of these cases into the light, that the world will be a little more livable. Maybe with another perpetrator behind bars, even if we haven’t heard of them or their crimes, something in the air will shift and we’ll feel that small bit of justice reach us wherever we are. I still feel like the world was robbed of Michelle McNamara’s voice. She had an unfairly short life. Her family and friends got an unfairly short time with her. And the people that didn’t know her, but now have her work sitting on their shelves, got only a glimpse at who she was and what she was capable of. And it doesn’t feel like enough. Even though in a lot of ways it was. The Golden State Killer was caught, in the manner she predicted. Her limited writings on the subject were sufficient enough to become a national bestseller. And we get people like Billy Jensen, carrying on in the way she would have. His book is part tribute to her and their friendship and part pursuing his own investigations. I loved following along with him. I loved seeing their shared passions and the work put in behind the scenes on her behalf. It’s not fair that this is all we have, but it’s just going to have to be enough....more

title: This Tender Land
author: Krueger, William Kent*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Take your time with this one. Like the meandering Gilead River, it’s best to travel at your own pace and fully appreciate the atmosphere around you. STake your time with this one. Like the meandering Gilead River, it’s best to travel at your own pace and fully appreciate the atmosphere around you. Set in Depression-era Minnesota, two brothers, a mute native boy and a young girl escape from The Lincoln Indian Training School, a miserable institution intent on, among other things, smothering indigenous ways of life. The story takes on a The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn vibe as the crew travels in a canoe and bears witness to the harsh realities of the country while trying to figure out their places in it.For American high school classrooms, this might be a better alternative to The Grapes of Wrath. That’s not saying that Krueger is a better writer than John Steinbeck or This Tender Land is a better book, but it is more likely to appeal to students. The main characters are a group of kids that embark on their own; it reads like an adventure story. There’s also a more nuanced look at topics that had only been narrowly explored previously. We witness firsthand an array of injustices thrust upon marginalized populations through the eyes of the characters. Religion isn’t presented simply as imagery and blind faith, but scrutinized by teenagers and children through the lenses of their own experiences. We see it utilized by both good and bad actors. Plus, teachers won’t have to ignore the plagiarism rumblings associated with Steinbeck’s famous novel. Though categorized as historical fiction, there’s a miraculous element running through the novel until it comes to a crescendo near the end. William Kent Krueger is revelatory and desperately hopeful in this depiction of one of the most challenging periods in American history....more

title: The Light at the Bottom of the World        (Light the Abyss, #1)
author: Shah, London*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Kind of surprised this one seems to have flown under the radar. As far as YA fantasy goes, it’s one of the better ones I’ve read this year. The characKind of surprised this one seems to have flown under the radar. As far as YA fantasy goes, it’s one of the better ones I’ve read this year. The characters aren’t that revelatory, but the setting is absolutely exceptional. When I read that it took place in completely underwater version of London, I assumed the inhabitants were all going to be mermaids. Or something similar at least, but nope! In this post-apocalyptic future the surviving civilization lives in airtight dwellings and travels in personal submarines among the other creatures that inhabit the ocean. The author is a little vague on what exactly caused this calamity and how the people pulled off this great underwater escape, but the events of the novel happen about 70 years after it happened, so it’s not entirely relevant to the main plot. And speaking of that...The first third felt like a cross between The Hunger Games and podracing in Star Wars, but then takes a turn towards something more like an undersea adventure. Our main character, Leyla, is your classic YA heroine, for better or worse. She even gets to yell “I can take care of myself!” at various authority figures in her life before eventually realizing that she, in fact, cannot take care of herself at all. Her hunky, brooding ‘protector’ who’s perpetually clenching his jaw fulfills the love interest role in the YA way of starting as a mortal enemy before embracing one another as lovers in less than a day. My biggest issue, though? The freaking dog. Shut up about the dog. Nobody cares about the dog. I don’t know why book-dogs annoy me so much, but I never enjoy reading anything with them, and this one is mentioned on nearly every page. Also Jojo is a dumb dog name. The tropes are redundant, and the symbolism is a little heavy-handed, but I was able to read through it without wanting to go back in time and murder a teenaged version of myself, so I consider that a win. In all seriousness, it’s a solid start to an apparent series set to pick up some time again in 2020. I’ll be looking out for it along with whatever London Shah puts out next!*Thanks to Disney-Hyperion & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Underground Railroad
author: Whitehead, Colson*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think I’ll have to take a break from slavery and abuse plots after this. The Nickel Boys, The Testaments, The Water Dancer...it’s a lot of brutalityI think I’ll have to take a break from slavery and abuse plots after this. The Nickel Boys, The Testaments, The Water Dancer...it’s a lot of brutality, no matter how necessary they may be to explore. This is the second Colson Whitehead novel I’ve read, and besides the historical context they both explored, a running theme seems to be resilience. Being a survivor, weathering hardships and loss, it’s what their respective main characters endure that shapes the people they become. But I just wish there was something else for Cora to have pursued, with the goal of not just surviving but living. I found more of that with The Nickel Boys than in The Underground Railroad. Some of the cruelties feel like they came straight from the Madame LaLaurie playbook of human torture. Slavery was the true American Horror Story and it’s important not to ignore those realities, but for anyone who may need the trigger warning: here it is.The railroad element was really clever, and I can’t believe nobody’s run with that before. The timeline took some getting used to, and I wish the chapters were divided a little more succinctly. This won a lot of awards when it came out, and Whitehead deserves all the acclaim he received. Just the overall bleakness made it seem so much longer than the relatively short 300ish pages it actually was. I’m glad I read it, but I probably won’t be revisiting it again....more

title: The Starless Sea
author: Morgenstern, Erin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After a debut as atmospheric and alluring as The Night Circus, I wasn’t sure how Erin Morgenstern would fare with her inevitable follow-up. Now, eightAfter a debut as atmospheric and alluring as The Night Circus, I wasn’t sure how Erin Morgenstern would fare with her inevitable follow-up. Now, eight years later, we have been given a story crafted so carefully and lovingly that I feel silly for having any doubts in the first place. If you come into this with any remaining concern that she may be unable to capture the same magic of her last book once again, let it be cast aside now.In a comment to promote her book on Goodreads, she said:“I write places. There are spaces that live in my head long before I find the characters and the stories that live in those spaces and figure out how best to tell them.”This was evident in her last book as much as this one. Nobody rivals Morgenstern in her lush setting descriptions. Every room we step into, every article of clothing put on, the smell in the air, the color of the sky—it’s all there, dripping with detail and waiting to be soaked up greedily. The story-within-a-story style that The Starless Sea takes on lends itself to even more opportunities to transport her readers to times and places we’ve never been before. In this way, this book is truly stunning.The beginning of each ‘chapter’ is a new story, seemingly unrelated to the overall plot-line running through the book. After several of these, I did feel a bit lost. It was like there was always one thread too many for me to keep track of, but that could have been intentional. It feels overly convoluted before everything starts to come together in the end. This is probably a book that will reveal something new on each re-readMaybe this is more a complaint with my ebook, but I found the ‘Book [I-VI]’ style of breaking up the text much more difficult to navigate than traditional chapters. The Night Circus had several jumps to different time periods and places, and even when Morgenstern was being purposefully opaque, they were clearly defined. I could go back to each of those subsections on my Kindle and reference the titles of them or the date given, but there was no such luck with The Starless Sea. With all of the interlocking plot points and metaphorical and clever story titles & subjects, I think this was a misstep in the overall structure. Perhaps the print version is better in this regard.I love reading books by this author, and I hope we don’t have to wait another eight years for a third one. Although, any amount of time could pass and I’d still be eagerly waiting whenever she decided to release it....more

title: The Majesties
author: Tsao, Tiffany
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There has been a massacre. In the first sentence of the first chapter, the narrator, Gwendolyn, reveals that her sister Estella murdered three hundredThere has been a massacre. In the first sentence of the first chapter, the narrator, Gwendolyn, reveals that her sister Estella murdered three hundred people. They’re members of her family, extended family and friends, poisoned for no discernible reason. This is where the story starts, but also where it ends. It would be wrong to classify this as a thriller or suspense in the traditional sense. If you’re looking for heightened happenings similar to the initial bombshell to be peppered throughout the rest of the novel, you may be disappointed. The majority of the book, basically every chapter between the first one and the last couple, is more an examination of one family’s discord spanning several years and generations. There’s so many layers present, from the inherited wealth, to racial frictions, to domestic abuse and even geopolitical ramifications. The description of this book compares itself to Crazy Rich Asians; this is true only in the most superficial way. The characters are crazy rich, from a wealthy Chinese-Indonesian family. There’s complicated familial dynamics and pressure to live up to the standards that have been cultivated decade to decade, grandparent to parent to child. Where the Crazy Rich Asians trilogy was criticized for not much acknowledging the realities of the majority population living outside of their enormous wealth, The Majesties brings a refreshing, sometimes dark level of self-awareness to the class struggles in Southeastern Asia, specifically Indonesia and the capital city of Jakarta. Though the story detours to parts of southern California & elsewhere, it’s focal point continues to be the family rooted in Jakarta.The unraveling of Gwendolyn and her sister’s family is crucial to understanding why Estella did what she did. The entire plot centers around that question: Why? What could have possibly possessed her to kill everyone in that room? It’s not a mystery in the way we’re accustomed to; the answers to the questions we’d normal be asking, ‘Who?’ ‘What?’ ‘How?’, are already known. There’s several big revelations at the end, twists and turns and bleak truths that leave the reader shell shocked. As the first 2020 release I’ve delved into, this was quite a memorable and haunting way to start. *Thanks to Atria Books & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Dutch House
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is my first Ann Patchett novel, and it’s probably not going to be a common starting point in her body of work, but I’m definitely a fan of her’s This is my first Ann Patchett novel, and it’s probably not going to be a common starting point in her body of work, but I’m definitely a fan of her’s after completing it.I don’t know if I could describe the plot to someone if they asked, so there’s not much of risk of spoilers here even if I wanted to give them. Patchett puts as much care and color into her characters as an artist puts into each brushstroke of a painting. If you told me she also created the portrait of Maeve on the cover, I would believe you.There’s no great twists or action-packed plot, just wonderful writing about complicated family dynamics. So many times I was filled with anger or resentment that mirrored a character’s, and sometimes surpassing it. Only to, by the end of it all, have it evaporate away and leave me wondering why I felt so much. To those with your own familial tensions: expect to be confronted with them as well.It’s not a sad book; it’s sad the way life is. Or beautiful the way life is. Or unfair the way life is. I really didn’t mean to write such a melancholic , but I guess this is where I ended up. But in case there’s any confusion, I recommend picking up The Dutch House.*Thanks to HarperCollins & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Whisper Man
author: North, Alex*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Alex North delivers a solidly creepy story in this debut thriller. The cover gave me major The Silence of the Lambs vibes, and I was glad to see the bAlex North delivers a solidly creepy story in this debut thriller. The cover gave me major The Silence of the Lambs vibes, and I was glad to see the butterflies weren’t just confined to imagery, but were incorporated in the plot as well. While not quite at the level of The Silent Patient, The Whisper Man is one of the better books among the genre this year.Set in a small British town, you have to know there are going to be plenty of connections among the characters. A couple are predictable, but most took me by surprise. Not necessarily because they’re so out of left field, but because I think I expected everyone to secretly be a murderer hiding in plain sight. Sure, most people have their secrets, but those secrets all aren’t usually actual skeletons in their closets. The perspectives shift from Tom, in first person, and a handful of other characters in third person. It’s interesting, if a little confusing at first, but ultimately doesn’t take away from anything that’s happening.On to the spoiler-y part: (view spoiler)[I loved the look at relationships between fathers and sons. So many had such similar internal dialogues that seem to echo what we hear of ‘troubled’ young men now. There’s a real look at coping with past traumas and how different people respond to it. The disconnect between these boys & men and their peers or families can distort their perceptions of reality and fantasy. There’s so many “lost boys” present in this book that I don’t think I could name them all on the first go. The crimes being portrayed are horrible, but they’re also immensely sad. It brings up an interesting debate of nature vs nurture. Did Francis do what he did because of a genetic predisposition or because of what he was exposed to at the hands of his father as a child? Were his actions inevitable either way? Basically, does what he witnessed make him who he is, or was he that person all along?The part that bugged me, however, was Rebecca. What was even going on with her? North made it seem, at least to me, like Tom murdered her and left her body for his son to find, up until the end. Her death wasn’t really ever elaborated on besides that she was...near stairs? What? I just don’t know why there wasn’t more clear-cut information given on a woman’s death who ended up being little more and a narrative devise. (hide spoiler)]It’s a good book, overall. It feels eerie and precarious and I flew through reading it. If you pick it up, you’ll be compelled to finish it to the end....more

title: Watchmen
author: Moore, Alan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is an interesting time in entertainment, world politics & media discourse to pick up Watchmen for the first time. Since originally published in 1This is an interesting time in entertainment, world politics & media discourse to pick up Watchmen for the first time. Since originally published in 1986-1987, Alan Moore’s work has continued to influence both popular culture and counter-culture in seemingly contradictory ways. The cult status of Watchmen has persisted for a reason, if not many, and I’m glad I finally got to experience it in its entirety. It’s kind of uncanny how many of the same elements that are at play during the events of Watchmen in 1985 are still relevant today. Tensions with Russia and conflict in the Middle East, radicalized right-wing extremists, fears of government conspiracy, looming climate change, corrupted politicians, etc—so much feels like it could have been written within the past couple of years. And with the total domination of super hero movie franchises, a la the MCU as well as others, the corporate cashing in on masked ‘avengers’ seems to resonate now more than ever. But since this was a “genre-changer”, some of the novel aspects are somewhat lost on those jumping in now for the first time. The dark grittiness and moral ambiguity are stark in comparison to traditional Superman-style heroes, but in a post-Dark Knight landscape and especially with more recent releases like The Boys on Amazon, these aren’t exactly fresh takes anymore. And maybe with the benefit (or curse) of hindsight I’m more able to critically look at those aspects overlooked at the time, than if I had picked it up 30 years ago.One of the parts I enjoyed the least was the culture surrounding the comics. There’s a lot of aggression, hyper-masculinity, political extremism and graphic violence present in the book(s). This in and of itself isn’t a big deal, especially since the author himself makes it quite clear that these are negative qualities, both in and out of the story. For this reason the people who identify with characters and themes in Watchmen seem like those least likely to do so, in some ways. As a satire of violence, Moore is criticizing not only characters like Rorschach, Dr. Manhattan, The Comedian and Ozymandias, but their entire way of thinking. But in the way that young men identified with Tyler Durden in Fight Club, another parody of toxic masculinity, some have misinterpreted Watchmen in the same way. There may not be a ‘good guy’, but there’s definitely bad guys.As is typical with many works from this era, representation leaves a lot to be desired. Basically all white, and the only female characters have been relegated to the roles of Discarded Older Woman, Girl Who Cries But Still Fucks, and Victim/Potential Victim.(view spoiler)[The decision to have Sally Jupiter, a victim of sexual assault, not only take up a relationship with her almost-rapist after the fact, but eventually forgive and fall in love with him, could be interesting in context with other characters who are deeply flawed. But if a portion of the intended audience reading sympathizes or worse, finds no fault in, characters like Rorschach or The Comedian, then this plot line is essentially a rape apology that excuses their actions or complicity. Complicated feelings towards an abuser isn’t uncommon, and the fact that a peer of hers was taking advantage of their pre-established relationship to attack her should make the betrayal all the worse. BUT the misinterpretation by so many of these characters and ideas makes it hard to appreciate this storyline as anything but icky. (hide spoiler)]Unfortunately, the same demographic that I described earlier probably won’t care about these things, and I’m just preaching to those who already agree.I think separate from the fandom, and in proper historical context, it’s still 5 stars for me. But when I see Red Pillers and Alt-Right forums that salivate over some of the characters and adopt their personal philosophies as their own, it makes me wonder what it means that I like it too....more

title: The Witches Are Coming
author: West, Lindy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “This is a witch hunt. We’re witches, and we’re hunting you.”God, I missed Lindy West. I mean, she didn’t go anywhere and I read Shrill only two month“This is a witch hunt. We’re witches, and we’re hunting you.”God, I missed Lindy West. I mean, she didn’t go anywhere and I read Shrill only two months ago and I still haven’t seen the show and she’s written pieces for a dozen or so other media outlets, but I still miiiiiiissed her!While Shrill: Notes from a Loud Woman was a lot of West’s own personal life, growth and realizations, The Witches Are Coming examines societal shifts more holistically and offers a ruthlessly necessary cultural critique. If her previous book was in part a crash course on the history of the internet up through the first half of 2016, we’re now taken on a trip through many generation-defining events that have taken place over the past three and a half years. The election of Donald Trump, Brexit, the #MeToo movement—these all have happened in the relatively short but also inexplicably long period since. In addressing not only these happenings, but the inevitable backlash to the backlash, Lindy West provides a thoughtful and well-reasoned examination of subjects that still are too discomfiting to bring up in some ‘polite company’. And she does it all with the same level of cutting humor that you’d come to expect from her work.And, guys, it’s really really funny. I was cracking up over even the chapter titles. Come on, Ted Bundy Was Not Charming—Are You High? That’s fucking classic; I want it embroidered on a pillow or something. And she replicates one of my favorite parts of her last book, which was the reflective look at one the idols of her youth, Howard Stern. But instead of Stern this time, she devotes entire chapters to examining the legacies of comedy legends such as Adam Sandler and Joan Rivers. Even some of the chapter titles, like Is Adam Sandler Funny?, would be enough provocation to set off a pack of furious fanboys to defend his honor, but I beg you all to take the time to read what she’s written. These aren’t hit pieces; the conclusions she reaches are nuanced and even the criticisms aren’t really levied at the performer personally, but at the society that shaped as well as consumed them.Even those who weren’t #blessed with their own chapter received credit where it was due. Ricky Gervais and Louis C.K.’s contributions to comedy aren’t merely tossed aside by a changing world, but they also aren’t immune to being challenged by it. One of the funniest chapters features Gwyneth Paltrow in all her Goopiness and it’s not mocking or glowing in the way we’ve come to expect towards her, but instead is refreshingly giddy and candid. West balances comic whimsy and difficult truths with the same level of deftness as Mary Poppins, disguising the bitterness of medicine with a spoonful of sugar. It really does make it all easier to swallow.Most chapters feature a story from West’s own life, either a hilarious anecdote or a moment of frustration, that is used as a segue into a topic of importance for her. A few are really Trojan Horses that don’t reveal their true nature until further into the piece, but some are upfront about the content for good reason. In What Is an Abortion, Anyway? she discusses not just her own real abortion, but her fictional one as well. Her insistence to include Shrill’s main character, Annie’s, abortion in the pilot was the same determination that birthed the #ShoutYourAbortion movement online. While not as satirical as the other essays, it’s just as sharp and truly beneficial to anyone who considers themselves pro-choice.Real talk, I was so giggly while reading this. My Kindle copy is so full of highlighted passages that if I had done the same thing to a physical copy it would be like 65% highlighter. Her self-awareness makes her so endearing and her biting wit is funny as hell—I just thoroughly enjoyed every bit of this book. The end left me optimistic and with a sense of pending accomplishment, which, yeah, is probably unearned at this stage, but with a clear path forward. I don’t know what else to say; Lindy West left me feeling happy and gave me some hope.*Thanks to Hachette Books & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Last Wish        (The Witcher, #0.5)
author: Sapkowski, Andrzej
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Adaption? You say? I’m on my way.Seriously, I’m not sure if I was even planning on watching the announced Netflix series before I found out it was basAdaption? You say? I’m on my way.Seriously, I’m not sure if I was even planning on watching the announced Netflix series before I found out it was based on a book series...and yet, here I am. Just a total slut for any book that has even a whisper of a potential movie or tv show adaptation. And the fact that they got Henry Cavill, aka literal Superman, playing the title character who hunts monsters and demons to star in a horror-leaning interpretation of the story just makes the whole thing even more enticing.I had a tough time figuring out where to start, though. Andrzej Sapkowski really had to make the ordering more confusing than Doctor Who & The Chronicles of Narnia...but I was able to check the recommended reading on the Witcher subreddit, so for anyone who’s also a little lost:1. The Last Wish (short stories)2. Sword of Destiny (short stories)3. Blood of Elves4. The Time of Contempt5. Baptism of Fire6. The Tower of the Swallow7. Lady of the LakeAnd then there’s Season of Storms which I guess is its own thing, technically is after The Last Wish, but should be read last. Or so they say.This was a short story collection, so it was a different way to introduce a character and fantasy world than I typically see. You do get a feel for Geralt as a person over the course of them, and I’m assuming some of the characters touched on will pop up again. Each story is almost like a mini quest that Geralt has undertaken and typically features a new monster, location and errand for him to complete. They’re framed by another story we’re fed piecemeal, chapter by chapter, in between the other tales. It’s an interesting way to relate a character backstory, but it did feel disjointed and made it hard at times to get truly invested.The stories are based on or inspired by other fairytales and folklore, albeit with a grim twist. Some are more easily recognizable, like Snow White or Beauty and the Beast, while others I had to look up, like Hans my Hedgehog, but they all divert majorly from the originals, so there’s not much of a spoiler there. I found Sapkowski really clever in crafting these takes on classic fables, and they fit exceedingly well in the darkly magical world he created for the Witcher to prowl.The rest of my complaints are the same ones that unfortunately come up in a lot of fantasy written by men. The women need some work. Either they’re unattractive, therefore barely worth mentioning, a sorceress who’s only personality is being super hot or, strangely enough, there’s a multiplicity of young women & girls who are straight-up monsters. They’re still ‘innocent’ but simultaneously ‘ruined’ and completely interchangeable. Plus there’s a good number of teenaged girls having their clothes ripped off, and this is apparently totally fine. Of all the stories in this collection, The Last Wish has the cringiest descriptions of female characters by far. I actually disliked that one so much I almost ended up taking an entire star off this , but for now I’ll leave it at four. I just dread going forward if Geralt is going to fulfill some kind of male fantasy role and every woman he encounters will be throwing themselves at him. From what I’ve read the games are even worse in this regard...but that’s not really the standard I want to judge books by, ‘Well at least it’s not as misogynistic as the video game!’Also, fight scenes are boring to read. All this to say yes, I probably will be reading the next installment in the series....more

There’s a reason this book is so immensely popular. I can’t compare it to other Pratchett and Gaiman books because I haven’t read any (oops), but I thoroughly enjoyed this offering from the two of them.I got a similar feeling while reading The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy as with this, albeit there were fewer jokes. That might have something to do with the nihilism of Douglas Adams’ series; you can’t really have the same attitude of ‘nothing matters in the end’ if your entire premise is that there’s definitely an afterlife and every choice you make does matter.I was watching the Amazon series after finishing sections of the book, and I liked it on the whole. The CGI is so laughably bad that I wondered if they did it purposely, but David Tennant and Michael Sheen are perfect as Crowley and Aziraphale, respectively. I believe Neil Gaiman was the show runner, so it’s about as true-to-book as you can get. I’m sure if Mr. Pratchett was still alive (d. 2015), he would have been involved as well. I’m not sure what I should pick up of theirs next, since I liked Good Omens so much. The Color of Magic? That’s Pratchett’s next most popular series [Discworld]. And I guess American Gods for Gaiman, as I’ve done Coraline already. Oh, I guess that means I have read something else of his then. title: The Nickel Boys
author: Whitehead, Colson*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Congrats to this Pulitzer Prize for Fiction winner!(And one of only four who have won twice!)This was so good. My first time reading a Colson WhiteheaCongrats to this Pulitzer Prize for Fiction winner!(And one of only four who have won twice!)This was so good. My first time reading a Colson Whitehead novel has left me completely overwhelmed. I’m going to have to pick up The Underground Railroad next!There’s so much pain present in stories like this. And part of that pain is in the nonfictional elements being played out within fiction. Nickel Academy’s real-life counterpart, the Dozier School for Boys, is all the scarier because it existed not in opposition to our society’s practices and norms, but in alignment with them. It’s easier to put into context something more current, like When They See Us, once you’ve acknowledged some of the horrors in this novel were common place not so long ago.Though fairly compact, around 224 pages, The Nickel Boys isn’t a light read. It almost felt like reading a scary story at times, told by the ghosts of our country’s past. Skeletons in the closet that we still haven’t reckoned with in a meaningful way. All of this is without even touching on the writing and the narrative, which is superb. When you think you know how it’s all going to end, the rug is pulled from under your feet. There’s only compelling reasons to pick up this novel, and I suggest everyone does before the hold list at their library gets too long....more

review: Binti is unlike anything I’ve ever read. I don’t usually gravitate towards a ton of science fiction, but I still feel like this character and story isBinti is unlike anything I’ve ever read. I don’t usually gravitate towards a ton of science fiction, but I still feel like this character and story is something remarkable. It’s gripping and fantastical and intelligent and I just couldn’t stop myself from tearing through it. My only drawback was that it felt kind of unresolved at the end. I feel like so much happened in the first three-quarters that the final stretch just left me hanging. Everything is just chill now?? I need to keep reminding myself it’s a novella so I don’t get frustrated. Also, to anyone wondering: the Khoush are Arab, the Himba are black African & the Edan looks like this. Sourced from the author’s twitter.  [image]My ebook clocked in at under 100 pages, so it’s a good fit for anyone trying to bump their Reading Challenge numbers. But if you need more, like I do, there’s two more installments: Home & The Night Masquerade. Don’t mind me, I’ll just be trying to cyber-bully my library into purchasing the third one because you can’t only have part of a trilogy, right???...more

title: The Girl Who Lived Twice        (Millennium, #6)
author: Lagercrantz, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Aaaaaand we’re back to the long-running game: Are we supposed to like Mikael Blomkvist?Seriously, though, not even a quarter of the way into the most Aaaaaand we’re back to the long-running game: Are we supposed to like Mikael Blomkvist?Seriously, though, not even a quarter of the way into the most recent (and final!) installment of David Lagercrantz’s continuation of Steig Larsson’s Millennium series and he already annoyed the crap out of me. He’s such a self-important twat that I just don’t understand how Lisbeth is the one who’s life is being constantly threatened. And of course at nearly every turn, any single woman (under 45) just hops in bed with him. They just can’t help themselves, you see? This was a complaint in Larsson’s novels as well, and I just kept holding out hope that Lagercrantz would buck that ridiculousness, but they both seems to think arrogant, generic-at-best middle-aged writers are the universal standard of male desirability to women.Though it’s not just Blomkvist or the out-there plot developments that left me feeling lukewarm throughout the book. For me, the characterizations left a lot to be desired, especially for the women. The disclaimer again being that the rest of the series was also plagued with poorly devised female characters, but I read those a long time ago and didn’t note any specifics then. So...oh well!There’s basically just two kinds of women in this book. There’s young women (under 30), who are vapid and stupid, and older women (30+), who are lonely and horny. If they’re too accomplished then don’t fret, because they’ve been given very tragic backstories to explain why she’s, like, such a cold bitch? At one point an accomplished journalist, after being yelled at for no discernible reason by Mikael, gives in to his raw sexual magnetism and stays in bed with him for days. Then, whilst experiencing troubling flashbacks, decides to go outside and just start gardening away the trauma. At HIS HOUSE. Because women do menial chores when they’re sad. Or don’t eat. Or have sex with men and cry. That’s the only way~~~~There’s also the disturbing trend of Mikael, multiple times to multiple women, demanding they tell him about their deeply distressing past experiences. For anyone who may have been pressured to do this at some point, YOU DO NOT OWE ANYONE AN EXPLANATION OF YOUR PERSONAL TRAUMAS. The brazen entitlement to someone else’s tragedies here is just staggering. And in return he grills them further and then refuses to disclose any relevant information he’s withholding. So once again: Are we supposed to like Mikael Blomkvist?Lisbeth is the exception to the women rule because she doesn’t count. Her story is just as wild as it was in the last two novels, so don’t expect anything remotely realistic here. Honestly, it’s all pretty convoluted. But Lisbeth is still interesting, and I had to see her story through to the end. That’s who I’d recommend this book to, anyone who needs finish the series. Cheers, guys, it’s been a ride!...more

title: After the End
author: Mackintosh, Clare*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Devastating and difficult, Clare Mackintosh delivers one gut punch after another in After The End. I did feel a little deflated when I found out this Devastating and difficult, Clare Mackintosh delivers one gut punch after another in After The End. I did feel a little deflated when I found out this wasn’t going to be her typical suspense/thriller, but it ended up being a welcome departure from the usual.Be prepared to take sides. That’s probably the best advice I can give someone going into this novel. And be ready to have your convictions challenged, thrown on the ground and jumped on repeatedly. It’s a book where everyone’s suffering and there’s no real right answers, which is frustrating. The characters waver between rational and emotional responses, and neither feels quite right. Likely because there is nothing right when your child is dying. That said, I wish Mackintosh had made a commitment one way or another. There could have been flashes to “what could have been” throughout without having distinct, parallel paths. But with the two dueling outcomes, it feels like she’s saying these are the only two ways it could have gone. There were so many variables: Dylan could have died en route, his tumor could have slowed down, he could have picked up an infection at any point, could have the surgery but end up worse off, etc. It felt as though the author gave one choice the best possible outcome and the other the worst possible one. (view spoiler)[Plus, she was way too easy on Max. He’s indignant and unsympathetic to everyone around him, especially his wife. Both versions of him, where he won and lost, were off-putting at best and really shitty at worst. And when he started complaining about British healthcare, as an American reading that, I almost threw my Kindle across the room. Bro, people over here are literally crowdsourcing for insulin because our health insurance is so terrible. He’s apparently forgotten what a thousand dollar medical deductible is like or taking an Uber to the hospital over an ambulance and—UGH I’m going to stop myself here. (hide spoiler)]Truthfully, I had to slog a bit through the last third, but I still think on the whole this is a good book worth reading....more

title: The Nobody People        (The Resonant Duology #1)
author: Proehl, Bob*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wish I got into this more. It had so much potential—varied perspectives, X-Men style superheroes, a school for ‘gifted’ children, etc. I was really I wish I got into this more. It had so much potential—varied perspectives, X-Men style superheroes, a school for ‘gifted’ children, etc. I was really expecting to love it, but alas, I ended up reading about 25%, skimming up to 50% and then skipping the rest.I didn’t care for any characters, and that’s beyond just “likeable” or “unlikeable”. They all had one personality trait and that’s basically it. Some, like Fahima, leaned so hard into playing against type that it became a whole new, even worse characterization. She wasn’t funny and blunt; she was an asshole. Avi’s entirely lame personality amounts to journalist, and he doesn’t even seem to be that good at it. And honestly, his (and our) inevitable introduction to the ‘supers’ is one of the worst I’ve ever seen played out. It’s like they each thought of the best way to approach an outsider in this situation...and then intentionally did the exact opposite.The book was also 500 pages long. It felt even longer. I think there were a lot of interesting ideas Bob Proehl was playing with, but he needed to pick a few and put the rest away. Was his editor on vacation? I feel like if you’re going to recycle so much from different sci-fi and comic tropes/plot-lines, then there has to be something revelatory in all of those pages or else just leave 150-200 of them on the cutting room floor.I think I’m being so hard on this book because I expect more from a super-powered ensemble story at this point. He’s a competent writer, and most of the ideas on their own were good. I probably would have had more positives to say if I liked the characters more or it dragged less overall, but it didn’t. It’s not one of the worst books I read this year, but if I had to do it over again, I wouldn’t have picked this one up.*Thanks to Random House - Ballantine & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Pan's Labyrinth: The Labyrinth of the Faun
author: Toro, Guillermo del
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In a dark and harsh world that runs parallel to own own, Guillermo del Toro has devised a brutally beautiful story about good, evil and a young girl wIn a dark and harsh world that runs parallel to own own, Guillermo del Toro has devised a brutally beautiful story about good, evil and a young girl who is brave enough to walk between the two.Having never seen the film, I went into Pan’s Labyrinth completely unfamiliar with the tale of Ofelia, the Faun, Mercedes and the rest of the characters. The book read somewhat like a narration of a movie, but plot is so entrancing that I couldn’t pull myself away. For anyone else who hasn’t seen the 2006 film, it’s a grim fairytale set in post-World War 2 Spain. Under the authoritarian Francisco Franco regime, many rebel groups struggled and failed to defeat the dictator before his death in 1975. I appreciated the historical context, especially the way it was not WW2 historical fiction set in England/France/US. This isn’t a book for kids, despite a child being the main protagonist. In reading up on the movie, I saw it was rated R and was a Spanish-language film. Both surprised me, but I really shouldn’t have been. I enjoyed the book, but what it really made me want to do was go check out the movie immediately. *Thanks to HarperTeen & Goodreads for an advance copy!...more

title: Dear Edward
author: Napolitano, Ann*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Went into this expecting an emotional gut-punch...left somewhat underwhelmed. I’m not even entirely sure what was missing for me, but I just didn’t coWent into this expecting an emotional gut-punch...left somewhat underwhelmed. I’m not even entirely sure what was missing for me, but I just didn’t connect to the story the way I was expecting.If you’ve read any blurb or  about Dear Edward so far, you probably are aware of the premise. A boy survives a plane crash that kills everyone else on board, then deals with the effects after the fact. It’s very sad, and I was expecting a lot of grief, but I didn’t really feel much of that overall. I think where Ann Napolitano succeeded was in the writing of a 12-year-old survivor’s trauma. Edward is a well constructed main character who is convincingly suffering from PTSD and depression, among other things. He feels disconnected from a good portion of the events of the book, which is a realistic depiction of someone going through this type of tragedy.That said, I really think she dropped the ball on the flashbacks. It felt like Napolitano was trying to replicate those types of scenes from Lost where they’d flash into random characters’ lives, but it just did not translate here. I don’t know how to fix it, exactly. Maybe if they were condensed and combined near the end? Or if we had gotten more information about the other passengers in the ‘present day’ story? But as it was just jumps to a half a dozen strangers, who were all stereotypes or caricatures (view spoiler)[  flight attendant is a tease, closeted gay soldier, leering businessman, woman finds out she’s pregnant WHILE on the flight—very soap opera-y(hide spoiler)], that had no relevance to Edward and his family/friends....besides that they should be remembered? I guess? I think without those parts, the narrative would have been stronger.(view spoiler)[I didn’t like Part 3 on the whole, either. The resolution for Edward felt hollow and unfulfilling, despite the story going for something uplifting. I was expecting something impressive or at least thoughtful for him to spend the money on. But buy your teacher a greenhouse because he was sad his plants died? Why not something like a scholarship or grant for the specific wishes of the people who wrote him those letters? You want to be a chef? Okay! Here’s money for culinary school in Betty’s son’s honor. Just seemed like such a waste.And the cockpit flashbacks were so unnecessary. That could have played out a hundred better ways, rather than going over in technical detail why one of the pilots was dumb for killing them all. We could have unraveled what happened slowly in bits and pieces throughout the novel, but instead we get that information dump at the very end. (hide spoiler)]I guess I didn’t know how disappointed I was until now. I appreciate that it wasn’t just tragedy porn, which something like this could easily fall into, but I don’t think the plot or characters carried the weight like those from Celeste Ng or Ann Patchett, which this has been compared to. There wasn’t much of a...story? It was just a tragic circumstance and not much beyond that. Napolitano is a talented writer, though, so I’m not put off from reading more by her going forward.*Thanks to Random House & Netgalley for an advance copy!**For more book talk & s, follow me on Instagram at @elle_mentbooks!...more

title: Fleishman Is in Trouble
author: Brodesser-Akner, Taffy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really like Taffy Brodesder-Ackner's writing. You can tell she spends a lot of time observing people then mulling them over. She's able to capture iI really like Taffy Brodesder-Ackner's writing. You can tell she spends a lot of time observing people then mulling them over. She's able to capture in her characters at very human and honest moments. Hating them is because you see some of yourself reflected back and you don't like to be made to look at it.That said, I don’t think this I was the target audience for this book. I don’t have much to compare marital strife or living in a big city or pressures with kids or almost anything the characters go through to. The protagonist (I guess), Toby Fleishman, is completely and totally insufferable. Hats off to Taffy for writing someone this unlikeable and obliviously self-centered. All of her characters have some flaws, but he seemed to have every single flaw at once. And this is a realistic depiction of a type of person who actually exists. I just found it difficult to care about his life.And that was kind of the crux of it for me. Fleishman Is In Trouble is a wonderfully written composite about a character I don’t want to know more about. A lot of the revelations are crushing and bleak. It really only reenforced my feelings about marriage, which are basically AVOID AT ALL COSTS! Part 3 was a lot easier for me to get through, but it’s only about 80 pages out of 373. I wanted more about Rachel and Libby and the kids and even Seth. The 3rd person perspective kind of reads like a voice over in a movie, which removed me yet another layer from the events occurring. Eventually I finished, and I’m glad I did, but I was fighting my instinct to abandon ship and watch more Netflix.Though, none of this will discourage me from picking up whatever she decides to write next—as long as it’s absent one Toby Fleishman.*Thanks to Random House, Netgalley & Goodreads for advance copies!...more

title: Magic for Liars
author: Gailey, Sarah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This ended up being so much more than what I was expecting. A private school for magic with a murder mystery sounds like a cool idea that can go horriThis ended up being so much more than what I was expecting. A private school for magic with a murder mystery sounds like a cool idea that can go horribly wrong. Luckily, Sarah Gailey was able to pull it off. The other-worldliness is grounded, but still a little rogue. Kind of the way Netflix did super-hero shows like Daredevil and Jessica Jones without feeling silly. There's a grittiness that's tangible and less like a straight-up fantasy, if that helps anyone bridge the gap at all.The mystery/thriller element is equally well done. Even if you're able to guess a portion of the circumstances, you likely won't get them all. There's a lot of subtleties that you aren't sure if are significant or not. Some are more relevant than others, and it makes for a layered story that is hard to put down. Ivy Gamble is exactly what you would want out of a PI: blunt, smart, funny, emotionally unavailable, possible alcoholic. There's a lot to unpack between her and her sister, Tabitha, a teacher at the magical academy, which makes for an interesting dynamic.I really liked this book. Anyone afraid it's going to be reminiscent of a certain magical establishment where wizards shit their pants need not worry. Also appreciated the amount of representation that isn't made a big deal of. I would definitely be interested in more from Ms. Gailey....more

title: Quichotte
author: Rushdie, Salman
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Disclaimer: I haven’t read Don Quixote. Not for any particular reason other than I haven’t gotten around to it, but because of this I’m not going to bDisclaimer: I haven’t read Don Quixote. Not for any particular reason other than I haven’t gotten around to it, but because of this I’m not going to be able to compare themes, characterizations or anything else they may share. I can only look at it as a stand-alone, so apologies if I miss any obvious references or tributes to the original novel.I think the biggest drawback to being unfamiliar with Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra’s masterwork & Salman Rushdie’s writing is that I had no idea where it was going. So much of the story feels meandering and nonsensical before everything finally clicks together. The two parallel character journeys blur the distinction between reality and fantasy that at times I forgot who’s perspective I was currently reading through, which I think was the point. A writer (character) is using a fictional persona to explore his own struggles and insecurities, whilst being in perpetual denial about it. The (actual) author writes about a novelist that’s writing about a former journalist—it’s like a literary Inception. In the end I didn’t know whether Rushdie himself was supposed to be represented through these characters. I still don’t.Rushdie skewers popular culture while also empathizing with those enraptured by it. He’s able to pinpoint exactly the type of man who could believably convince himself that stalking a woman is akin to an Odyssey-like quest. He makes it easy to identify with a protagonist that at first glance you may not have much in common with, but grow to see as a part of yourself—just one that may be uncomfortable to acknowledge. The story is mostly framed as a look at American culture, with an Indian-American focus and a couple detours to the U.K. and India, but I think Quichotte is still accessible to all.I’m not a huge fan of ‘pop culture dumps’ of just listing random references for readers to pat themselves on the back for recognizing, BUT this was probably the best use of it I’ve seen so far. (An example of this that’s, in my opinion, pandering would be Ready Player One.) I would recommend this book if you’re willing to set aside any pre-set rules for reality or how people behave and don’t really mind non-answers. Be ready to get a little lost before finally being led to the (kind of) summit.*Thanks to Random House & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Bone Season        (The Bone Season, #1)
author: Shannon, Samantha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After reading The Priory of the Orange Tree by Samantha Shannon, I was excited to learn she had previously written a fantasy series that I could sink After reading The Priory of the Orange Tree by Samantha Shannon, I was excited to learn she had previously written a fantasy series that I could sink my teeth into. The s warned me it was very different from Priory, but I was still a little surprized to see how much of a departure it was.Not to say the series isn't good, it is! At least I can say the first one is, I haven't gotten to the other two yet. It's a dystopian magical future set in some version of London where King Edward(?) didn't succeed the throne from Queen Victoria and instead was outed as a clairvoyant before fleeing. I'm not super familiar with the British monarchy, but I think I would have heard about that if it had happened. England has been replaced by Scion, the new evil government, and the blend of future sci-fi technology with fantastical elements is really cool.The world building is immense here. Luckily I read the prequel novella The Pale Dreamer prior to this or I think I would have been pretty lost. Unfortunately, we don't see much of London and the Scion before jumping elsewhere quickly. It's hard to really grasp the perils of the world Paige is leaving behind before being thrust somewhere else even more formidable. We don't really get to feel the weight of her emotional connections to those she's left behind, too.But onto the big gripe:(view spoiler)[I have a huge problem with the Paige-Warden romance. He's her slave master. He uses the word slave repeatedly, in fact. It reminds me of those gross romances people try to write about black slaves and their white masters, or between Nazi soldiers and Jewish women. It's not endearing. He's not redeemed because he, like, didn't even hit her much. There's no pardon because he decided to help humans rebel once after 180 years of kidnapping, enslavement, torture and murder. Then once again 20 years later when he thinks one of them is hot. I was just not at all expecting this turn and was totally blindsided. For god's sake, HIS NAME IS WARDEN! Was Overlord taken?? He just keeps gaslighting her and it's beyond infuriating.  (hide spoiler)]That said, it doesn't take away from my overall enjoyment. I'm definitely going to follow up with the The Mime Order as soon as I get a few other books off my TBR....more

title: The Shape of Night
author: Gerritsen, Tess*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This isn’t the thriller I was expecting. Mainly because it’s not a thriller. I guess it’s romantic suspense? I usually don’t go for romance books, so This isn’t the thriller I was expecting. Mainly because it’s not a thriller. I guess it’s romantic suspense? I usually don’t go for romance books, so I don’t know how I missed that in the description. But I wanted to try a Tess Gerritsen stand-alone, especially since I didn’t really care for two of her other immensely popular Rizzoli & Isles books that I read previously. But I think at the end of the day I’m just not the best fit for her work.The main character, Ava, has the most ridiculous LadyJob™ I’ve seen in a while. It’s almost like Halmark movie levels of comical. She’s a cookbook writer that gets huge advances that lets her rent a mansion in Maine indefinitely because...lobster? And her editor is apparently the most understanding person in the publishing industry because she is a YEAR PAST HER DEADLINE and has given him barely anything, but he still drives hours to the house to gal-pal-chat and she actually gets mad at him for asking about the book. Like...come on. It’s a recipe book. Why she needs to ‘find herself’ in a Stephen King book setting and feed lumberjacks stroganoff in order to accomplish her “work” is beyond my comprehension. She’s also super snobby.And truthfully, I’m not even sure this is considered romance. It’s a (view spoiler)[sexual relationship with a ghost (hide spoiler)]. There’s a lot of these “sex scenes” littered through the book and they all made me feel...icky? They didn’t feel totally consensual and didn’t seem to serve any purpose to the plot besides the perceived transgressiveness, so I just started skimming them. The paranormal aspect was one of the interesting pieces of the story, but it never actually pans out. So much build up for literally nothing. Also, apparently everyone in this town is an inept townie and only Ava notices when a bunch of people have disappeared or died in the same geographical location for decades.It wasn’t unreadable, but I didn’t like this much at all. Maybe I’m just the wrong audience. Oh well, it was a quick read, so not the biggest loss of time.*Thanks to Random House - Ballantine & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

Plus, I love when family members just won't let it go. This was a relatively quick read that's definitely worth the effort!*Thanks to Random House & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more
