author: Stevenson, Robin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Every woman should read this. It provides what's severely lacking in the majority of discussions surrounding abortion and women's reproductive rights:Every woman should read this. It provides what's severely lacking in the majority of discussions surrounding abortion and women's reproductive rights: context. There's no inflammatory language, no imposition of religious ideals, just information. Plenty of personal stories, yes, but that's to put into perspective the people who are at risk when we limit access to basic health care. This isn't the moral conundrum that we've been fed for years. It's a way to control women through their bodies.Robin Stevenson has constructed a comprehensive breakdown of historical precedent, recent women's movements, medical information and a schematic to move forward for women & girls across the globe. It's easy to digest and understand, without the author talking down to her audience.Some of the most enlightening for me was how closely racism and classism were associated with reproductive justice for women living in the US. The disparity between how contraception, abortion and sterilization has been available or limited to affluent white communities verses marginalized ones is enraging. There's something productive we can do with that rage, though. It's speak up loudly, publicly and often in defense of basic human rights. As quoted in the book, "Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere." - MLK*Thanks to Orca Books & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Cari Mora
author: Harris, Thomas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This wasn’t the disaster that other s had promised. I think with Thomas Harris there were expectations that a lot of previously successful authoThis wasn’t the disaster that other s had promised. I think with Thomas Harris there were expectations that a lot of previously successful authors feel when they decide to write something completely new, many years later. Cari Mora wasn’t hard to get through, but it was hard to get into.The biggest departure from the Hannibal Lecter series is what the plot revolves around. It’s kind of a cartel/heist book and takes place primarily in Miami, though there are some jumps to South America in present day as well as in flashbacks. Cari Mora is the name of the heroine, which was kind of a let down honestly. The author kept using her full name, I think to drive the title home, but I was hoping there was something more significant about it. Spoiler: there isn’t. And despite being the protagonist, she’s not given a lot to do. She’s young, attractive, vaguely useful, and eventually becomes the target of a murderous psycho (of course), but isn’t featured much until the end.The cartel stuff felt like someone trying to copy Narcos, and he even references the popular Netflix show in the book. I wasn’t sure who any of the cartel members were and who we were supposed to root for, and I frequently had to reread portions because I accidentally skimmed over someone’s death. The dialogue was choppy and weird at times, and the narration felt removed from the events being described.What was familiar just didn’t capture the same twisted interest as Harris’ other books. The main villain, especially, was just a cheap knock off of The Tooth Fairy or Buffalo Bill, that never quite landed for me. He’s a man with genetic defect, a social outcast, and is obsessed with mutilating women’s bodies in a really disturbing way. The stakes never felt real and neither did the characters. It was super readable, though, and I flew through it.TL;DR: you can skip this one....more

title: Howard Stern Comes Again
author: Stern, Howard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Part interview transcripts and part reflection on those interviews, Howard Stern Comes Again was a pleasant surprise that depicts a colorful compositePart interview transcripts and part reflection on those interviews, Howard Stern Comes Again was a pleasant surprise that depicts a colorful composite of a nuanced and at times, conflicted man. This book is probably better for those who aren’t already huge Howard Stern fans. If you haven’t listened to his show much or heard his interviews OR if you only know him by his shock-jock past, this is a great insight into his growth as an interviewer and a person. There’s a nice array of guests spanning several decades, so I think you’ll be able to make up your mind about him either way by the end. As I mentioned in my Shrill: Notes from a Loud Woman , I read the books concurrently and was able to round out some of my conflicting feelings about Howard Stern individually, and perhaps more broadly, what he represents. Stern of the 80s, 90s and into the 00s was a reactionary and crass contrarian who has admitted since that he harbored a lot of bitterness and feelings of inadequacy. He lashed out frequently and showed very little compassion at times. He said hurtful things not despite this fact, but because of it, just for the reaction. I would have not been interested in anything Stern of the past had to say.But he’s grown since then. He’s become more empathetic. He’s been given more freedom and has been able to let go of the anger he had. It’s a success story that I cling to now when it feels like cruelty for the sake of it has become more and more acceptable. His journey is laid out in segments at the beginning of each chapter introducing the guest and usually providing a personal anecdote that contributed to his line of questioning or mindset at the time. Some of them are more significant than others, while a few come off as self-congratulatory. On the whole, these parts have more of a memoir feel than the interviews, but both work well together.What I had more of a problem with intermittently was what he said to his guests. There’s a huge tonal shift if he’s speaking to a woman that’s more ‘sexualized’ in his mind vs the average man he has on. There felt like so much more inherent respect with the men and a select few women he has seemingly arbitrarily deemed worthy. The way he speaks about women with the men he’s interviewing can be diminishing as well. This isn’t limited to the Trump interviews or conversations 10+ years old; some are relatively recent and feel jarring compared to, say, his empathetic consideration of mental illness or drug addiction. If anything, the book is a great example of self-improvement. And perhaps an even better example of how we all have so much more room to continue to grow....more

title: The Night Circus
author: Morgenstern, Erin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't think I've ever been able to clearly envision a setting the way I was able to while reading The Night Circus. There's so much captivating and I don't think I've ever been able to clearly envision a setting the way I was able to while reading The Night Circus. There's so much captivating and dazzling detail that the tents and costumes and magic seem to leap off the page and construct themselves before you. The circus itself is just so utterly dreamy that I didn't want it to ever end! I ended up really drawing out the time spent reading it, and even so I don't feel like I fully got my fill.The characters are equal parts charming & engrossing, if not a little bit uncanny. So many minor characters left such an impression that I felt like they didn't get enough of our focus. Erin Morgenstern's greatest talent, though, lies in the descriptions of the world they're all living in. It makes me desperate for something similar and tangible to visit, but one without all the sketchiness around circus animals. I think the fantastical elements of the story left some parts without the intended emotional weight. There's deaths that don't feel that impactful and romances that don't exactly land for me, despite the radiance of the courtship. Some of the more sinister and ominous portions didn't quite pan out in the way I was expecting, but I don't think it took away from the eeriness as a whole.Alluring, magical and haunting, if anyone has been putting this one off (or just completely oblivious like I was), I would recommend giving it a go!This is currently 'in development' for a movie and I don't know how to feel about it. It's one of those books that will either be adapted amazingly or totally botched. It has a lot of potential for some breathtaking cinematography, but I think it will depend on the director, budget and marketing. If it really does happen, then they (director Geremy Jasper) better do it justice!...more

title: Between the World and Me
author: Coates, Ta-Nehisi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Different people are going to have different reactions to this book, depending on their own experiences. This line from Westworld best explains mine:"Different people are going to have different reactions to this book, depending on their own experiences. This line from Westworld best explains mine:"Have you ever questioned the nature of your reality?" Perhaps the fact that I only heard of this book after it was mentioned in Chelsea Handler's latest memoir says as much about my own perspectives. But nonetheless, I concur with the many other ers here. This should be required reading in the United States.Between the World and Me feels intimate, as it was addressed to his son, but also in the title, to the world. The framing as a letter to a child reminded me of Dear Ijeawele, or a Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie. As Ta-Nehisi Coates walks us through parts of his life, it feels as though every new discovery he makes creates an abundance of new questions. I wondered often how to catch up if you're already so far behind. For all of these questions, Coates admits to not having the answers to some. It's comforting that someone this smart struggles with resolving competing ideas about complex topics. Going forward, there's a lot that white America is going to have to reckon with. It's not going to be comfortable or easy, but with every day that passes it becomes more and more necessary. I'm not looking forward to the process, but I'm hopeful for the result. That's what will have to get us through the despondency....more

title: Darkness on the Edge of Town        (Stranger Things, #2)
author: Christopher, Adam*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wasn't sure what to expect from this Stranger Things novel. The only other one, Suspicious Minds, received mixed s from fans of the TV series. DWasn't sure what to expect from this Stranger Things novel. The only other one, Suspicious Minds, received mixed s from fans of the TV series. Darkness on the Edge of Town, however, is a backstory of one of the most beloved characters from the show, Jim Hopper, as a detective in the NYPD, seven years before he first meets Eleven. The majority of the text is set in 1977, but there are several intercut scenes in 1984, where Hopper is recalling the events of the story to Eleven. It's kind of like a Princess Bride thing.It starts as any by-the-book police procedural. Hopper investigating multiple homicides, a rookie cop, Feds vs local police conflict, etc. Don't expect much in the realism department here. He's a rogue cop who plays by his own rules & that's miraculously always in the right. Hopper in the book doesn't really seem to have the temperament to be a detective, and it didn't do much to make his character more sympathetic. A lot of the stakes for him seem melodramatic. Someone threatens his family in a completely unnecessary and cartoonishly villainous way. The bad guys don't seem coherent, and law enforcements eventual solution makes no sense. There's several cliches, my least favorite is the "I can't tell my wife what's going on because reasons." The back half of the book, though, picks up and gets pretty exciting. I'd just set both your expectations from the franchise and how police officers work aside before jumping in.I did really like the portions with Eleven, though, and wish there were more of them. Hopper at one point was explaining to a young girl in the 80s about sexism and racism in the 70s (for an audience in 2019). I get why they can't really put more of 1984 Hawkins in a novel while the show is still coming out, but this book feels like filler. Entertaining filler, but pretty disconnected.*Thanks to Random House - Ballantine & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Water Dancer
author: Coates, Ta-Nehisi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In Ta-Nehisi Coates’ Between the World and Me, he wrote on the idea of serious writers and their characters being white. Classic literature has been tIn Ta-Nehisi Coates’ Between the World and Me, he wrote on the idea of serious writers and their characters being white. Classic literature has been taught to us as historically being by white men about white culture, where other perspectives are interpreted as inferior. At one point, Coates considered a question by Saul Bellow that asks who the Tolstoy of the Zulus is. Later, he accepted the response by Ralph Wiley, “Tolstoy is the Tolstoy of the Zulus,” and in that sentiment affirmed that stories by black authors about black characters matter just as much as white ones, but without reducing them to merely a ‘black version’ of their counterparts. Though he’s written both Black Panther and Captain America’s comic series, this is Coates’ first full-length fictional work. Taking place during the middle of the 19th century, Hiram is a member of the Tasked in Virginia. He serves the Quality until he attempts to join the Underground and discovers the power of Conduction. The terms used are intuitive and historical, stemming from language used in the old south by both slaveholders and those enslaved. Most characters are created by the author, but historical locations, events and figures are skillfully interwoven with the magical realism of the novel to create a truly remarkable story.Coates is a talented writer, and I’ve enjoyed everything I’ve read of his. But, the beginning especially, was pretty slow going. Eventually the plot picks up a bit, but there were so many breaks in the story where Hiram would reflect deeply, and he felt like a stand-in for the author to have yet another introspection. These ideas seem to work so much better in Coates’ non-fiction books, but at times took away from the overall narrative he was trying to tell here. The book could have been much shorter without taking away anything crucial.I did enjoy it overall, though, and this was an excellent debut novel for an already very accomplished author.*Thanks to Random House & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Heroine
author: McGinnis, Mindy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** Books about addiction are tough, man. It's hard to watch someone go down a path that only has a few endings, even if they're fiction**spoiler alert** Books about addiction are tough, man. It's hard to watch someone go down a path that only has a few endings, even if they're fictional. Despite Mickey not being real, her struggles and her pain are representational of a national crisis that feels like it has no end in sight. I don't really enjoy stories about downward spirals. There's an inevitability to the despair the characters face and the best you can hope for is that the current rock bottom is the actual bottom this time. The prologue is a flash forward to multiple character deaths while the 'heroine' of the book is in the depths of her addiction. This is a massive spoiler before even the first chapter, but in a story like this, is it actually? What other way could it have ended? It's difficult to read about their lives while knowing how they will meet their end. And the element of surprise being taken away doesn't pull the eventual gut punch. Mindy McGinnis also doesn't hold back on the really unglamorous parts of addiction. From lies told, to the crimes committed, to the really gross bodily functions losing control, there doesn't seem to be much in the way of upsides to being an addict. One of the most poignant examples was when Mickey was self-medicating to counteract her other medications. Every new substance she put into her body to solve one issue kept creating a new issue in its place. It felt a lot like The Lady Who Swallowed the Fly. "She swallowed the cat to catch the bird, she swallowed the bird to catch the spider, she swallowed the spider to catch the fly....I guess she'll die."The fact that this all happened to a teenager is maybe one of the worst parts of it all. This book really sheds light on how vulnerable already vulnerable communities are to falling into this type of life. I don't know what the answer is...but I hope someone can figure it out sooner rather than later....more

title: Life Will Be the Death of Me: . . . and you too!
author: Handler, Chelsea
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's a lot of self-help books on the market. And thank god this isn't one. Some people have found their way in the world, and good for them. But a There's a lot of self-help books on the market. And thank god this isn't one. Some people have found their way in the world, and good for them. But a few of them have turned it into a formula and commodified it, to be sold to the world as a cure-all for life's big and small problems. And people going through personal crises lap it up, hoping to find something that might work for them too.Chelsea Handler isn't doing that. She, like many of us, see the issues of the world and want to do something, but feels powerless. So in this book, Chelsea starts by working on the only person she has direct control over: herself.I've read a few of her books before and loved both her E! & Netflix shows, but this book feels like a new era for Chelsea Handler. She starts by acknowledging her privilege as a white woman in America. She feels spoiled and selfish for living in luxury and wants to fix those parts of her. No, most of us aren't multi-millionaires living in Hollywood, but there's elements that a lot of people can relate to in wondering what it's all for.A majority of her personal growth is in therapy. We're related the sessions she has with her therapist, Dan, and get to witness a part of her that wasn't visible to even those closest to her. Learning more about her family dynamics, the loss of her brother, then mother, explains a lot about the Chelsea Handler of today. There's a lot of useful revelations that struck a chord with me as well. I found myself getting emotional with her at times.Chelsea has always been sharp. She's known in part for being crass and crude, but is also really smart and an excellent writer. The best part of her is put on display, and that's her incredible level of self-awareness. She's not condescending in her experiences, and there's still plenty of levity and funny moments. The chapters featuring her dogs are classic Chelsea. I feel like almost anyone who reads this would get something positive out of it....more

title: The Winter of the Witch        (The Winternight Trilogy, #3)
author: Arden, Katherine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It’s bittersweet to reach the end of such a wonderful series, but what an ending it was! After The Girl in the Tower, I started reading a bit about thIt’s bittersweet to reach the end of such a wonderful series, but what an ending it was! After The Girl in the Tower, I started reading a bit about the rule of Dmitrii Ivanovich and when I saw there was a warrior monk named Aleksandr that served him...well I’m very satisfied with where Katherine Arden decided to conclude the series.I will really miss Vasya, though. She’s a heroine for the ages and if the world was fair, would have an infinite number of books written about her. I feel like a lot of medieval fantasy drips with this unrepentant misogyny that’s given a pass under the guise of “historical accuracy”. Arden didn’t shy away from the harshness of this period, but put it into context without feeling gratuitous. There was no hand-waving, saying that’s just how it was, and I appreciated her ability to present feudal Russian in a way that didn’t make me gag. Vasya understands the nature of her place in this world, and she is able to carve out her own version of agency.The Winter of the Witch returns to the old, dark kind of fairytale—the type where Ariel turns into sea foam at the end instead of a princess. There’s more Russian and Slavic mythology as well as real historical events, which are masterfully melded together. Lingering questions and blank spaces are filled in with a level of detail that I’m not used to seeing in many series, if I’m being honest. The arc of Vasilisa Petrovna feels complete and on a clear trajectory. Plus, there’s a lot of action; you definitely won’t be bored.I wish the author was writing more for adults right now, but she’s been doing a middle grade series that I’ll still probably pick up eventually. Maybe we can split the difference and she can write YA next? But whenever she decides to put out something else, I’ll be the first one in line....more

title: Ask Again, Yes
author: Keane, Mary Beth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've always had a bias for kids over parents. If there's any kind of complicated scenario or relationship I'm more likely to take the kid's side. MultI've always had a bias for kids over parents. If there's any kind of complicated scenario or relationship I'm more likely to take the kid's side. Multi-generational stories like Ask Again, Yes always challenge those beliefs and I'm grateful for that. Even so, I think a big part of that is that I'm not a parent, and I have no plans to become one at any point. I feel like people who have kids are easier on other parents, more understanding of some mistakes because they've made them too. Parents are just people. I don't think that's much of an excuse, but is more of a reason that some adults shouldn't reproduce. I really felt for Kate and Peter as children and young adults, especially when they started living lives of least resistance. You might not outgrow the scars of childhood, but I guess you can treat them. I struggled with wanting to assign blame throughout this novel. It just feels like someone should be at fault. There are parties who bear some responsibility, but I just get so frustrated when they never seem to be the ones to bear the consequences. In this case, life really does imitate art.Mary Beth Keane does an excellent job juggling multiple viewpoints without abruptly announcing a new 'narrator' or harshly switching the tone. It feels like a movie in that way, just seamlessly checking in on another character, having the passage of time speed up or slow down accordingly. She's also able to put us into the minds of people struggling psychologically, especially when a character is having a breakdown or paranoid episode. Everyone is hurt by untreated mental illness, and she makes you feel that pain multidimensionally. This was a sad story of hard lessons. Not a happy ending, but some kind of a resolution. The best we can hope for, I guess.*Thanks to Scribner & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Crown of Coral and Pearl        (Crown of Coral and Pearl, #1)
author: Rutherford, Mara*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I thought this was extremely readable. It's well-written and compelling enough to want to finish. I just have been struggling with YA fantasy lately. I thought this was extremely readable. It's well-written and compelling enough to want to finish. I just have been struggling with YA fantasy lately. Some is done really well, and others feel phoned-in. This one fell somewhere in the middle.A lot of this book felt really familiar. A beautiful maiden, a sullen & smirking prince, a girl thrust into luxurious royal life, falling for the alternative love interest, etc. That's also not to mention the similarities Crown of Coral and Pearl shares with The Cruel Prince: twin girls, betraying betrothals, switching places, one submissive twin & one defiant one, being taken from your home. It's not the same story, but it felt as though they both covered the same themes.Except for the obsession with scars. I found it incredibly jarring. Almost every character either proclaims or sadly agrees that any skin blemish is literally the most disgusting thing ever, and it's never really challenged. Even by the end, I found the attempts at addressing it unsubstantial. The way Nor's facial scar is described is just nonsensical. It's so small and light you can barely see it, yet apparently it's the first thing anyone notices and is incredibly memorable. The idea of her being 'ruined' for it is just so absurd to me that I found it more unbelievable than the magic healing coral or mystical sea spirits.And for an alleged "queendom", there was some of the lowest levels of female agency that I've seen in a while. If the aim was to make anyone on the island of Varenia even somewhat sympathetic, it did not come across. It's probably not the best sign when an entire population is threatened with extinction and my first reaction is GOOD. I'm not sure if the ending is a set up for a sequel, but I think it would be best as a stand-alone. I liked the relationship between the sisters, but the romance(s) felt forced. And the villain seemed to just do whatever would make the story most interesting for the protagonist. Although I think a lot of people will enjoy this, it just wasn't my favorite. *Thanks to Inkyard Press & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Educated
author: Westover, Tara*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Educated was not what I was expecting. The buzz on this book was absolutely insane last year, and like any good faux-rebel, I decided I would read it Educated was not what I was expecting. The buzz on this book was absolutely insane last year, and like any good faux-rebel, I decided I would read it later when all the hype died down... And when it never died down I just snagged one of my libraries 15 digital copies when one became available. And it was...woof. It was truly a lot to take in. For some reason I assumed it was more aspirational in nature, something like Girl, Wash Your Face of last year. It ended up being more like The Glass Castle, a memoir I deeply love. Maybe the giant pencil cover threw me, idk. Whatever the reason, I wasn't ready for Tara Westover's devastating recollections of her childhood.The Westovers are not bad people. It's not like they set out to actively harm their family. But they are also not fit to be in charge of children. The saddest thing about their story is that these situations are more common (to varying degrees) than we want to admit. How can we mediate situations that we don't know exist, by people who are naturally adverse to involving any type of 'outsiders'? There's a terrifying and dangerous amount of intentional ignorance and seclusion in some parts of the US & the rest of the world. I don't know the solution to problems like this.Almost as concerning is some of the negative reactions to this memoir. How someone can call this "fake" or "exaggerated" is beyond my understanding. I actually saw a  that said "I've heard of worse upbringings". It's not a contest. And that just adds credibility to Westover's story. Some even doubted the education she received, despite the professors & institutions being Google-able. Good God, I hope those people aren't ever approached by a cult. If they are, they'll be hiding in their own bunkers, stockpiling weapons and canned fruit with the rest of them.I found Tara Westover's chronicling of her own self-doubts and criticisms her best asset in warding off nay-sayers. The gas-lighting by her family and constant purposeful regression really drove home how deep the trauma goes. The entire family is stunted, and even after Tara and some of her brothers have 'gotten out', their father (and to an extent mother & brother) still have such a strong grasp on them. At one point she mentions not wanting to be referred to as 'impressive' by an academic audience. I can understand that, but it's really all I can say to sum up her harrowing life. She's impressive not just for her higher education or subsequent career, but her resolve. Her resolve that even when broken several times, had come back together, propped her back up and carried on....more

title: The Beekeeper of Aleppo
author: Lefteri, Christy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Christy Lefteri has crafted a remarkable novel. In the Author's Note she describes her time working at a UNICEF refugee camp in Greece and how deeply Christy Lefteri has crafted a remarkable novel. In the Author's Note she describes her time working at a UNICEF refugee camp in Greece and how deeply it affected her. With the help of refugees in England and informed by her own experiences at the camps, the characters of Nuri and Afra took shape, representing the thousands of displaced from Syria and other war-ravaged places. These perspectives are crucial to the construction of the book. You can see Aleppo like a painting in front of you, hear the voices echoing in Athens, taste the salty Aegean Sea. But you also feel the devastating and all-consuming hardship of the people displaced from their homes. We move from Nuri's prior life in Aleppo, Syria, back and forth to his applying for asylum in the U.K., one slowly catching up to the other. Every relocation and obstacle hits you like a punch to the gut and the immensity of their situation sinks in steadily until you're swallowed whole.This is a book about family, friendship, distance and grief. The physical scars may eventually fade, but psychological ones only fester. In The Beekeeper of Aleppo, we see those who are violently thrown from their previous existences begin to unravel and how much of yourself is left behind. I want others to read this piercing novel so we can stop being scared of scared people.*Thanks to Random House - Ballantine & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Six of Crows        (Six of Crows, #1)
author: Bardugo, Leigh*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “No mourners. No funerals. Among them, it passed for ‘good luck’.”[image]As much as I enjoy reading fantasy, sometimes I feel a little hesitant before“No mourners. No funerals. Among them, it passed for ‘good luck’.”[image]As much as I enjoy reading fantasy, sometimes I feel a little hesitant before starting a new series. There’s so much world-building and lore that has to be unpacked to appreciate the characters and their motivations that sometimes it can be rough going in the beginning. After debating between the original trilogy, first duology and the currently incomplete second duology (so...one book), I decided to pick up Six of Crows despite the chronological order of the Grishaverse. This series has had such glowing s that I thought it would give me the best shot at falling in love with Leigh Bardugo’s work and fully committing to her world. And.....I think I made the right choice. With a plot that centers around a heist and a half a dozen distinct character points of view, there’s so much going on in absolutely the best way. From Jesper, the cheekiest and best sharpshooter you’ll come across, to Nina, who’s powers paired with her charm will keep you on your toes, to Inej, just as endearing as deadly, with a particular set of skills that will have you checking over your shoulder—there is not a weak character in the bunch. And when they team up with Wylan, Matthias along with their forever-scheming leader Kaz, you’ll be hard pressed to find a treasure or secret out there that they‘ll be unable to extract.“Kaz leaned back. ‘What's the easiest way to steal a man's wallet?’‘Knife to the throat?’ asked Inej.‘Gun to the back?’ said Jesper.‘Poison in his cup?’ suggested Nina.‘You're all horrible,” said Matthias.” The Dregs, as they’re known, are rambunctious and brilliant and funny and exactly who you’d want in a group of frenemy gang members to be. There’s enough information given to easily follow along with what’s happening, with enough withheld to not overwhelm but keep you guessing. I was totally enraptured. I even had to force myself finish other books I was reading before I would let myself come back to this one. Bardugo’s writing has found its rhythm here, and her greatest strength lies in her characters’ interactions.[image]This is one of those stories that you’re just going to have to experience for yourself. Out of all of the books I’ve recommended to people, Six of Crows has one of the highest success rates, even among my notoriously picky reader friends. And honestly, the biggest drawback of reading her other series set in this universe has been that they never quite reach this level of radiance again. Though if you want to revisit some of the same characters and locations, there is a direct sequel, Crooked Kingdom, which is her second best novel. But I don’t want it to seem like I’m trying to knock against the original trilogy—it’s still good! Show-watchers who stumble across this  will absolutely want to read that if they want to deep dive into the Ravkan turmoil. And for those who prefer to read it in chronological order, this is what you’re going to want to do:Shadow and Bone -> Siege and Storm -> Ruin and RisingSix of Crows -> Crooked KingdomKing of Scars -> Rule of Wolves[image]I’m sorry Alina, I still love you.And now with the second KoS book out this year, I’m sad to say there are no Grishaverse books currently in the works. That said, Bardugo has mentioned there is *potential* for a third one “many years down the line”, which makes me equal parts ecstatic and anxious. I’m completely ravenous for any future books set in this universe, but afraid that she may not be able to recapture the magic of this specific duology within the world she’s now expanded on even further. Only time will tell, but either way I’m still going to be reading up and tuning in to whatever has Bardugo’s name on it....more

title: Disappearing Earth
author: Phillips, Julia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Raw and devastatingly vivid, Disappearing Earth has more than lived up to its laudatory s. So many lives are affected by tragedy, and Julia PhilRaw and devastatingly vivid, Disappearing Earth has more than lived up to its laudatory s. So many lives are affected by tragedy, and Julia Phillips expertly depicts these rippling effects, even to people and places one wouldn't expect to be impacted. Despite only being explicitly featured in a couple of chapters, the disappeared girls are a common thread linking many disconnected lives together, in unexpected ways.But there's more at work here than just a story about two missing girls. The book is structured as stories and glimpses into the lives of several different people living in the same peninsula of Russia. We see how two stolen children are used to tighten the already rigid hold on women across many communities. This book is about trapped women and trapped girls. Yes, there's a resolution to the two girls' story, but for many we meet, there's no such satisfying conclusion.Which is perfectly acceptable, and closer to the truth for those living similarly. It's a testament to Phillips' writing how quickly I became attached to new characters, despite only knowing them for a couple dozen pages. I was amazed at the way some characters who were prominent in later chapters had been woven into earlier ones in seamless cameos. This was an impactful and remarkable novel, and as a debut leaves me even more eager to see more from this author!...more

review: Reading this book felt like putting together a puzzle without knowing what the picture is going to be. Each piece is a work of art in its own right, bReading this book felt like putting together a puzzle without knowing what the picture is going to be. Each piece is a work of art in its own right, but you don't necessarily know what its significance is yet in relation to the others. Everything is so expertly woven together that by the end it feels like a weighted fabric draped over you, something you can't take off. Something you don't want to.I was so captivated by the stories of the characters in this novel that I stopped reading everything else and couldn't go back to them until this was finished. Tommy Orange is an artist. I'm such a fan after this debut, and likewise devastated there isn't more. I don't know what he's planning for a follow-up, but I'll be the first in line whenever he decides to write it....more

title: Internment
author: Ahmed, Samira*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really liked the idea here. It's not that far from the realm of possibility, for either American Muslims or asylum-seekers at the southern border. BI really liked the idea here. It's not that far from the realm of possibility, for either American Muslims or asylum-seekers at the southern border. But I wasn't able to get all the way through it, honestly. It's not bad, but I just have a too-full TBR list to devote several more hours to a book I'm not really getting anything out of.The severity felt inconsistent. Some changes are drastic, but there isn't really a visible 'turning point' in the country. Nor is there anything incremental at all. The timeline feels very rushed, if I'm interpreting it correctly. It's not that these things can't happen, I just don't think they'd happen like this. Also the euphemisms to Trump are too heavy-handed to not call him out specifically. I'd say either commit all the way and use his name or make it more ambiguous; you can't have it both ways.It also reads very YA. The teenagers feel like a parody of teenagers. I didn't connect with any characters. There's some good ideas, but the execution really undersells the message. I'm a little bummed, but I'm sure there will be plenty more Trump-spawned books coming out for several years after he's expired from the office....more

title: The Swallows
author: Lutz, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Right away, The Swallows hits the ground running. You're immediately brought into Stonebridge's intense ecosystem from the perspective of Alex Witt, aRight away, The Swallows hits the ground running. You're immediately brought into Stonebridge's intense ecosystem from the perspective of Alex Witt, a new teacher, who doesn't have time for teenage hierarchal nonsense. We then meet Gemma Russo, a student and rebel trying to topple the abusive status quo from the inside, not long after. Other narrators include student Norman Crowley and faculty member Finn Ford.This started off as a fun book. It followed some of the familiar beats of a private boarding school, but quickly it turns into something else entirely. We're thrown into the planning stages of a budding rebellion, with none of the unnecessary explanations of why the characters would be so outraged at the state of their school. One group of students is being despicable to another group through various acts of manipulation and fear. By the time the revolt comes to a head, I'm ready to take up arms along with them. The writing is funny and casual, even with very not-casual subjects. Lisa Lutz overlaps character perspectives sometimes and tells the interactions from multiple points of view, which I enjoyed for the most part. There were a few times I didn't realize that several chapters were all taking place simultaneously, but figured it out eventually.I got so ramped up that, especially approaching the final act, I wanted to brandish an axe and shave my head--Alas, the ending was inevitable. Not predictable, but it couldn't have ended any other way. The final paragraph was really haunting. This is one of those that's going to stay with you a long time after you've finished it.*Thanks to Random House - Ballantine & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Where the Crawdads Sing
author: Owens, Delia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a really good novel. I agree with another er who said they felt surprised that it surged so much in popularity, though. Perhaps it was This was a really good novel. I agree with another er who said they felt surprised that it surged so much in popularity, though. Perhaps it was a matter of timing, that it's resonating more now than it would have years ago. Either way, I'm glad to have gotten the opportunity to read it.The story focuses on Kya, a young child who grows into young woman after being abandoned by her family before she was able to read. She spends a lot of this time desperately sad. So much of her life seems tinged with desperation. Desperate for human contact, love. Desperate to get away from it. She's the tragedy of a girl left to fall through the cracks, and then be blamed for those circumstances. Really heartbreaking to think about.There's a suspicious death and eventual investigation, but while it may be a 'mystery', it didn't really pull my focus. I thought I could see where it was going, but even if you can 'guess' parts of the resolution, it's by no means the end. The final third or so felt like it dragged a bit, so I can see how some people got bored. I feel like if you're only reading for plot-driven reasons, then you're more likely to be disappointed.Where the Crawdad Sings is a portrait of American life that seems to be preserved in part from generation to generation, for better or worse. I hope it can challenge our prejudices in a meaningful way, like it did for some characters in the book....more

author: Harrow, Alix E.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’ve seen this book described as a love letter to storytelling—and that’s spot on. It starts out familiarly enough, a plucky young girl raised by a weI’ve seen this book described as a love letter to storytelling—and that’s spot on. It starts out familiarly enough, a plucky young girl raised by a wealthy benefactor at the turn of the century, and while I enjoy some of those stories, they can feel a bit stale after a while. Even though it was immediately apparent Alix Harrow was an exceptional writer, I didn’t expect to be so enraptured by the world she has crafted and shared with us.There’s adventure and intrigue, there’s mystery and mysticism. There’s magic and contests of wills. There’s so much heart poured into this book that I often found myself very moved. It gave me a feeling deep inside that anything is possible. If I read this as a child I might have believed it to be secretly true, even if I knew better, similarly to how I felt about The Chronicles of Narnia. I don’t want to overhype and then have it not meet someone’s extraordinary expectations, but I can’t imagine that anyone who picked up The Ten Thousand Doors of January could be disappointed. This one’s more than just a pretty cover.*Thanks to Redhook Books & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Silent Patient
author: Michaelides, Alex*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Full disclosure: I hate this cover. It looks like skin peeling off and I really can't look at it, so much so that I wasn't going to read this book at Full disclosure: I hate this cover. It looks like skin peeling off and I really can't look at it, so much so that I wasn't going to read this book at all. I know it's supposed resemble something like that, even to make you initially uncomfortable, but I hate imagery of ripping and peeling skin. Black Swan nearly broke me out in hives, and I'm itchy just thinking about it. BUT The Silent Patient has been getting such glowing s that I decided to suck it up and dive in......and I'm so glad I did. While the premise is great, woman in asylum is silent after being convicted of husbands murder, I don't think it fully does the story justice. There's such a collection of characters, each with an incriminating and innocently annoying duality, that you never know if your suspicions are well-founded or completely paranoid. This mirrors Alicia Berenson's journey, as she lives out the 'is she telling the truth, actually crazy or crazy like a fox' theme that I love so much.There's also something about therapists/mental health facilities/shrinks that people instantly distrust. It could be entertainment media portrayal or historical precedent or personal experience or maybe just something fundamental about the idea of someone trying to get into your head. I love the way Alex Michaelides played with our expectations and was able to deliver such a satisfying--not even a twist, but a revelation. Ugh, now I feel bad for trashing the cover. It's cool! I'll just stare at it until I'm desensitized. [image]Brilliantly constructed and utterly engrossing, Michaelides has made himself a new fan!...more

title: Shrill: Notes from a Loud Woman
author: West, Lindy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In my grand tradition of hearing about a new tv show/movie, learning that show/movie is based on a BOOK, refusing to watch said show/movie until I’ve In my grand tradition of hearing about a new tv show/movie, learning that show/movie is based on a BOOK, refusing to watch said show/movie until I’ve read the BOOK, being added to a waitlist at the library approximately 700 people long, before finally getting to read it—only to realize that I don’t have a Hulu account to watch the aforementioned show/movie I read the BOOK for in the first place, I give you: Shrill by Lindy West.Whether I end up using someone else’s log-in or just pirate it while dodging softcore anime pop-ups, I’ll eventually watch the show Shrill. The brilliant Aidy Bryant plays a Lindy-like character and I’m assuming there will be plot lines that mirror her life, but right now I can’t compare them any more than that. All I can say is that I loved Ms. West’s writing and I hope the show lives up to it.Despite the title, the book is not just about loud, outspoken women. The author is an unflinching feminist and has repeatedly called out those who promote sexist and harmful rhetoric, but it’s not just about the misogyny. West discusses the intersection of sexism and fat-shaming, along with other issues like racism and online trolls, and links them in a way that’s easy to understand and hard to unsee once it’s been pointed out.Interestingly, I was reading Howard Stern’s new memoir at the same time, and I was caught off guard when West proclaimed her love of his radio show throughout her formative years. She writes about struggling to reconcile her admiration for him with the outright sexism on his program, where she felt like she had to laugh along with a joke to which she was the punchline. This really mirrored some of my feelings reading the thoughtful reflection by an older Stern at the beginning of a chapter, followed by jarring language in the transcripts immediately following. A lot of the interviews weren’t even that old, like around five years or so, but it still came off as dated and not very funny. The two books ended up being unlikely companion pieces to each other.The part about losing her “funny card” really got to me. Having to decide whether or not to continue to weather abuse in a community that you’re a part of and otherwise enjoy or take a stand and end up subjecting yourself to even more vitriol, whilst having your membership to that community revoked is just so desperately unfair. And time after time of taking those hits eventually causes an instinctual avoidance of it altogether, if you haven’t already been kicked out at that point. The fact that this happens in comedy, where so many outsiders and outcasts have found reprieve from the harshness of the world, is just even more depressing. I’m glad that Lindy West and her book have done so well. She’s a fantastic writer who validated my impulses to use CAPS for EMPHASIS, without taking away from the ‘seriousness’ of her work. Her upcoming book The Witches Are Coming is one of my most anticipated for this year, but until then I’ll just be reading old Jezebel articles of hers to pass the time....more

title: Shadow Frost        (Shadow Frost, #1)
author: Ma, Coco*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’m getting tired of YA fantasy monarchies, at least the traditionally ‘western’ ones. The princesses are all sarcastic and the princes are just a smiI’m getting tired of YA fantasy monarchies, at least the traditionally ‘western’ ones. The princesses are all sarcastic and the princes are just a smirk personified, and all this ground feels very well-treaded. I’m reading too much into this, but what does it say when all the important and powerful characters are determined by ‘blood’ and the station to which they are born? I never thought I’d pine for the Bella Swan styled regular girls *sigh*, but here we are.The character interactions really aren’t charming in the slightest. They’re just mean to each other, then their ears and cheeks flush. Not to mention how inappropriate some of these relationships are; if someone is your ‘guardian’ growing up, but as soon as you get boobs it becomes something more, then he needs to be shipped off to the Woody Allen Island of Misfit Predators. Also—what’s desirable about a guy crashing through your closed bedroom window, leering at your “low neckline”, then slapping him while he clutches a...baby bird? Is this what teenagers think is romantic now? Back in my day, creepy older men in books simply snuck into teenage girls’ bedrooms to watch them sleep, like NORMAL people.And woooooow the male posturing is just next level. Two dudes are arguing and fighting every other chapter over said sarcastic princess’s **vIrGiNiTy** and it’s incredibly toxic. She also hits them both a lot. Hopefully I don’t need to explain why these are problematic, especially for teenagers. Relationships shouldn’t be this hostile, and there’s nothing in the least bit romantic about how these characters act with each other.It’s fine, just too familiar. I only got halfway through before I decided to throw in the towel. If you’re looking for a paint by numbers YA fantasy novel, then this is as good an option as any. The author apparently wrote this when she was 15, so I’ll give her the benefit of the doubt and am open to reading more from her.*Thanks to Blackstone Publishing & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Say Nothing: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland
author: Keefe, Patrick Radden
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For those outside of the U.K., at least stateside, we're not taught much about the period known as 'The Troubles'. In fact, I don't think I had any foFor those outside of the U.K., at least stateside, we're not taught much about the period known as 'The Troubles'. In fact, I don't think I had any formal instruction on basically any of the conflicts between England and Ireland besides possibly a blurb about how so many of the Irish immigrated to the U.S. in the last couple of centuries. And after reading Say Nothing, it's clear that this is by design. I couldn't help the alternating waves of outrage and fatigue coming over me. With every chapter I demanded justice and that someone pay for these crimes, and by the next one I assessed that the people had paid enough--it was time to stop. The absolute terror of this localized violence feels nearly impossible to those who have never experienced it, and the more that regular people were pulled into the crossfire, the more I felt like several key players who held the most responsibility ended up escaping the carnage relatively unscathed."The romantic idyll of a revolutionary movement is easier to sustain when there is no danger that one's own family members might get blown to pieces on a trip to the grocery store."Though Patrick Radden Keefe touches on several time periods and references many players in this undeclared war, we follow a few in detail to frame the unfolding of key events. Chapter 1 opens in 1972 on the abduction of Jean McConville and we follow her children as they search for what happened to her well into their own adulthood, past even the age she was when she was taken. The second chapter looks at the Price sisters, Dolours and Marian, during their childhood in the 1950s growing up in an IRA household. We follow their radicalization as a template for how many young people became involved in the new Provisional IRA. Through them we meet Gerry Adams and Brendan Hughes, and in their friendship we see the power structure of the Provos and associating organizations working for the cause.The search for Jean McConville grows over time as we learn new information. It goes from what happened to Jean McConville, to where is she, to who took her, to why was she taken? The first two questions have been conclusively answered, and the second to last is nearly there as well. Keefe satisfies most with his own deductive explanation, but it won't be confirmed without the passing of one of the people involved. To the final question, there isn't a consensus, but it doesn't really matter. For those who seek justification for this crime and others, you won't find it. And similarly, for those of us who seek traditional forms of justice, we're unlikely to receive it.The Troubles aren't a unique type of conflict, but unlike those that seem to be further removed from North American and European lives, North Ireland feels like our own backyard. In situations like these, there's no real winners, just loss. And as much as I'd like to say we will learn from past mistakes, it feels more likely we'll just continue making them."Who should be held accountable for a shared history of violence?"...more

title: The Girl in the Tower        (The Winternight Trilogy, #2)

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In the follow-up to The Bear and the Nightingale, we catch up with Vasya not long after she fled her home following the death of her father and step-mIn the follow-up to The Bear and the Nightingale, we catch up with Vasya not long after she fled her home following the death of her father and step-mother. In an act of ultimate projection, she’s been accused of witchcraft by the total creep-fest priest, Konstantin, and has to disguise herself as a boy to escape the patriarchy (marriage & convents, ew). After linking up with the frost demon Morozko and their respective sassy horses, the two embark on a buddy comedy called Made In Moscow or The Byzantine Brothers, with new episodes airing weekly on NBC.**I’m using humor to distract from the fact that it’s been a few weeks since I read this and kinda forgot what happened—BUT it’s all coming back to me now I swear!   [image]After reading better ers’ synopsizes, I actually do remember how I felt during The Girl in the Tower for the most part. This sequel was a lot more political than the last book, with Vasya having to navigate complicated power dynamics while also concealing her identity. Her only two siblings that matter, Sasha and Olga, are there in Moscow with her, both trying to protect her from outside forces as well as from her own dangerous impulses. (The two other brothers, one of whom I forgot was even a thing, basically don’t exist in this novel, so don’t bother trying to remember their names.)The villains of this book feel less defined. They’re more ambiguously human and less ‘evil one-eyed bear’ or straight-up Frollo. (view spoiler)[I did get kind of lost for a bit in the Kasyan vs Morozko beef, but I’m like 85% sure I got it now. (hide spoiler)] Vasya serves total Mulan vibes as she gets ready to assume her Final Form™ in The Winter of the Witch, the final installment of Katherine Arden’s trilogy.Please don’t take my flippant tone as a representation of the book or series. I used all my ~*fancy words*~ for my  of the first novel, and felt this cosmic pull to balance out all of that gushing with references to Disney movies from the 90s and Celine Dion. If you enjoyed The Bear and the Nightingale, you’ll also like Arden’s latest installment as well....more

title: The Empire of Gold        (The Daevabad Trilogy, #3)
author: Chakraborty, S.A.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A 2020 Goodreads Choice finalist in Fantasy!It’s really no secret how much I’ve adored this series. From the moment we met Nahri in The City of BrA 2020 Goodreads Choice finalist in Fantasy!It’s really no secret how much I’ve adored this series. From the moment we met Nahri in The City of Brass, I knew this was going to be a special story. I’d like to just take a beat and thank Shannon Chakraborty for transporting us into a world of her own imagining; I feel truly lucky to have been able to experience her creation.“Creator, every time I think I’ve found the bottom in all of this, I get some new story of murder and vengeance.”But for those who haven’t had the opportunity yet, I don’t want to mislead anyone into thinking this is a series of just beautiful magic set in a far away place. Though the characters are powerful djinn, the setting an enchanted city, at the center of the story is revenge and violence, passed down through the generations. Pain and grudges are inherited, just like their powers, and it can be a difficult cycle to break out of. Empire of Gold is the final comeuppance for all the characters who have been reeling with this legacy of grief and trauma. Each of the younger ones are forced to make a decision: will they let their ancestral anger dictate their paths or will they forge their own? I’m sure there’s a lot of parallels to Middle Eastern history and politics represented between the 6 tribes which I am not aware of. But you don’t have to have any sort of background knowledge before diving into this series; you just need to prepare to have your beliefs challenged again and again. And take my word for it, Chakraborty doesn’t let anyone get away with feeling 100% vindicated. This is an entire society painted in shades of grey, much like our own.“she wasn’t going to waste her life regretting other people’s choices”There wasn’t one character I didn’t feel for in some way. Nahri is our protagonist that tries her best, but is struggling with identity. Ali is devout, rigid in his beliefs, and always attempting to do the right thing. Dara is strong, passionate and stubborn, with a relentless loyalty to those he loves. I won’t give a blurb for every single character, but Zaynab, Muntadhir and Jamshid are also completely captivating. Throughout all three books, Chakraborty explores themes of family, both who you’re related to and that which you choose for yourself. Similarly, we examine the importance of a shared history, of a shared culture. The importance of someone’s name. It’s up to each person to decide which pieces of themselves make up their own identity. You don’t have to answer for every mistake your family or friends have made, but each of us is responsible for the choices we make. We are culpable in accepting the status quo when it benefits us to someone else’s detriment, even if we aren’t the ones to created that power structure in the first place. Seeing something wrong and doing nothing causes just as much damage.Please note I have barely scratched the surface of everything covered in these books! Read some other s so you can get a fuller picture. If this was being adapted for film instead of a Netflix series, this book would be split into at least two movies. Not just because of the length, but the huge amount of plot and territory that’s covered. But since it is going to be a Netflix show, I would also like to congratulate Shannon & the fandom because honestly this is huge for us too!! ...more

title: The Good Dog
author: Mills, Walker Jean*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was an incredibly sweet book. The author uses love for a family dog to teach empathy and kindness to children. My neighbors had a dog they loved,This was an incredibly sweet book. The author uses love for a family dog to teach empathy and kindness to children. My neighbors had a dog they loved, but when they had a baby about a year ago the dog reacted aggressively to her and tried to attack her. They were beside themselves when they had to get rid of their dog for the sake of their daughter. Though she won't remember the dog at all, I'm sure as she gets older they might consider getting another. I'm giving them this book to help remind and reenforce the love that can exist between a kid and her dog. Just an FYI for anyone who is interested: there's a bible verse at the end of the book. It's not a religious story, but it's applicable to the idea of being kind to people. This may be a plus for some readers who are Christians and may be out of place for those who are not, but I thought it could be relevant either way.*Thanks to Goodreads and Walker Jean Mills for a signed copy!...more

title: The Queen of Nothing        (The Folk of the Air, #3)
author: Black, Holly*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of those books that I don’t know how I feel about until I’m, like, halfway through writing the . As others have pointed out, there’sThis is one of those books that I don’t know how I feel about until I’m, like, halfway through writing the . As others have pointed out, there’s nothing that’s incredibly groundbreaking in this series as far as YA fantasy goes. What has made it so popular is that it’s all done excruciatingly well; there’s that elusive quality that you can’t quite put your finger on which makes it incredibly addictive.That said, no matter what the star rating ends up being, this was pretty definitively the weakest installment of the Folks of the Air trilogy. I’m not sure if Holly Black felt the need to hurry to get this one out, but considering The Wicked King came out only earlier this year, I feel like she could have waited until 2020 and taken her time wrapping everything up. Much of the book felt rushed, and coming in at just barely 300 pages, there was room for a little extra narrative.Now for the spoiler-heavy critique: (view spoiler)[The biggest thing missing (besides MORE PAGES) was the looming sense of fear and precariousness surrounding Jude. The first two books had her scrambling to simply survive, but all of her supposed ‘threats’ in The Queen of Nothing felt toothless. I was never actually afraid she or another main character would fall to harm. The ending was so anticlimactic. I was waiting for literally any of Chekhov’s guns to surface, but Black just dropped them ALL. Lady Asha (Cardan’s mom) amounted to nothing. The Undersea turned tail. Locke, one of the most quietly menacing villains of the series, was killed before the book even started. I just...don’t understand what happened here.And that’s not even touching on the characters who suddenly did an about face for no discernible reason. Oriana I guess has no loyalty and no motives, which undermines her prior shrewdness. Madoc is all over the place, seemingly just there as a foil to Jude’s plans. Cardan has been reduced to a schmaltzy romance novel cover-boy. And—I’m sorry, but I am definitively NOT here for the Taryn redemption arc. Whoopsie I killed the husband who I betrayed you for, who almost killed you, and who was meeeean to meeeee after. Can you take the fall for his murder for me and our baaaybeee. I have not actively rooted for any character’s death as much as Taryn’s, good lord, she is T-O-X-I-C. The only ones who seem unaffected are Vivi and Oak, who both are just as delightfully apathetic to the Faerieland skirmishes as ever. I really didn’t like the softening of characters in an effort to make them more, I dunno, likable? Why bother trying to redeem any of the characters? One of this series’ strengths is that the characters are so easy to hate. You don’t really want to root for any of them because they’re bad people, but you do it anyways. Why not just own that? Instead everyone gets a pass for all of the shitty stuff they’ve done for the sake of a touching family pizza party at the end. (Seriously, Madoc killed their mother & father, stole half the army, almost killed Jude, plotted against her, tried to enslave her and turned her friends and family against her, and his punishment was....having to live comfortably with his wife, daughter and adopted son? WHAT?) (hide spoiler)]In a year with so many great fantasy and YA fantasy releases (including the second book in the same trilogy!), The Queen of Nothing didn’t manage to leave much of an impression. I really hate to give this anything but a glowing , but I can’t let the hype overshadow the actual contents of the book. I wouldn’t say I’m disappointed, but, yeah, this was a bit of a let down.As an aside, I love when authors I love are friends, and this dedication made me inexplicably happy:“For Leigh Bardugo, who never lets me get away with anything”...more

review: This book really spiked my stress levels. Really good, but made me so anxious. One of my worst nightmares is everyone thinking you're insane and nobodThis book really spiked my stress levels. Really good, but made me so anxious. One of my worst nightmares is everyone thinking you're insane and nobody believing you. It's just so debilitating. Am I crazy? Or is everyone else? Oof, I can't stand it.Changeling folklore is a reaaaallly messed up part of British history. I'd say Google it, but I wish I hadn't. Depending on the myth they could have been twins or kids with developmental disorders, like Downs Syndrome, which just adds an extra layer of awfulness to it all. Really cool concept for a modern day twisted mystery, but it makes me want to hold my imaginary children close--I can only guess how actual parents will feel reading it.On another note, I noticed a similarity between one aspect of Little Darlings and another book with questionable kids, Baby Teeth. Mostly, just the insufferableness of the fathers in both. Are all dads like them? They can't be. The father in Baby Teeth seemed like a more devoted father, but also more naive. Patrick, on the other hand, is just trash. Ugh, Lauren, girl--just throw the whole man away. I can see why there was so much buzz about this one. And word is that it's going to be adapted into something, so be on the lookout for that!*Thanks to Crooked Lane Books & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Enchantée        (Enchantée, #1)
author: Trelease, Gita*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: On the cusp of the French Revolution, Enchantée straddles the worlds of historical fiction and fantasy. Camille is a magician living in poverty in theOn the cusp of the French Revolution, Enchantée straddles the worlds of historical fiction and fantasy. Camille is a magician living in poverty in the beginning of 1789 before she unlocks more of her magic and is able to infiltrate the world of the aristocracy. If you know anything about this period, you know that this is an...interesting time to start jumping up the class ladder.Camille has two siblings, Sophie and Alain, who are awful. (view spoiler)[Alain is an abusive monster and I'm glad he's shoved out of the picture most of the time. Sophie is painfully idiotic and naive, especially for someone old enough to get married. She has the temperament of a much younger girl, in a world where poor children like her would have had to grow up fast. You would think that compared to her brother she would come off better, but it really just highlights how spoiled she acts and how crappy she treats her sister. No love lost for either of them. Camille, girl, just tell people you're an only child! (hide spoiler)]The historical events happening are really well-woven into the plot, and you can follow along with how both the poor in the city of Paris as well as the nobles in Versailles are responding to the civic unrest. Camille befriends several members of the upper class and becomes more sympathetic to them, which challenges her beliefs about class and wealth. (view spoiler)[Although come on....Lazare not being allowed to blow his inheritance on a hot air balloon is not a real person problem. Seriously, there are literal cHILDREN STARVING IN THE STREET. But he's TroyBolton-ing about not being able to 'be himself'. Yeah, no. Let him eat cake. (hide spoiler)]I liked the magical aspect. It was a little undefined, in that it seemed to change in capabilities depending on what was required by the characters at that exact moment, but not too often. I will say this book suffered from my mortal nemesis Characters-Not-Sharing-Information-Because-Plot-And-Conflict, which is incredibly annoying. The bad guy was obvious & mustache-twirling evil, and the build up to the final climactic moment was a little predictable, but it was still a decent read....more

title: Everything I Never Told You
author: Ng, Celeste*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Reading an author's debut novel after more recent works has been an unintentional pattern I've fallen into lately. Part of me feels as though I've misReading an author's debut novel after more recent works has been an unintentional pattern I've fallen into lately. Part of me feels as though I've missed the boat in terms of garnering anything new or revelatory from these first books, but another part feels like maybe I'm able to appreciate them with more context into the author's point of view. Unless books are in series, there isn't much of an expectation to follow them chronologically. But while the plots and characters of individual stories may not intersect, you can usually trace themes shared through the majority of a writer's work, even if in their original book you may not have seen them.Despite being regionally close in setting, there's little connecting the characters of Everything I Never Told You to Little Fires Everywhere. Almost immediately, though, I was struck with how complicated the family dynamics were within the Lee family. Celeste Ng has a keen ability to construct complex familial webs where any tug on one member invariably pulls on many others.Many of the characters blame one another for Lydia's death. Is there anyone to blame? Is it a little of everyone? Is it no one? Their blame is just accusatory responsibility that's grown from their own past resentments. Each member of the family is struggling with feeling responsible for other people's happiness and well-being, even at the cost of their own. The responsibility Lydia felt towards her family during her life isn't quashed in death, it's passed on to the people she left behind. Every interaction is tinged with pronounced regret. It's a really bleak portrait of American middle class life that only stings so much because it rings so true. I found myself welling up near the end. This was truly beautiful & lingering and I eagerly await her next novel....more

review: I don't like to not finish books, even if I skim or skip sections. But yeah this wasn't for me. I got about halfway through before throwing in the towI don't like to not finish books, even if I skim or skip sections. But yeah this wasn't for me. I got about halfway through before throwing in the towel.To be fair to the author, I won't leave a rating. There's nothing wrong with his writing. John Glynn seems like a nice guy. The subjects of his memoir just remind me so much of some of the people I went to college with. The ones who never really grew out of those days--not necessarily the drinking or partying, but the mindset. I'm only a few years past and the summer in Montauk feels to me like an extra long spring break, divided by high school cliques.I also probably shouldn't have started this book immediately after finishing one about Syrian refugees. There was too much of a tonal shift. Everything felt trivial, and I'm sorry, but I just don't really care how privileged east coast 20-something's spend their summer bar hopping. *Thanks to Grand Central Publishing & Goodreads for an advance copy!...more

author: VanderMeer, Jeff*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really liked the idea of this once I figured out the setting. If Annihilation is the crew aboard the shuttle, then Authority is the story of missionI really liked the idea of this once I figured out the setting. If Annihilation is the crew aboard the shuttle, then Authority is the story of mission control. The ironic part of that being that they seemingly have no control over the mission at all. During Annihilation we were kept wondering, 'What's the bigger picture here?', 'Is this all part of a larger plan?', 'Who's actually pulling the strings and to what end?', so I was excited to see the back-end so to speak of these explorations. Even if it meant a near entirely new cast of characters.If there's a difference between OMG what's happening?! and Wait, what happened?, then I was waffling between the two of them much of the time. I wasn't sure whether my attention span was just failing me or whether parts were unclear, but I found myself having to go back and re-read portions where I missed some information. Jeff Vandermeer reveals information in a really strange way, and he does it this way multiple times.I wanted more information into the members of the Southern Reach other than The Psychologist and Control. All other employees seemed like stand-ins for actual characters. Even ones we get more interaction with, like Whitby and Grace, feel like they only act as obstacles for the protagonist, not as their own entities. Similarly, Central was a total mess. I get it's supposed to represent 'The Government' shrouded in secrecy, but it just came off as disjointed and unnecessarily ambiguous.The first half or so was nearly unbearably slow. So much was repeatedly dwelled on in Control's past and inter-office conflict that could have just been done away with. I had no idea the book only spans a week; it felt like months. Part 4 ended up being the most intense, and I wish portions like that had received more attention. There were some really interesting insights into the beginning of and initial responses to Area X, but they just weren't explored enough. Also, I understood nearly nothing until three-quarters of the way through, which feels excessively withholding.I like the world Vandermeer crafted, but I wish he was more consistent in his storytelling....more
