author: He, Joan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book gave me so much whiplash--especially at the end! Part magical fantasy, part courtroom drama and part murder investigation, there's a lot of This book gave me so much whiplash--especially at the end! Part magical fantasy, part courtroom drama and part murder investigation, there's a lot of plot in this one. The question of who killed the king is dangled over us as the new queen has to attempt to navigate her country's legal system as well as the court of public opinion. Hesina additionally goes up against her own advisors, ministers and even her own people. There's a complex political structure in Yan that did away with the 'unquestioned tyrannical king' that usually exist in stories like this, which I really appreciated. There's also a religious cult-like mindset that invades the population and mimics some of the abuses of power and widespread fear & animosity that parts of the world are dealing with today. Both the audience and the characters are asked, is it better to try to appease a mob or to dismantle it? "In trying times, truth is the first thing we betray."Hesina has a pretty large and complicated family, with an adopted brother and sister, a half-brother and a full brother along with her father, mother who doesn't live with them and the courtesan mother of said half-brother. There's resentment and anger bubbling beneath the surface at all times, and it at times was difficult to follow people's motivations. Sometimes even after the explanations of some characters' actions, I was still left confused on why.I don't know if this is a theme with the fantasy books I've read lately or just in general, but it seems like the endings are always set up for a sequel. Which is fine, but I like to know that going into the book, so I can rate it as a stand-alone or one of a series. If this was a stand-alone then I feel like it left me with some questions, but if there's more coming, then the epilogue was the perfect post/mid-credits scene like out of a Marvel movie. You'll be itching for more!*Thank you to Albert Whitman & Company and Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Priory of the Orange Tree        (The Roots of Chaos, #1)
author: Shannon, Samantha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow I feel like I just finished a marathon, despite my debilitating allergy to exercise. After breaking myself from the hypnotic trance that is the coWow I feel like I just finished a marathon, despite my debilitating allergy to exercise. After breaking myself from the hypnotic trance that is the cover, I'd hoped to conquer this book but was still a little nervous. Maybe it’s the size.......yeah it’s mostly the size, but the s had also made it out to be something supremely epic and I felt a little apprehensive as if it could actually swallow me whole. The Priory of the Orange Tree definitely lives up to the hype. It's expansive and intricate and had me in awe of the world Samantha Shannon had constructed. I was a bit lost at first and constantly referencing the map, but by the end I had a general idea where the characters were most of the time. Chapters are organized by regions 'East', 'West' & 'South', but you’re not always aware of which kingdom or perspective you’re following. It ends up forcing you to focus and not passively read; this is a story that demands your attention.But finally, I have found a fantasy book that doesn't follow arbitrary gender roles in a world of magic and dragons. In crafting Priory, Shannon puts women and men on an equal playing field. When designing their own societies with their own sets of rules, I never understood why so many authors choose to restrict half the population in the same way they've been restricted in our own histories. It wasn't until near the end of the book that I realized there hadn't been any sexual violence. There wasn’t even the threat of rape, which is so common in fantasy that most of us are probably desensitized to it.There's also none of the teenager sex scenes that appear more often in YA fantasy either. This is a book written for adults that doesn’t have to resort to cheap potshots at female characters in order to distinguish itself from YA and doesn’t use hIsToRiCaL aCcUrAcY as an excuse to subject them to further harm. Women are heads of courts, they're villains, they're mothers, they're soldiers, they're complex and whole and none of their character development is done at the expense of male characters. And it’s all done without being explicitly addressed. There's no grand declaration that women are subverting expectations or are just as capable as men. They just are. And it's wonderful and well-done.I know it's a doozy of a book, but it's sooo worth it. Really, I don't know how Shannon is going to get away with not writing a follow-up. There's just too much potential! Although I expressly forbid her from writing anything longer than this. There's as much plot in her one book as there is in like 3 seasons of Game of Thrones.[image]**For more book talk & s, follow me on Instagram at @elle_mentbooks!...more

title: The Outpost: An Untold Story of American Valor
author: Tapper, Jake*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Before The Hellfire Club in 2018, and even before joining CNN in 2013, Jake Tapper authored The Outpost: An Untold Story of American Valor in Before The Hellfire Club in 2018, and even before joining CNN in 2013, Jake Tapper authored The Outpost: An Untold Story of American Valor in 2012. In the shadow of the War on Terror taking place in Iraq, Tapper provides a harrowing testimony of American military presence in a remote part of Afghanistan from 2006 through 2009. Following the 3-71 Cav to the 1-91 Cav and 6-4 Cav, ending with the 3-61 Cav, The Outpost injects a remarkable amount of humanity into events and subject matter that can feel very technical to a civilian audience. The title makes it sound like this book is about one battle. It's not. By nature of the war in Afghanistan, there's an expanding map of locations and evolving roster of people manning them over an ever-extending period of time. Frankly, it can be overwhelming, but Tapper includes many reference points and plenty of backstory to ground yourself in & keep you from getting too lost in Afghanistan village names or military lingo.Still, the immensity isn't just related to the terminology, it's in tandem to the war itself. I had this looming feeling of dread any time a new person was introduced and their life's story was provided. Too many times someone appeared, only to be seriously injured, nearly killed or actually die. Advancements were made in working with local leaders, followed by them being completely undermined chapters later. The state of the war in Afghanistan was such that there felt like no progress was being made, but the only way to guarantee a total collapse of the country was to pull out all forces. The difference between the resources and attention allocated to the two countries is best described by this saying from American troops: "If you're in Iraq and need something, you ask for it. If you're in Afghanistan and you need something, you learn how to do without it.”I will warn anyone that wants to dive into this book that it's not something you can passively read; it needs your full attention or you'll quickly become lost. Also prepare to become incredibly frustrated. Though it's fairly localized, the struggles of those depicted in this book are indicative of the larger issues of the war in Afghanistan. It's insightful, devastating, aggravating and extremely thorough. Journalism like this is what we need now more than ever--a critical eye with an open mind and an empathetic heart.For those who read this after the movie comes out in 2019, from what I understand, the majority of the plot and characters in it are present only in the third/final part of the book. Orlando Bloom's character, 1LT Ben Keating, is in the first part and Milo Gibson's, CPT Robert Yllescas, is in the second. Scott Eastwood, Caleb Landry Jones & James Jagger are present for the final firefight as SSG Clint Romesha, SPC Ty Carter & PFC Chris Jones. Since there's no overlap of the time when Keating and Yllescas are at the camp with the members of the 3-61 Cav, I'm curious how they'll be incorporated into the movie. Some of the veterans of this outpost and battle along with Tapper were consulted on it, so I'm sure it'll be faithful to actual events. After it comes out I'll try to remember to update this post!...more

title: Searching for Sylvie Lee
author: Kwok, Jean*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Intriguing, mysterious and with a cross-cultural plot, Searching for Sylvie Lee had a lot going for it based off the premise alone. I was totally onboIntriguing, mysterious and with a cross-cultural plot, Searching for Sylvie Lee had a lot going for it based off the premise alone. I was totally onboard during the middle of the novel, but after a slow start and a weirdly neat, but somehow still incomplete ending, I still feel somewhat unsatisfied.Amy Lee's older sister, Sylvie, is accomplished, brilliant & stunning, but is still struggling personally and professionally. I totally get that, and I think a lot of people can identify with both sisters feeling like they're treading water. The story focuses on two parts of an extended Chinese family, one living in the US and one in the Netherlands. There's flashbacks and perspectives from multiple generations, and some interestingly translated phrases (in English). I liked seeing a part of Europe I haven't really read much about, and I appreciate that Jean Kwok didn't shy away from the way minorities are treated in both the US & Europe. From the country that brought you Zwarte Piet (Black Pete), it's crazy that some of the most 'progressive' countries in the world could be in such denial about their own racism and prejudices.That said, I don't know why I felt so detached reading a lot of it. I think it might have been that I only really related to the Lee sisters. The other characters seemed almost like stereotypes of Dutch and Chinese people, which is weird because the author was born in Hong Kong, grew up in the US and currently lives in the Netherlands. The Nordic people were all distant and cold, the Chinese were extremely traditional and secretive. Sylvie and Amy, both American, were drowning in student loan debt and searching for their 'purpose'--which actually is completely spot on. 😔He first half reads like Where'd You Go, Bernadette, but less whimsy & more weight. (view spoiler)[The second half has a lot of parallels with Everything I Never Told You: drowning, sister searching for sister, parental/marital strife, secret gay crush...actually there's even more than I thought. But the ending doesn't carry the emotional weight that Celeste Ng provides in her books. The suicide doesn't really make a lot of sense, even in something as nonsensical as suicide. Also, the abusive and predatory husband/workplace are just....never addressed? And after decades of resentment in the family, everything is worked out in one conversation? They're all good now? It just felt flimsy, which is a bummer because I was starting to get into the Whodunnit of it all.  (hide spoiler)]I'd like to read more from the author, because I like her writing, but this story just didn't stick the landing for me.*Thanks to William Morrow & Goodreads for an advance copy!...more

title: Boy Swallows Universe
author: Dalton, Trent
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'd heard a lot of conflicting information about Boy Swallows Universe before I eventually got to reading it. I saw it described as a thriller, romancI'd heard a lot of conflicting information about Boy Swallows Universe before I eventually got to reading it. I saw it described as a thriller, romance, crime, coming of age story, and it's not really any of those things on the whole. There's elements of all of those and more, but I hesitate to put any single label on it.Some parts are a real slow burn and others are incredibly fast-paced. The first three-quarters seemed to be all preamble and a set-up for the last quarter; I wish it was a little more consistent throughout. Truthfully I was completely lost at times, not debilitatingly so, but in a way that had me counting pages remaining in the chapter. Additionally there's both fantastical and touchingly beautiful portions fragmented throughout. I'd press anyone who's read it to say they weren't moved during the reflections on trauma and the failure of adults responding to it in children. It's not difficult to discern what's taken directly from Trent Dalton's life and what's fiction. The author is similar to Eli Bell in this way: he's a "'colour writer'...'You like all the little details...You paint pretty pictures.'" I felt like Dalton was constantly adjusting our view from trees to forest, back and forth again and again. The book is about tiny details shaping a boy's life. The book is about the entirety of the universe doing so. The book is about people. The book is about grand ideas. I have no idea what this book was about.I found a lot of scenes playing out in August and Eli's lives familiar to the world we're currently in, but also in stark contrast that feels like it's from a far-off era. There's something surreal about reading material set in the recent past. People live in the suburbs, but women can't open their own bank accounts. Everyone watches tv and drives cars, but you can be openly discriminated against for being a minority. This isn't a land of corsets or flappers in speakeasies, it's the period my parents grew up in, the 60s, 70s & 80s. Some of the typical experiences of people during those decades seem obscene to hear about now.This is the type of novel I think I would revisit at some point in the future. Things I've missed out on the first time around may appear pronounced later on. If HBO is on the look-out for something else to adapt after Big Little Lies & Sharp Objects, I think it would be an excellent candidate.*Thanks to HarperCollins & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Wicked King        (The Folk of the Air, #2)

review: I can't think of any fantasy series that makes me feel as anxious as this one does. In the same way each prince of The Cruel Prince was immensely crueI can't think of any fantasy series that makes me feel as anxious as this one does. In the same way each prince of The Cruel Prince was immensely cruel, just about everyone in The Wicked King is supremely wicked. Seriously, everyone short of the Bomb and Oak could drop dead and they'd probably deserve it.We get to see Jude as the de facto ruler and how that impacts her ideals. Though she keeps insisting that she's only acting the way she does to protect the people she cares about, she consistently does many of the same things that she use to criticize the prior ruler for doing. Is Jude becoming the thing she use to despise? It reminds me of that line from Mean Girls "I know it looks like I was becoming a bitch. But that's only because I was acting like a bitch." Mmmm okay, Jude, girl. Whatever you say.(view spoiler)[God as if I needed more reasons to hate Taryn. Why doesn't everyone hate Taryn as much as me? we shoULD TOTALLY JUST STAB TARYN. Hopefully for the last book Jude will stop de-powering herself. I really dislike how often she subjects herself to all the abuse and ridicule and straight up torture from the faeries. I'm looking forward to final-form Jude in the style of like a Mega Charizard flying back into Elfhame like an absolute terror.Now that Cardan reverse-ghosted her, Jude might actually be formidable. That hate-sex scene was simultaneously unexpected and completely predictable. I know that the next book will have him claiming to have sent her away 'to protect her', and knowing Jude, the murderous doormat that she is, she'll totally accept that. title: A Curse So Dark and Lonely        (Cursebreakers, #1)
author: Kemmerer, Brigid*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was...not the book for me. Maybe I was enchanted by the cover, but the story itself didn't live up to my expectations. Once you strip away all thThis was...not the book for me. Maybe I was enchanted by the cover, but the story itself didn't live up to my expectations. Once you strip away all the Disney-isms, catchy songs, charming French candle sticks, Emma Watson, etc., the creepier elements of Beauty and the Beast really appear much more jarring. Based on the initial information we're given about Rhen, there was just no way for me to forgive him. He might be redeemable to others, but after the (view spoiler)[kidnapping of hundreds of young women, their many deaths, the slaughter of his family and soldiers, denial of this information to his entire people & even more (hide spoiler)] ....I just can't do it. It tinges this romance with ickiness at best and furious disgust at worst.But it's not just the Prince that is extra ugh-enducing. Harper is a lot of things. She is strong-willed. She's a girl with cerebral palsy. She is a skilled equestrian. She has a mother dying of cancer. She's also got one of the worst cases of NotLikeOtherGirls disease that I've ever seen. She's so different from the hundreds of others. None of them were quite like her. I just hate when books do this. A woman isn't interesting only at the expense of other women. I just think their romance is completely ridiculous. She's supposedly furious for being kidnapped but has butterflies for him within 24 hours of her snatching. She just gives in too easily. He's also one of the least charming princes I've encountered in YA fantasy. Like, come on, it should not be that hard to resist him.At one point he says "There is no greater crime than rape." And then follows it up by saying outright that it's preferable to die than live after surviving sexual assault. I will attempt to reign in my outrage by letting that horrendous sentiment speak for itself.Unfortunately, I was not a fan. I skimmed a decent amount. It's not badly written, but I loathed the characters and eventual premise too much to ever have a chance of liking it. Without the prince it would have been a paint by numbers YA fantasy, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. If you want an interesting and atmospheric retelling of a classic fairy tale, might I recommend House of Salt and Sorrows by Erin A. Craig. It's creeping and fantastical and did a better job overall....more

title: The Song of Achilles
author: Miller, Madeline*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is exactly my kind of love story. Madeline Miller has the extraordinary ability to humanize mythological figures in new and compelling ways. CharThis is exactly my kind of love story. Madeline Miller has the extraordinary ability to humanize mythological figures in new and compelling ways. Characters that may have been traditionally hard to empathize with move and speak with a level of dimension I would have trouble assigning to them otherwise. Basically—she’s made me give a shit about some old Greek assholes.The Trojan War is one of the most chronicled events in history, its lore being embellished and retold, with several surviving versions currently in existence. There’s not much that’s revelatory in The Song of Achilles in that sense; Miller isn’t reinventing the story. But she breathes new life into established characters and hones their lives & choices into arcs an audience can follow. I usually have trouble reading when I know how it’s all gonna end, but Miller writes so well that part of me genuinely believed it was somehow going to turn out differently.The only downside is that after finishing this, I have now read two out of two of her novels. This is sad. Someone pray to Athena that she comes out with another soon....more

title: The Bear and the Nightingale        (The Winternight Trilogy, #1)
author: Arden, Katherine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a hauntingly beautiful novel. After finishing I'm left not empty or ravenous, but satisfied with that conclusion of the first in a trilogy. Yes, What a hauntingly beautiful novel. After finishing I'm left not empty or ravenous, but satisfied with that conclusion of the first in a trilogy. Yes, the door is left open for more story, but it's set to the side, nearly out of sight. While some series rely on dangling a precarious cliff-hanger in front of greedy readers, Katherine Arden's characters, descriptions and story-telling will keep us involved until the bitter end.And yes, I expect the ending to be bitter. It's a harsh world, fourteenth century Russia. I'm surprised I was able to find a precise time period (around the mid 1350's) to place these events in. The princes of Moscow, though, were real people who lived during that era. I obviously didn't find anything about Vasya, since the princesses barely had their first names mentioned on Wikipedia. Even girls born into influential families were barely a footnote of history, as seems to always be the case.Perhaps that's part of what makes Vasya such an enthralling heroine. She exists believably within her own historical confines while occasionally moving outside the lines of what was expected of women and girls. Every injustice just solidifies her resolve and makes you that much more invested in her endeavors. Maybe just as much as it was a darker fairy tale, The Bear and the Nightingale is a stiff rebuke of religious fanaticism and the rectitude of 'divine' rulers. The weaponization of vulnerable persons fears in order to serve a hidden agenda seems to be a thread that runs throughout both literature and history. How easy it is for one charismatic individual to turn an entire local population into frenzied, craven monsters, scarier than even those they initially feared.I can't wait to delve further into this world and see what else Arden has to offer....more

title: A Keeper
author: Norton, Graham
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I saw this book was written by someone named Graham Norton, I thought, Oh, like the guy from that British talk show with the red couch! Graham muWhen I saw this book was written by someone named Graham Norton, I thought, Oh, like the guy from that British talk show with the red couch! Graham must be a super common name over there. I was totally caught off guard when I found out it was the same person! Though it feels like every celebrity has 'written' a book of some kind, usually nonfiction about their own lives, I did not expect him to be a fiction writer as well. Celebrity authors garner a lot of attention, and it feels like their efforts don't usually work out as often as they do, but I was pleasantly surprised with Mr. Norton's sophomore novel.Told as flashbacks between mother and daughter, we follow Elizabeth in present day as she returns to the place she was born for answers about her origins. Patricia, her mother, has died and Elizabeth's responsible for her home and apparently appeasing her terrible family. Intercutting the issues she has with them, her son and ex-husband, we're given background on Patricia and what happened to her around the time Elizabeth was born. While not action-packed, the story is creeping and tense. Every answer found raises new questions as you work your way through the mystery of it all.I really liked it, and I'll be sure to check out Graham Norton's other novel. Anyone who enjoyed Clare Mackintosh's books, such as I Let You Go Or Let Me Lie, I think would appreciate this.*Thanks to Atria Books and Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Assassin's Blade        (Throne of Glass, #0.1-0.5)
author: Maas, Sarah J.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Having only read the first Throne of Glass book, I didn't know where this collection of prequel stories fit in, and I'm not sure if I'm going to wish Having only read the first Throne of Glass book, I didn't know where this collection of prequel stories fit in, and I'm not sure if I'm going to wish I held off on them or not. Buuuut this one had a shorter wait time than Crown of Midnight, so I shuffled the batting order a bit. Looking at all 5 stories individually I can see what each one was meant to accomplish. Pirate Lord sets up the conflict for the other 4 novellas as well as give insight into the relationship between Celaena and Sam, who was mentioned in the first novel. I peaked enough ahead to see that Healer was meant to give background on a character that will show up in later sequels. Desert also introduces a future character as well as provides some world building.Underworld is like the running start before the vault, Empire, where we stick the landing, perfectly positioned to lead directly into the events of ToG.But taking a step back and looking at them as a whole, I think Maas gives us just as much character development for Celaena as any world-building she does here. I'm not sure if I just brushed over some of her flaws while reading the first one or if it was more evident here, but maaaan is she stuck-up and selfish. I guess I could chalk some of it up to teenage arrogance, but sometimes she was just really insufferable. And we really get beat over the head with how *~*pReTtY~*~ she is at nearly every opportunity. I just didn't notice she was so vain and materialistic in the original book. Perhaps these events humbled her some? Based off of the ending of the final novella, I can see where she got some of that attitude from. The naïveté I complained about in the first book was also on full display here, but I understand that she hasn't had time to shed that yet.I also kept getting MAJOR Iron Fist vibes every time she mentioned she was Adarlan's Assassin™. Which was approximately every other page. Seriously, it was like I am Celaena Sardothien, the Immortal Adaralan's Assassin, protector of Rifthold, sworn enemy of the King.I wish that these stories were spread over a longer period of time. I would have loved to see her training and much younger, to see how she'd develop into the person she is now, but hopefully there will be more opportunities to look back on that time in future installments!...more

title: Parkland: Birth of a Movement
author: Cullen, Dave*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 20 years after the catalyst that would launch an era defined by school shootings in America, Dave Cullen follows up his book chronicling the events of20 years after the catalyst that would launch an era defined by school shootings in America, Dave Cullen follows up his book chronicling the events of Columbine with Parkland. 10 years since its release and still haunted by the stories he related to the world, Cullen and the rest of America find in the students of Marjorie Stoneman Douglas precisely what was missing from the gun control debate over the decades: young, passionate and relentless voices from those most vulnerable.There isn't one person in America who's grown up during the past 20 years that hasn't thought about being shot at school. This is I think the point that many older generations either don't grasp or don't want to accept. Now after letting gun legislation all but disappear, an entire generation has risen up to demand action from our country that has denied its own complicity in the death of its children.Last year, when the March For Our Lives was taking place across the nation, I watched with foggy eyes as student after student gave speech after speech on behalf of gun safety and as a call against violence. I wasn't at the march, in D.C. or more locally in Chicago, but I was in audience of both. They streamed through Twitter on my computer, from the comfort of my bed. I cried then. And I cried reading this book.This is a brilliant piece of journalism, a personal profile on several March members and a call to action for those reading it. According to Cullen, the adults in the book expressed trouble balancing the young teenaged survivors: how do you give them the deference of adults while protecting them as children? By listening and paying attention.MFOL and the Parkland kids didn't fix everything. We're just starting to take a second look at gun legislation, but their actions have had a crucial impact. They've shifted the conversation. No longer can politicians plead the second on common sense gun measures. Not without the younger generation(s) holding them accountable....more

title: Gods of Jade and Shadow
author: Moreno-Garcia, Silvia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's interesting to think about how little Mayan, Aztec or other Indigenous mythology is present in mainstream US culture compared to, say, Greek mythIt's interesting to think about how little Mayan, Aztec or other Indigenous mythology is present in mainstream US culture compared to, say, Greek mythology. This especially considering our geographical proximity to these cultures vs Europe and the rest of the world. Maybe that's evidence of our Euro-centrism left over from colonialism, but I'm glad that's changing as time goes by.This book had a fun mix of fantasy-adventure, magical folklore, historical context (Mexico, 1920s) and a daring female protagonist who forms a bond with the God of Death. Sometimes it's easy to forget how much social mobility has changed over time and varies in different regions of the world. Casiopea has very few options before (unwittingly) falling into the service of a previously imprisoned god who must go on a quest to retrieve parts of himself stolen by an evil-er sibling. Even though she was forced(!) upon threat of death(!!) to help this god reclaim himself, they eventually form a bond which came off like a kind of Stockholm Syndrome, but whatever, maybe he was unbearably dreamy.I also definitely read the title as Gods of Shade and Shadow for the first half of the book and imagined the demons and gods being super passive-aggressive to each other.Moreno-Garcia is wonderfully descriptive and creates a lush world for readers to step into. The story was compelling and I really appreciated the characters' interactions with one another. I think a lot of people will enjoy this book!*Thanks to Random House - Ballantine & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: A Curious Beginning        (Veronica Speedwell, #1)
author: Raybourn, Deanna*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a pretty fun one. A murder mystery set in 1887 and starring a female lepidopterist with a modern outlook, Veronica Speedwell can be quite chaThis was a pretty fun one. A murder mystery set in 1887 and starring a female lepidopterist with a modern outlook, Veronica Speedwell can be quite charming when she wants to be. The pairing of her with foul-mouthed fellow scientist Stoker makes for the trading of clever jabs at each other's expense and is, for the most part, enjoyable.I was interested in solving the two big mysteries: the murder(s) and Veronica's past. Everything else felt like an unnecessary trek that was disjointed from what she and Stoker were trying to accomplish. Basically there's about 100 pages of plot I could have done without, but it didn't take away from the rest of the story, just from my attention span.While I liked the banter to a point, there was a lot of it constantly. Sometimes it seemed like Stoker only said things to set up a 'smart' retort from Veronica. Honestly, she's also really mean to him at times and I think we're meant to cheer her on for it? I'm not sure. And this is totally not important, but it also got stuck in my head....HOW did Veronica's flask have that much liquor in it?? Like, they're constantly taking pulls from this thing and getting wasted, but it doesn't run out until near the end! Is there some magical South American juju at work that made it actually bottomless?! I have seen no flask that could hold the amount the two of them drank. I don't even think a 1L bottle would have enough, tbh. But I digress.I think I'll stick with this series. I'm hoping after all the character introductions and background information is established there will be more room for other storylines. (view spoiler)[I was surprised to find out Veronica's mother was likely based off of an actual person. Look up Nellie Clifden if you want to read about her, but she had a fling with the prince which was rumored to have been a contributor to his father's death. The liberties within the book start with his marrying her and fathering a child with her, of which there is no evidence. But she was an Irish actress! (hide spoiler)]...more

title: The Stranger Diaries        (Harbinder Kaur, #1)
author: Griffiths, Elly*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a really pleasant surprise! I'd never heard of Elly Griffiths before receiving this book in the mail, but it ended up being so much more thanThis was a really pleasant surprise! I'd never heard of Elly Griffiths before receiving this book in the mail, but it ended up being so much more than your typical boilerplate thriller. Set at a British secondary school, many of the adult characters are members of the English department, so there's several literary references sprinkled throughout. The apparent murder of a faculty member is intercut with passages from a short story, The Stranger, who's author had resided at the school, shrouded in intrigue many years prior. The Victorian gothic style of the story mirrors the events of the novel and does an excellent job of keeping the hair on your arms raised in tension.Told from the perspectives of Clare, Ella's colleague/friend; Georgia, Clare's daughter; and Harbinder, one of the investigators into Ella's death, Griffiths is skilled at switching between three distinct voices. The danger of obsession is played with and throws suspicion onto several possible suspects. Even though every person who becomes obsessed isn't a killer, the threat and excuses we use to dismiss these tendencies are contrasted with the eventual worst-case scenario. There's a lot of story worked into this mystery. I was jumping from conclusion to conclusion before the guilty party was revealed. After this one, I think I'll be checking out other Elly Griffiths books--possibly the Ruth Galloway series?*Thanks to Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, Netgalley & Goodreads for advance copies!...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This one was okay. It's basically a revenge fantasy. There's plenty that pushes the boundary of believability, including a main character moving to MaThis one was okay. It's basically a revenge fantasy. There's plenty that pushes the boundary of believability, including a main character moving to Manhattan on a whim, randomly emailing a stranger for a highly coveted job (& getting it) and the ease of renting and moving about NYC with nearly zero planning. There's even a makeover that I'm sure would make a great movie montage scene set to an upbeat pop song.The book is written from two perspectives, Kerrie and Jordana, who are ruthless narrators. They're both pretty--as the title demands. And they have this 'not like other girls' vibe that rubbed me the wrong way at times. I'm not sure who I was supposed to root for, if anyone, because I really didn't take to either. None of the characters really talk like people do. Like I said, it reads like someone's fantasy. It reminded me of a Facebook post telling a story of something that totally, definitely happened and ended with "and then everyone clapped". So many of the characters felt like line item stereotypes: cheating asshole husband, check; materialistic, vapid women, check; rich hottie who's above all that stuff and really 'sees' our heroine...you get it. I also found the guy that we're supposed to like completely insufferable, so there's that.It's just too predictable. I feel like the author could have played with our expectations and really surprised the audience, but ah well. It's not bad, but I won't remember I read it a month from now.*Thanks to Gallery Books & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: House of Salt and Sorrows        (Sisters of the Salt, #1)
author: Craig, Erin A.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This ended up being a lot creepier than I was expecting! I thought it would be a Victorianesque fantasy/murder mystery as a spin on the old 12 DancingThis ended up being a lot creepier than I was expecting! I thought it would be a Victorianesque fantasy/murder mystery as a spin on the old 12 Dancing Princesses fairytale, which it still was. But there was a really Gothic and twisted element to the story that was a welcome surprise. All of the characters come off as at least a little bit sinister as you attempt to unravel the strange events befalling the Thaumas family. You're never sure what's real and what's not, which is disorienting in the best way. It's a really devastating story, even if it ends on a high-ish note, there's a lot of death and destruction. I'd suggest not reading while on any downers.The one thing I wish wasn't as prevalent was the romantic element. Maybe it's my cold, un-dead heart, but I kind of feel like it takes away from the familial love and trauma if in the midst of mourning your sisters there's a week-old romance that gets all the grand gestures and statements. But it's based on a fairytale, so the heroine is expected to fall in love with the first person who says "bless you" when she sneezes, I guess. On the source material, I really, really liked the answer to the question: "How do the princesses' shoes keep getting worn out?" Craig is quite clever with this storyline and it's one of my favorite parts of the whole book!*Thanks to Random House Children's and Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: The Mastermind: Drugs. Empire. Murder. Betrayal.
author: Ratliff, Evan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a ride! I had never heard of Paul Le Roux before jumping into this book, but it turned out to be astounding and at times riveting, bordering on tWhat a ride! I had never heard of Paul Le Roux before jumping into this book, but it turned out to be astounding and at times riveting, bordering on the fantastical. If I wasn't told it was true crime beforehand I would have agreed with Preet Bharara that parts "were ripped from the pages of a Tom Clancy novel".The events depicted initially jumped between the early/mid-2000s, when the first crimes were taking place, and a decade after that, when Evan Ratliff embarked on his own investigation. Eventually the years in between are filled in by investigators, law enforcement and a surprising number of people who previously worked for Le Roux. That ended up being one of the most insane parts to me, that the author was able to coax so many former associates (some still avoiding capture by American authorities!) into giving interviews and admitting to being a part of many extremely serious international crimes.The book is divided into three parts and then into chapters depicting different sides of the investigation and entire criminal enterprise at various stages. My favorites were 'The Reporter' and 'The Investigators' chapters. Ratliff is a skilled journalist and his ability to relay his first-hand accounts of the places and people he visited were extremely engaging. The ones with the cooler sounding titles--'The Mercenaries', 'The Mastermind'--were interesting, but at times struggled to keep my attention. When this shady underworld starts unraveling, the pace picks up as those involved start collapsing under the pressure.The unexpected antagonists of the ordeal seemed to be the arresting agency and prosecutors involved. Specifically, the SOD and Linda Marks, who both dropped the ball in big ways, and failed to live up to the work that Kimberly Brill and Kent Bailey put into the pursuit of Paul Le Roux and his organization. The inability to coordinate with both internal and international law enforcement were a huge weak spot that an alleged 'criminal Mastermind' could easily exploit. The reader is left to judge whether or not he did so.*Thanks to Random House and Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Colombiano
author: Young, Rusty*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've been wanting to read something like Colombiano for a long time, but without really knowing exactly what it would be. Rusty Young does an impeccabI've been wanting to read something like Colombiano for a long time, but without really knowing exactly what it would be. Rusty Young does an impeccable job overlaying facts and events with fictional characters and circumstances. I had to resist my urge to find out if every person or utterance actually happened, because it doesn't really change anything. The stories in this book are representative of a larger issue and have real-world, human consequences. It didn't matter if there was a kid named 'Coca-Cola'.The novel did end up being a lot longer than I thought, but the chapters are relatively short & digestible. That said, there's definitely parts that could have been cut down. I think Young was trying to incorporate his main subjects' full testimony of the conditions in Colombia and perhaps didn't feel right about removing these portions.One thing I appreciated was that the author didn't skim over the women and girls who were caught up in the fighting as well. It might have been easy for a protagonist who's young & male to brush off what happens to his female comrades, but he confronts the sexual exploitation and straight-up assault by commanders and other enlistees towards those in their own ranks. And though not as often, the racism in the country is pointed out by way of Pedro's best friend, Palillo. The ending was as much of a resolution as you could hope for in a no-win situation like this. For anyone who wishes to gain some insight into the other side of the 'War On Drugs', I strongly recommend Colombiano. I can tell this will be one of my favorites of the year!*Thanks to Havelock & Baker and Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Winners Take All: The Elite Charade of Changing the World
author: Giridharadas, Anand*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really like Anand Giridharadas. I’ve seen him on a couple of media outlets, and it’s clear he’s a smart guy. I also have come to agree with a lot ofI really like Anand Giridharadas. I’ve seen him on a couple of media outlets, and it’s clear he’s a smart guy. I also have come to agree with a lot of the stuff he says about economic inequality and how those in power across the political spectrum work to keep the status quo. But this book was still difficult for me to get through, despite clocking in at under 300 pages.I’ll admit I find it harder to read nonfiction that doesn’t have a narrative element running through it. Something like Catch and Kill or nearly any memoir is so much easier for me to get sucked into. The problem with Winners Take All for me was that the gist of his argument was made in the introductory chapter. The following chapters were just collections of examples of what he already said. Like, here’s a woman who wanted to save the world but then got sucked into the capitalism machine, here’s a man that believes he’s helping other people but it really helping himself, etc. It got repetitive pretty quickly. But the topic Giridharadas chose to write about really resonates with me and a lot of people in my generation. He puts into words what many of us feel, even if we haven’t identified it yet. It’s a feeling of unfairness and that the deck’s already stacked against us. That most of the people who purport to be helping are just preforming altruism instead of doing something meaningful. We were told that the best way to change the system is to work from within it, but it’s becoming more and more clear that by working for those institutions we’re just continuing to prop up the powerful.Really, I think I would have loved this as an essay. He could have used these personal examples more concisely to make his points. I know I’m part of the target audience for this work. I’m young(ish), my disillusionment with the state of the country is growing, I’m receptive to these ideas, even if I haven’t fully embraced them yet, and I’ve been fooled in the past by the very tactics that these ‘socially-conscious’ companies have deployed in the book. But still I struggled here. I’ll probably go watch some of his other interviews to build on these ideas more, but as for the book itself, I don't think it was my ideal medium. Maybe the audiobook would have been a better fit....more

title: The Penelopiad
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I will always be drawn to stories like this, reimaginings of legends we’ve all heard before. Ones that don’t feature the heroes we’re accustomed to foI will always be drawn to stories like this, reimaginings of legends we’ve all heard before. Ones that don’t feature the heroes we’re accustomed to focusing on, but the people who occupy the margins, the forgotten. Women have traditionally been relegated to these positions, their accomplishments flattened and swept away. So many of these narratives have been formative in our culture, to a point where we may not even be able to recognize them as anything but expected. It’s important when considering the source material, though, that we don’t take those surviving versions as the ‘original’ ones. It’s simply the one that had been written down and altered along the way, to fit within the storyteller’s own perspectives and worldview.The story of Penelope is not the story of Odysseus. It never really was. If you’re examining texts from thousands of years ago, there’s plenty to find objectionable. In The Penelopiad, Margaret Atwood strikes a smart balance between historical context and modern morality. She doesn’t pontificate for the reader, pointing out how slavery is wrong or forced marriages are detrimental; this much is implied. But she lets us consider a person’s legacy, what is remembered and what is forgotten. Is there an amount of good deeds that can expunge the bad ones? This is applied to all characters, not just the highborn men. Penelope has the luxury of looking back on her own reputation and image long after her death in order to teach something to the reader. What you take away from this tale may be indicative.Though women such as Penelope and her mostly nameless maids are able to express themselves as three-dimensional characters, this is not the case for all women present. Helen is spoken of with disdain for being “puffed up with vanity” and “ambitious”. The men are allowed to trot their accomplishments out, even expected to, but because Helen is beautiful and smart, she must also be calculating and vindictive. For the all of the humanization Atwood grants Penelope, I wish she would extend the same courtesy to Helen. Even if Helen was as callous as she’s made out to be, with “selfishness and her deranged lust”, how is it she who shoulders the blame? What about the men who commodify women to the extent that they only can see themselves as an object to be valued or discarded based on how much those same men want to fuck them? For all the retellings of the The Odyssey, are there any who take up Helen’s cause? If you find one, let me know, because I haven’t stumbled upon it. While Madeline Miller’s The Song of Achilles allows Briseis some agency during the Trojan War, and Penelope gets to narrate her own life in The Penelopiad, there’s little sympathy for her older cousin. Perhaps she’s hard to empathize with, seen as too privileged to have any real problems. Or maybe it feels like we’ve already heard her story through the Odyssey—the face that launched a thousand ships, and all that. But is that actually her story, or is she simply a convenient pawn in the service of the egos of men? There’s nothing like blaming a generational war on a young woman for simply *checks notes* existing while pretty. I enjoyed this book on the whole. The interludes with the maidens made it almost seem like a play. I think those chapters would extend really well to the stage. Atwood writes along familiar plot lines in a more modern and less epic fashion than The Odyssey, but still in a way that doesn’t become too dated over time. More of these types of works, please!...more

title: Miracle Creek
author: Kim, Angie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Whew, this one was quite a ride! I love a good unreliable narrator, and this book had plenty of those. If I was ever worried that a courtroom drama woWhew, this one was quite a ride! I love a good unreliable narrator, and this book had plenty of those. If I was ever worried that a courtroom drama wouldn't have enough action in it, that fear was quashed in the very first chapter.The Incident, as it's called, is a truly brutal event. It's painstakingly told from numerous points of view and may cause the reader to physically cringe, but it's the center of a complicated blame-game where almost everyone is either holding back or outright lying. These exclusions lead to even more tragedy and conflict, where by the end multiple parties share varying amounts of culpability.We also get a raw and vulnerable look at what it's like to care for a special needs child day-to-day. Even as the characters make mistakes in their parenting, you can't help but feel a great amount of empathy for them. And as much as anything else, this is a story about one family's immigration. Their complicated dynamic after uprooting themselves and having to readjust to a completely new set of social and cultural rules...I can hardly fathom going through something so difficult.Angie Kim really did an exceptional job covering so many distinct perspectives and story lines at once. And near the end, the book really had me exactly where it wanted me!*Thanks to Farrar, Straus and Giroux & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

title: Recursion
author: Crouch, Blake*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It seems like it would be exhausting to live inside Blake Crouch's head. The just pure scale of his last book, Dark Matter, and now Recursion, are dauIt seems like it would be exhausting to live inside Blake Crouch's head. The just pure scale of his last book, Dark Matter, and now Recursion, are daunting to consider, let alone be the one to map out and write. At just past the midpoint of each of his books I have stopped, took a breather and had the same thought: "How the fuck is he going to get himself out of this one?"But he always does, or his characters do. If I was responsible for writing the conclusions for his books I would have probably ended them with 'and then everyone died and everything was terrible byeeeee.' During his latest AMA, Crouch disclosed he was passing off a lot of the creative input for Recursion's upcoming Shonda Rhimes adaptation on Netflix because the book had "kicked [his] ass". I can only imagine. Reading the book kicked my ass, but in the best way.What starts as a story about memory quickly evolves into something else entirely. It's a commentary on technology and man's future. It's a story about regrets. It's dense, but digestible. That's one of my favorite things about Crouch as a writer, there's so much actual science built into the foundation of his science-fiction, but you don't have to have much of a grasp on those concepts before diving into the narrative. I never felt like I was missing something important, despite getting a C in high school physics. He writes approachable sci-fi that doesn't skimp on story.This is one of those books that will follow you around. I'm immensely excited to see the adaptation, but I love that we get the opportunity to read it first. A top tier book for me this year, I definitely recommend Recursion to anyone who hasn't yet put it on their TBR list!...more

title: The Last Widow        (Will Trent, #9)
author: Slaughter, Karin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I would like to apologize to the other two books I’m currently reading because I wasn’t able to pick up anything else until I finished The Last Widow.I would like to apologize to the other two books I’m currently reading because I wasn’t able to pick up anything else until I finished The Last Widow.(view spoiler)[I’ve also gotta hand it to Karin Slaughter with this one, because I wasn’t expecting this from her Will Trent series at all. It starts like a lot of her books do: a woman living and minding her own business until BAM a psychotic monster comes barreling into her life and kidnaps (murders/rapes/etc) her. And like a lot of Slaughter’s Grant County or Trent series, poor Sara Linton and Will are just always caught in the middle of the action. I mean, I know they both have baggage, but how have they gone through 7 books together, hostage situations, several totaled BMWs, 3 dogs, a dangerous ex-girlfriend—buuuut he still hasn’t moved in with her?? Communication needs to happen all the time, not just during life and death situations.Anyways, when the “anti-government” assailants were first being introduced, I thought Slaughter was going to just dance around the fact they’re violent nationalists, white supremacists, right-wing extremists, fucking NAZIS, or all of the above. But I was totally off base, and she really didn’t pull any punches, as per usual. There’s so much background information that we’re given, by way of Faith Mitchell as an audience surrogate primarily. We’re walked through exactly what these organizations are, who they are, why they are growing, what the government’s [sometimes lack of] response is and more. The most important piece, both to the storyline and in the real-life mirrors of it, are specifically who is being targeted for recruitment. Military, police, angry young white men. Nothing is left out for the sake of the reader’s comfort level with it . And my god, the story is gripping. The point of view bounces between Will, Faith and Sara, which is good because during most of the events they’re separated from each other. The initial action sequence, though, does have some overlap and I found the rehashing of what just happened kind of tedious. Even with the three perspectives, it was still hard to guess what would happen next. I found it extremely difficult to tear myself away from the book up until literally the last page. There’s so much covered that I am actually in awe of Slaughter’s research and sources for this one story. The ending is high energy, and isn’t really resolved until the end of the last chapter. Even so, I’m sure the ramifications of everything that happened will be echoing into the following installment(s).The radicalized men, weaponization of religion, cult mindset and all the big points of conflict are handled really well. The author understands the scope of these issues. What I’m still bothered by is the smaller, interpersonal conflicts, primarily between the women. Faith will not stop negging herself and comparing her body to other women’s. On one page she shoots down a guy interested in her, but then on the very next page speculates about giving him a blow job. Sara brings up Angie in her internal monologue so many times, and basically creates a pro/con chart of their respective body parts all while being held hostage. Angie isn’t even in the freaking book, Sara. They’re portrayed as these smart, kick-ass, self-assured women only until there’s a ‘threatening’ woman or potential love interest in the room and it just kills me every time. Like wtf is this:“Objectively, Sara could say that she had better breasts than Angie, but that was like saying that two Hershey’s Kisses looked better on an ironing board.”The other issue I was conflicted about was the way we’re meant to interpret Gwen. She’s an adult woman who has been abused since childhood, was used as a walking womb for her entire adulthood, and then eventually ends up being more than complicit in multiple murders, including her own children. Sara describes her as “worse than an abuser”, and I struggle with that. It feels like as a society, especially women, are harder on the women who know about abuse and do nothing than the men who perpetrate it. I think of it as a Serena Joy complex. Slaughter is aware of it too, because she points it out in the Epilogue when newscasters are blaming Michelle for her role in the massacre whilst be tortured. I think Gwen is responsible for her own choices, but why is she more culpable than the men who are making most of the decisions in the first place? (hide spoiler)]This book is enthralling and thought-provoking. I hid the entire  under spoilers, so if you haven’t read it before reading this, go pick it up!...more

What a hideous, hideous song."During Part 1, Siwar alternating between flashbacks as herself in Amman, Jordan and current three-year-old Wyatt in Seattle. I loved her instinctual reactions to both Western culture and the idiosyncrasies in the life of a toddler. The second part almost feels like a sequel to the first part, with Siwar's consciousness being the connecting factor. There's a struggle for control during the majority of Part 2 between Siwar and her now much older host, Wyatt. The second part also focuses more on the mystery of who killed Siwar 25 years prior. You're kept guessing even when you feel like you've figured it out! title: Daisy Jones & The Six
author: Reid, Taylor Jenkins*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So much hype for this book. So many people adored it that I ended up putting it off for a bit until I could devote my undivided attention to it.In manSo much hype for this book. So many people adored it that I ended up putting it off for a bit until I could devote my undivided attention to it.In many ways Daisy Jones & The Six is straightforward plot-wise. Before starting you can surmise that it's going to be a book about a band falling apart. So around halfway through I was afraid I wasn't going to love it the way others have and thought maybe it was too predictable. This was one of those times I'm glad I was very wrong. I knew I was invested in the characters when I started having mini-arguments in my head about which of them was right and wrong in a scene. Yes, the band breaks up, but there's so much else going on that it feels like a secondary concern. Some of the revelations are just so well executed that I had to put the book down for a moment to absorb them. The interviews are quite different from what I'm used to in a novel, but I really enjoyed the structure. Taylor Jenkins Reid able to handle difficult topics with just the right amount of sensitivity and honesty. The characters revealed things about themselves that I don't think would have come across as well in a traditional third or first person perspective. You can tell so much about people by the way they tell the same story. The style makes me want to check out the audiobook after I finish with the print copy. I think I might wait a bit before returning to Daisy Jones, but I will definitely be back. (Additionally, I love that Jenkins Reid was inspired in part by Fleetwood Mac. I was definitely getting some Stevie Knicks vibes.)...more

title: The Gilded Wolves        (The Gilded Wolves, #1)
author: Chokshi, Roshani*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** There's a lot going on with this one. At times I felt like I was missing several background chapters or passages of exposition, beca**spoiler alert** There's a lot going on with this one. At times I felt like I was missing several background chapters or passages of exposition, because it leaps around so much. You eventually can catch up, but there's some gaps and holes never really addressed and it's easier to just not think too much about it.The setting is very atmospheric. Because the plot is focused around 'forged' objects, there's a lot of detail put into their descriptions. Sometimes the objects act as a work-around if the story needs some way to secretly record conversations or replace other tools of modern convenience. The characters are also given complicated back stories that are all very tragic, but somehow still a bit thin? Tristan and Severin's, especially, is bizarre and never quite explained enough for me. But on the characters...there's parts I liked. Zofia's place on the spectrum is never directly named, but it's portrayed pretty well. Hypnos and Enrique's mixed-race ancestry in industrial France is a nice break from the presumed homogenous population. Laila's origins and abilities are really interesting and original to me. You could tell right away there was something up with Tristian, though, since he's the only one of the core five without a POV chapter--even Hypnos has one at the end. But, ugh, Severin. He's the worst. I couldn't stand him. He's arrogant, entitled, controlling and grating. The way he orders around his friends, whom he considers family, talks down to Tristan and Hypnos, smashes things Enrique cares about (??) and acts possessive of Laila just made me root against him even though he's supposed to be the main protagonist. He also is the worst offender of the other two major problems I had with the characters: obnoxious amounts of sarcasm and forcing a romance on characters just for the sake of it. Also nOT TELLING ANYONE ELSE YOUR PLANS WHY DOES EVERYONE DO THIS IN BOOKS?!?!And apparently out of a group of people with Poirot-on-steroids levels of deduction, he's also the one who gets to smirk and smugly say the answer to a puzzle before everyone else. Can you tell he bothers me??? But I refuse to let him ruin the good parts! The concept of forging and artifacts from lost cultures with hidden capabilities is a really cool one. The author also acknowledges the part colonialism played in acquiring them, as well as oppression and theft of culture. I feel like those interested in science and history will like this book. I thought the golden ratio and Fermat/hexagons were worked into the storyline in a really clever way. Some of the expressions and language clearly aren't era-specific, but since it's fantasy I'll give it a pass on that. I read this as a stand alone, but since it seems set up for a sequel, who knows? If there's a follow-up I'll read that one as well and see if it changes any of my critiques. Probably won't make me like Severin any more, though....more

title: Perfect Crime        (D.I. Callanach, #5)
author: Fields, Helen Sarah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** I went into this not knowing it was the fifth in a series, so I don't have the same long-standing relationship with the characters a**spoiler alert** I went into this not knowing it was the fifth in a series, so I don't have the same long-standing relationship with the characters as others who have read the previous books. There is a bit of exposition in the first few chapters to get you up to speed, but it's somewhat abrupt and there's a lot of plot holdover that you're expected to swallow if you're just jumping in. In hindsight I would have started at book 1, but it didn't make the experience impossible to deal with.More than just past events, there's established character relationships that, for me, didn't really come together. Luc and Ava's relationship makes zero sense to me. She's his boss, but he is incredibly condescending, controlling and at times creepy to her. Some of their interactions are too inappropriate to be believable for even a workplace romance, so as a reader to be asked to believe they're not romantically involved, but just have a really close friendship, is too much. Maybe they earned this in the previous books, but there was no payoff with them as a standalone.Luc isn't the only one who is weirdly territorial about his boss. Apparently another officer and a witness just can't help themselves and immediately have to try to disrupt a working relationship with her and act on their attraction to her. Between the two cops white-knighting for her favor and the doctor hitting on her mid-interview...there's a lot of below the surface misogyny to take in. And Ava chides herself for "giving off signals" to these men--No girl! Don't say that!As for the murders and premise itself, I thought it was a really interesting idea. A killer targeting people who had failed suicide attempts like a bitter grim reaper--very intriguing! I liked how there were entire chapters devoted to going into the mindset of the suicidal victims before they died. You really get to see them as people instead of as just bodies waiting to be discovered. And the psychological unravel of the killer is somethingI definitely didn't see coming. I liked it on the whole, but the investigative angle more so than the interpersonal conflict.*Thanks to Avon Books U.K. & Netgalley for an advance copy!...more

You can tell multiple people are involved just by the fact that you're told who the baddie is right off the bat. And oof was Ashley a hot mess of a character. He's a perfect liar, sociopath, but loves his brother and also kind of loves Darby? Seriously? What was "You could have been my girlfriend, Darby!" supposed to accomplish? It feels like the trope where an author has to make sure the audience knows the young, female protagonist is desirable. It just felt like too much. And the Darby as the Hero theme was also laid on waaaay too thickly. I mean, she kind of abandoned the kid in a cold car for hours. Since the net result was nearly everyone dying, would it have been worse than her just telling the room all at once initially? And so many of her interactions with Ashley were bizarre. I don't think a sudden burst of adrenaline would help if you're being suffocated like she was in the bathroom. The story would have benefited if the multiple perspectives were dialed down a bit. title: The Binding
author: Collins, Bridget*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I absolutely love this premise. Book binding as a way to alter/remove someone's memories is so bizarrely wonderful that only someone submerged in bookI absolutely love this premise. Book binding as a way to alter/remove someone's memories is so bizarrely wonderful that only someone submerged in books and familiar with the publishing process would come up with it. I loved the way Collins went beyond the obvious results of this technique's existence to include its commodification, manipulation and the really seedy underbelly of it all. The preface at the beginning by the author explains that she got into book binding and the idea for this story grew from that, and her expertise in the subject matter really shows.It started off a little strangely for me, I'll admit. I found Emmett Farmer's family unnaturally cruel. Cruelty is a theme for a good number of characters introduced later on as well. Some of the allusions to the mystery surrounding his circumstances felt a bit heavy-handed, but it makes more sense later on. Both the reader and the narrator are kept in the dark until the second part of the book. Part III is told from another character's point of view, but is a case of dramatic irony--where the audience knows something the character doesn't. It makes some of the events that happen to or around him even more gut-wrenching.Part II is a departure from the first and third, jumping back to the events predating those we'd been following. I don't want to spoil anything, but I will say that it reads somewhat like its own story within the story, which fits nicely with the themes of the book. There's no real fantasy or magic in Part II, but there's family discord, betrayal and a love story. As a person who frequently eye-rolls at romance plots, I have to say this one is really well-earned. And it's crucial to the plot, so the extended detour from the other storyline isn't for nothing.Since book binding isn't actually some sort of dark magic (no matter how much I would like it to be), it might be hard to really understand what the characters stand to lose when agreeing to be bound. The part that disturbed me was the lack of ownership over your own memories and life when completely at the mercy of a binder. What of ourselves do we have the right to? If not memories, then what about our life stories? Our images and data? Our DNA? I think there's more modern and practical applications to this idea than one world originally believe.I think of Henrietta Lacks who had her cells used without her knowledge by pharmaceutical companies for major profit and progress. Or Prince who didn't want to be turned into a hologram...then was at the Super Bowl. Facebook collecting user data and selling it. Adaptions and biopics that don't stay true to their subjects. 23&me holding our DNA and family history for their own purposes. There's seemingly no end to the comparisons.Real-life scaries aside, this was a lovely book that surpassed my expectations. I'll be think for a while, and what else can you really want from a good story?On the cover:This is one of the nicest ARCs I've received; it doesn't look like a proof, it looks like an upscale trade paperback. You can tell that the author and publisher put a lot of care and love into the production. I was curious to see what the finished copy would look like, so I checked its hashtag on Instagram. And oh my God--they're BEAUTIFUL. I think there's a few different editions floating around, but they all have the same ornate gilded lettering and overall design both on the dust-jacket AND on the actual hard cover. 10/10 A++ love it!!*Thank you to William Morrow & Goodreads for an advance copy!...more

There was a murder mystery wraAfter getting a sneak-peak at the first 5 chapters a few months ago, I was really excited to see how this one unfolded. There was a murder mystery wrapped up in a magical matriarchy--sounds great to me!I think my first issue was with Keralie, the master thief & heroine that gets roped into the royal drama. She is unnaturally flippant about everything and it started to grate on me. She's always smirking and rattling off 'clever' one-liners in a way that I found really annoying. Any point where we're supposed to empathize with her struggles or trauma is immediately undercut by her own attitude. I just don't care for this type of character. I don't think it adds anything of value and it just feels like the author trying to drive home how 'cool' or 'relatable' we're supposed to find her. It happens with male characters too, and I hate it in them as well.The other thing that I didn't care for was what I've come to refer to as The Vibranium Solution. I see it more in pseudo-scientific fantasy stories like this one. Like how in Black Panther Vibranium is used to MacGyver new inconceivable technology with no real coherent explanation, the kingdom of Eonia has nearly magical capabilities, but is explained away as "science", while their neighboring kingdoms are still using horses as their main mode of transportation. I think when authors try to retain both old societal and cultural structures that don't really exist anymore, while also taking advantage of new science-fiction possibilities (with a sprinkle of magic), there's a high chance of this occurring. (view spoiler)[The example that most bothered me was when a technology that records memories can suddenly, seemingly for plot reasons, record someone's intentions and plans in vivid imagery as well. This is totally possible, but nobody had ever considered doing it before. And then later it can control your mind for similar ~*pLoT*~ reasons. I don't have a problem buying into new worlds and realities, but I hate when the rules change mid-play. It feels lazy. (hide spoiler)]The murder mystery portion, though, thought was compelling enough. I went into Part 4 (of 4) with vague suspicions, but no real idea who it was. I was wrong in about every possible way, but the ending was so out of left field that I don't know who could have accurately come up with it. I didn't love the conclusion of it all to be honest. It's not bad, it's just kind of weird and nonsensical.It was fine. I wish I liked it more, but for me it didn't live up to the concept....more

review: Despite this being my first Harlan Coben novel, I've been waiting to dive into it for quite a while! The cover was so striking and cool that I was surDespite this being my first Harlan Coben novel, I've been waiting to dive into it for quite a while! The cover was so striking and cool that I was surprised to find out he's an established author of thriller/suspense books. Maybe I'm generalizing too much, but there's a certain 'look' to a lot of the thriller/mystery/suspense genre books that I see perched at the front of bookstores and plastered all over New Releases banners online. The graphic orange & black spiral seemed more artistic than the typical picture of a girl with half her face/body obscured in an ominous fashion that I'm used to. Not to trample all over the cliches about covers, but I just really liked this one for some reason. ANYWAYS--I found this to be a really engaging book. You can tell Coben is a pro; it's one of the best paced suspense books I've read in a while. There's a subtle, but steady urgency throughout that keeps you reading, but you can still take breaks as you need them, then pick back up without preamble. Another thing I appreciated was the lack of gratuitous violence, especially against women. The story may kick off with a missing girl, but the mystery evolves into much more than that. I love Karin Slaughter's books, but my god are they brutal. I always feel like I have to be careful recommending books like hers because of what they could trigger in people. Coben also does an excellent job at juggling a bunch of different plot points while keeping up with some topical issues. It's a fully fleshed out story that doesn't feel overcrowded.I will say that after reading posts in r/menwritingwomen, I've found it easier see passages or phrasing that men are more likely to use. Elena repeatedly describing herself as "chubby", "round middle-aged", "pudgy", "squat", etc. is just so unnecessary. Will male brains just EXPLODE if it isn't mentioned how attractive or unattractive a woman is every 30 pages or something? Women aren't constantly contemplating their own fuckability; society does that enough for them. Plus, Elena is a badass ex-fed PI who's entire romantic history is just sprawled out for seemingly no real purpose besides making her...what, tragic? Ugh, whatever. /finI did like the story on the whole, though. I plan to pick up some of Mr. Coben's previous works to compare this to!...more

title: The Light Years
author: Rush, Chris*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I knew I liked Chris Rush from the first chapter. We're introduced to him as a child who appears to be more certain of who he is than most adults I'veI knew I liked Chris Rush from the first chapter. We're introduced to him as a child who appears to be more certain of who he is than most adults I've met. As Rush recounts his childhood into adolescence and then young adulthood, the environment around him, people he encounters, the era he lives in, all attempt to forge him into a different person. His resilience is just amazing to me. After living what feels like several lifetimes worth in a decade, I'm left completely in awe.The highs and lows reading of this memoir mimic the drug-fueled jaunts of the author. He delivers his testaments with a measured amount of nonchalance, as if they were typical childhood milestones. Though he recalls layered enthusiasm for these substances at the time, with the benefit of hindsight we get to really see the absurdity of the predicaments he found himself in due to drug use. It's euphoric, but devastating. And with a lot of stories of people with fucked up childhoods, there's the adults that failed them. Usually repeatedly, immensely and often. Even though he was able to thrive well enough to write a book in the end, it was not an easy or necessary journey. Honestly, I don't know how he survived. And many in similar positions don't. It feels unfair and despite getting many good stories out of it, it's a gut-punch to think about. One of the most astounding things is that Rush doesn't seem angry much at all, at any point. Maybe he's worked through these feelings or he just doesn't have the rage that others might. I don't think I'd have the same temperament if I had undergone a fraction of what he did.I loved this memoir. It's melancholic and profound and I highly recommend it!*Thanks to Goodreads, Netgalley & Farrar, Straus and Giroux for advance copies!...more
