review: After delving into multiple new (to me) fantasy books this year, I think this is the best launch of a series I've read so far! The characters were forAfter delving into multiple new (to me) fantasy books this year, I think this is the best launch of a series I've read so far! The characters were formidable, but flawed, so nobody was over-powered or cartoonishly sinister. The land of Elfhame as well as the Faerie Court and people that make it up, are lavish and enchanting. The dark undercurrent of their lives of leisure and magic help emphasize that all the splendor laid before us only comes at a significant cost.As much as there's a focus on the mystical and fantastical throughout, I also really enjoyed the complex relationships the characters had with each other. The three Duarte sisters, who had all gone through the same traumatic event, couldn't have been more different from one another. The testing of family bonds between them and their adopted father and brother vs the dynamic between the royal children were interesting to compare. What makes someone a parent? A sibling? Is it blood or does that have anything to do with it? And stemming from these questions is the over-arching one: is who you are as a person pre-determined or is it a result of the environment you were exposed to? Nature vs nurture. At least so far, we haven't been given an answer.I wasn't expecting a YA fantasy novel to be so philosophical, but maybe I'm not giving either genre enough credit. I can't wait to see how these questions are expanded on in the two additional books in the series, as well as the novella that supposedly follows this one in succession (if I can get my library to acquire it!) Though not quite a cliffhanger, the challenge presented by the King at the end is the perfect one to propel us forward into The Wicked King.Now that you got what you wanted, what are you going to do with it? Hopefully it was all worth it, Jude....more

I liked that this is a thriller that doesn't kill/disappear someone in the first couple chapters; the tension feels like it's been earned. title: The Testaments        (The Handmaid's Tale, #2)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was sure I would be just be one of many in the chorus of positive s for Margaret Atwood’s record-breaking follow-up to The Handmaid's Tale. ThI was sure I would be just be one of many in the chorus of positive s for Margaret Atwood’s record-breaking follow-up to The Handmaid's Tale. The early critic s seemed glowing and widespread, so I was really surprised to see so many Goodreads users who I follow and think highly of not really connect with the story at all. Some of the most liked s of the novel just totally panned it, which happens, but still made me pause and wonder if my interpretation was unrefined in some way.But after finishing The Testaments and mulling it over some, I think I just disagree. One of the biggest complaints about unplanned sequels are that they’re unnecessary, and that’s shown up a lot in the negative reactions. Maybe from a story-telling perspective, The Handmaid’s Tale works best as a stand-alone. That’s not why Atwood wrote it, though. She wrote it as a reaction to the world around her at the time she was experiencing it. There are countless interviews with her where she’s expressed similar notions about our current day ordeals, and that’s what has pushed her towards writing a follow-up. It’s some of the same reasons why a Handmaid’s Tale TV show found such success in the first place. It’s easy to look at this as a cash grab, but they’re both parallel responses to an alarming shift in authoritarian inclinations and populist reactions.One of the criticisms I didn’t really understand was that it’s very “YA”. I mean, there’s two perspectives from people under 25, so I guess that’s technically correct? But this feels like a dig, as if there’s something less respectable about writing for a young adult audience. I just think that’s bullshit. I’ve seen more risk-taking by YA authors than in nearly every other genre. Historically and in modernity, young people are not just joining revolutions, they’re leading them. If some current YA heroines and plot lines feel similar to Atwood’s, could it be that they’ve simply drawn inspiration from her? I like that she’s expanded beyond June’s viewpoint; there’s more than one way to suffer, to resist.Most have at least appreciated Aunt Lydia’s arc here. And maybe that’s because she’s already an established character that we’ve gotten a lot of face-time with, but not a lot of background on. I think it’s a little more than that, though. We haven’t seen much about women that are beyond “child bearing years” in Gilead. Even Serena Joy isn’t more than mid to early 40s in the novel, despite not being able to have children. How did Lydia climb her way to near the top of a hierarchy that has no discernible use for women her age? We’ve seen Aunts and Marthas, but we haven’t seen as them yet. Similarly to how young girls have been paraded around Gilead, but we have no way of knowing what that life is. We don’t know what it’s like as a child to escape an tyrannical regime. These are valuable insights. If The Handmaid’s Tale is a resource for women 25-40 caught in an oppressive society, then The Testaments can provide for women and girls at different stages of their lives.I also appreciate Atwood for not attempting to “subvert our expectations”. She isn’t trying to compete with the TV show, and she’s not pretending it doesn’t exist. That’s a really difficult balancing act, and she pulls it off. She’s able to write without contradicting or accommodating the show’s narrative, and maybe that’s not what everyone wanted. But I think that she’s got the right idea here to be in tandem with its producers. If there’s an idea that they each want to land with readers/viewers, and it’s the same idea, then their respective audiences will have a lot of overlap. In order to pull off some ‘big plot twists’ she’d have to veer off course, and I think that would take away from her overarching message.Maybe The Handmaid’s Tale was enough for you, and that’s fine. But the world is different from how it was, and some of us need more. The first installment gave us a look at how a society can fall and what the ramifications of that look like. What happens, though, when you’re already in the thick of it? How can you stop it; how can you keep it from getting worse? How can you make it better? That’s what’s at stake here and Atwood understands it, even if it isn’t ~*LiTeRaRy~*~ in the way we’ve come to expect. If this book doesn’t do much for you, maybe you’re not the intended audience. For me it was equal parts harrowing, helpful & hopeful, and the necessary companion piece to The Handmaid’s Tale....more

review: This was such a beautiful novel. It's one of those that stays with you for a long time after you've finished it. Celeste Ng is an exceptional story teThis was such a beautiful novel. It's one of those that stays with you for a long time after you've finished it. Celeste Ng is an exceptional story teller; she doesn't tell us who her characters are or even show us, but is able to get them to reveal their own true selves. Their choices never feel contrived or out of left field--they're exactly what should be expected based off of who they are as people, but without being predictable. They're the most human fictional characters I've read in a long time.Since I read this after they announced the mini series in production, I got to imagine Kerry Washington as Mia and Reese Witherspoon as Elena. I'm excited to see their interpretations of these complex women, and I have high hopes for them.I went to college in Ohio, where the student body was over 80% white and upper-middle class was tiered based on your family's vacations and what car you were bought as a teenager. There were privileged students from privileged families all over the midwest & US, including the wealthy suburbs of Cleveland, which very much resembled the ones depicted in Little Fires Everywhere. I recognized the people, language and culture of the Shaker Heights community in so many of my friends, family and even myself. I've heard things like "I would never get myself into that situation in the first place." more times than I can count. I feel different after reading this book. For people who won't end up reading it, I hope that the tv show will reach them. I think the self-reflection that this story inspires may be able to shift some heartland hearts and minds. The question is: What are we going to do about it?...more

review: I ended up liking this book more by the end than I did about halfway through. It felt like it was going to be a bunch of stereotypical characters doinI ended up liking this book more by the end than I did about halfway through. It felt like it was going to be a bunch of stereotypical characters doing the same stereotypical things, but I was pleasantly surprised by the way it turned out.The characters on the whole ended up being much more layered than they appeared to be. The story is told in both present day and flashbacks from two different viewpoints: Diana the Mother-in-Law and Lucy her daughter-in-law. Occasionally I got thrown off because there were time jumps in the middle of chapters not made explicitly clear, but it wasn't too bad.I do think the author gave much more attention to fleshing out the female characters than the male ones. At times the men in the story seem like sitcom versions of men, which kept me from really being invested in them.Also, throughout the book I was having trouble deciding if Lucy was supposed to be a parody of a "woke" person or actually socially conscious. I only bring this up because of the many times she declares her self a feminist, but then is completely blown away by her husband doing basic household chores or child rearing. Like, yeah, if you're 8 months pregnant and feeling sick your husband should be doing the laundry...and oh my god referring to him as 'menfolk'! Twice!! I feel like if I ever met Lucy she would drive me crazy.Besides that I enjoyed the pacing and the fact that we're kept in suspense until the very last dozen or so pages. You might suspect some earlier on, but there's enough held back to keep you on the edge of your seat!*Thanks to St. Martin's Press, Netgalley & Goodreads for advance copies!...more

title: Circe
author: Miller, Madeline*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved this book so much, I didn't want it to end. Greek mythology has always had great adventures and characters and monsters, but I never thought II loved this book so much, I didn't want it to end. Greek mythology has always had great adventures and characters and monsters, but I never thought I could be invested in one character so much. Circe is so...not exactly relatable, but while she might be living the eternal life of an actual Goddess, she struggles in such a human way that you almost forget she's the daughter of the literal sun.I think some older works, especially ones written in grand epics and dense language, can be challenging to appreciate the story through the writing. The Gods and mortals that appear in Greek mythology are flawed; they can be bitter or lustful or vain or vengeful, among other things. But some are limited to one or two traits and can lose their nuance. Madeline Miller is able to add shading and depth to the outlines of these characters in a really beautiful way. Her writing is gorgeous and rich, completely living up to the legacy of the source material.“You can teach a viper to eat from your hands, but you cannot take away how much it likes to bite.”I also love how this book redefined the hero's journey by taking a female character, who may typically have been merely scenery or 'thing to be conquered', and made her the center of her own adventure. She does come into contact with men on their own quests, but they are never the focus. Instead, they are the supporting aspects to her personal epic.Circe challenges the ‘official’ versions of their tales as well as the presumed ‘heroes’ that star in them. She is constantly questioning the powerful, from mortal men who prey on those presumed inferior, up to the Gods and Titans themselves.Plus, she's a witch. And witches are super cool. And even if you recognize names and parts of stories you've heard before throughout the book, you probably haven't gotten the full story....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Both stunning and crushing. Speak was such an impactful moment for me when my 9th grade English teacher assigned it to our class. This is the perfect Both stunning and crushing. Speak was such an impactful moment for me when my 9th grade English teacher assigned it to our class. This is the perfect point in time for Laurie Halse Anderson to release a follow-up.Part 1 felt like a peek behind the curtain at what made the person who made the original novel. I liked the detour to Denmark; it made me want to call up my Danish grandmother. Though she loves her family, Laurie's words and memories were hard to read. Parents poorly equipped to deal with their own lives are even more poorly equipped to deal with children's.Parts 2 & 3 were emotional. They were empowering. They were difficult. They were necessary. Just go read Shout for yourself. I can't paraphrase a movement."This is the story of a girl who lost her voice and wrote herself a new one."Speak, Laurie....more

title: Two Can Keep a Secret
author: McManus, Karen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'd been waiting for this one! Karen McManus really helped pull me out of my February slump with Two Can Keep A Secret. I was wondering if I'd just grI'd been waiting for this one! Karen McManus really helped pull me out of my February slump with Two Can Keep A Secret. I was wondering if I'd just grown tired of thrillers/mystery/suspense as a genre, but nope! I've just been waiting for a good one to come along.Right off the bat I felt a little nervous I wouldn't take to the characters based off of their exceedingly trendy names. They kind of have a dystopian-YA-trilogy vibe, but my fear was misplaced! Having names that stuck with you ("the one that sounds like a kind of tree", etc.) actually helped in the beginning with the many character name drops in rapid secession. I guess they're into unique names in Vermont? I'll buy it.The story is told from two perspectives, Ellery and Malcom, and feature several competing mysteries. You're left wondering how (or if) they all fit together and who's holding back what. Anyone who's a fan of Pretty Little Liars needs to get on this one ASAP. There's missing teenagers, a queen bee, *twinning*, an incompetent police force and even an Ezra! This book feels fresh while playing some of the old favorites--you won't be bored, I promise....more

review: Natasha Ngan has crafted a stunning, atmospheric world in Girls of Paper and Fire. From the landscapes and clans to the palace and castes to the beautNatasha Ngan has crafted a stunning, atmospheric world in Girls of Paper and Fire. From the landscapes and clans to the palace and castes to the beautiful clothes and food sourced across the Asia, she weaves a kingdom that's familiar, but completely magical. I was totally enthralled from the first chapter.It's a good sign when the end of a book leaves you saying "What's next? Is there more?!" I'm really hoping there's going to be a sequel. While the story is a complete one that stands on its own, I just neeeeed to get more Lei in my life. There's a cliffhanger that feels like a Marvel post-credits scene....so there has to be a follow-up, right?!?I also kept wanting to see the demons of the Steel and Moon castes illustrated in some way. Possibly as a graphic novel or animation? As much as I enjoyed imagining these great half-man-half-beasts sharing a world with humans, I feel like the right artist(s) could expand on Ngan's words and descriptions of characters....more

author: Jewell, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** I always feel like I'm missing something in Lisa Jewell's books that other people are picking up on. There's interesting plot, disti**spoiler alert** I always feel like I'm missing something in Lisa Jewell's books that other people are picking up on. There's interesting plot, distinct characters, good writing, etc...but they always fall a bit short for me. After this last one, I think I figured out what it was. They just don't have the suspense I want them to. It's like reading a mystery that you've already looked up the ending for, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. I just need to adjust my expectations going forward.Jewell really handled multiple perspectives quite well. There's a teenage girl with a mentally unstable parent, a teenage boy who's basically an incel and a horny, rudderless 20-something lusting after old married men. It took a while to get my bearings; there were a bunch of characters in close proximity, but with little connecting them besides that. Yes it came together in the end...I guess? Portions felt like Chekov's gun, especially with Joey and Tom. Why bring up green eyes so much? Or her dead mom? It's like I'm missing the last couple of chapters.But it was engaging! I just wasn't ever 'thrilled' while reading this 'thriller'....more

title: Sadie
author: Summers, Courtney*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Little girls don't stay little forever. They grow into strong women that return to destroy your world." - Kyle StephensI couldn't get that quote out "Little girls don't stay little forever. They grow into strong women that return to destroy your world." - Kyle StephensI couldn't get that quote out of my head while reading Sadie. Kyle Stephens was one of the over 200 young women to give victim impact statements at the trial of Larry Nassar, their former gymnastics trainer, and ultimately, a depraved sexual predator.Sadie is a girl with nothing left to lose. She’s never fully been able to live her life for herself, having had to care for her sister Mattie from a young age. But even when her sister is gone, she still can’t let go of that instinct to protect her. She’s exactly the person you would want on your side, but is also often the type to be taken for granted.The book alternates between Sadie’s perspective and True Crime podcaster West McCray’s attempt to follow the trail she’s left in her wake. There’s an overwhelming sense of helplessness in being a step or two behind Sadie as she barrels head-first into the search for what happened to her sister. The journey that Courtney Summers takes us on is devastating and enthralling. You, like McCray, won’t be able to pull yourself away until you find out what happened to Sadie?Something I noticed about people when they are presented with cases of sexual violence is that it typically prompts one of two reactions: either they are unable to face it or they are unable to look away from it. I don't know which one is worse, but one is clearly more advantageous for predators. Sure, some of us are drawn to ‘SVU-style’ stories and that might say something about our society’s need to witness gratuitous violence, but I do not accept that the opposite impulse is somehow more inherently ‘acceptable’. Ignoring something because it’s unpleasant just gives more opportunities for it to turn into a problem, and leaves the vulnerable members of your community even more so. Sadie is equal parts engrossing and painful. Courtney Summers has written a character that knows what's on the dark underside of the rock, and flips it over anyways. Then she makes us look it in the eye, acknowledge it. If you're searching for comfort or even peace, you won't find it here. But if you want truth, then Sadie has it for you.**I don't know what the different trigger warnings are, and other s have listed them all out for those interested. Just assume this novel has all of them.**...more

title: Calypso: Essays
author: Sedaris, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not knowing anything of David Sedaris going into Calypso, I was glad to discover how much I enjoyed listening to his stories. Truly, the delivery he gNot knowing anything of David Sedaris going into Calypso, I was glad to discover how much I enjoyed listening to his stories. Truly, the delivery he gives in the audiobook version is incredibly delightful and I don't think anyone else could have done it justice. I especially liked the recordings of live readings he'd done for certain chapters that intercut the others. I knew the name Sedaris sounded familiar, though, and in Googling him I found out his sister is Amy Sedaris from Second City. She's been on things like The Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt or as a guest & friend of Stephen Colbert's show. David uses his family as a major source in his writings, especially his sisters and father. Their dynamics make for one funny story after another, weaved in with some unexpected melancholy.It helps that the Sedaris family seems easy to laugh with, completely aware of their own shortcomings, but totally unbothered by them. Early on David discloses his sister's untimely death, and that colors the rest of the book, even in stories that don't reference her at all. There's a bit of regretful whimsy that he carries with him throughout, and even parts where he's buying pants the price of a car, he remains easy to connect with.I can see why this book was on all the best sellers lists last year, and I'm glad I waited to pick it up, if only because I probably wouldn't have listened to the audio recording otherwise. Humorous enough to laugh out loud a bunch and never too somber to not be lifted up by a well-placed quip, Sedaris just earned himself a new fan....more

title: On the Come Up
author: Thomas, Angie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Hate U Give is a tough act to follow, especially as a debut, but Angie Thomas really stepped up to meet the challenge. There's a bit of cross-overThe Hate U Give is a tough act to follow, especially as a debut, but Angie Thomas really stepped up to meet the challenge. There's a bit of cross-over between some of the issues both Starr and Bri deal with (assuming the worst of black kids, aggressive law enforcement, etc.), but Bri also struggles against poverty, drug dealers, gangs and sexism in hip-hop, on top of navigating 'normal' teen problems like heartbreak and ACT prep.Reading On the Come Up has just reaffirmed my belief that Thomas has an amazing ability to capture a moment in time in the life of a teenager. It reminds me of S.E. Hinton with The Outsiders in authenticity and honesty. There will be classrooms of kids reading her books decades from now, and hopefully they enjoy them more than I did Catcher in the Rye or The Old Man and the Sea. I think more than anything this author just really shines in crafting her characters. When an injustice happens, you feel Bri's righteous anger with her. You feel the same conflicting feelings for Aunt Pooh as her. You laugh when she jokes with her friends and you cry when she does in her brother's arms. And not to spoil anything, but when she eventually does Come Up, you rise with her. The cleverness and humor breaks up some of the serious moments and helps both readers and subjects of the story handle the heaviness of it all.I loved going through Bri's thought process while coming up with her lyrics. Angie Thomas displays her own talent here and gives insight into the creativity behind the words we end up hearing. It's really impressive.I can hear it now--what's that they're chanting? MOVIE MOVIE MOVIE MOVIE MOVIE I know it's only been out for a minute.......but pleeeEEEEEEEZE ANGIE, GIRL. And I know you had at least one person in mind for the tweet in the epilogue. I thought it would be Lil' Kim or J. Cole, but if it's someone else I neEEeEeed to know!Songs mentioned:Flashlight - Parliament [19]Kick in the Door - Notorious B.I.G [24]Illmatic (album) - Nas [25]A Tale of Two Citiez - J. title: Children of Virtue and Vengeance        (Legacy of Orïsha, #2)
author: Adeyemi, Tomi*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don’t really know what happened here. This series had such a promising start, there was so much hype and it just kind of...fizzled. This absolutely I don’t really know what happened here. This series had such a promising start, there was so much hype and it just kind of...fizzled. This absolutely breaks my heart to have to write, but three stars is the most generous I can be with Children of Virtue and Vengeance. Maybe there were signs of this outcome all along. The release date was repeatedly pushed back to almost two years after the publication of Children of Blood and Bone. The problem with having such a big gap between books is that you lose momentum; memories fade and people eventually lose interest. The whole thing felt rushed, very much like a first draft. I’m wondering if Tomi Adeyemi got wrapped up in picturing the world she created on the big screen. A lot of the dialogue felt like it was ripped from an amateur screenplay and any ‘action’ was more like stage direction than a narrative. It just pales in comparison to its predecessor.The characters don’t hold up either. They especially fall apart in the third act. Amari and Zélie are like parodies of themselves. Inan prefers to beg people to let him explain instead of actually, oh I don’t know, explaining what his plans are. The entire conflict could have been avoided in a 5 minute conversation, at multiple points in the story. They treat their family & friends like strangers and people they just met like a long-lost twin. I lost track of the amount of times that a person around Amari, Inan, Zélie or Tzain threatened to murder someone they (allegedly) loved only to be met by....*crickets*. Not one word of protest or acknowledgement. The entire thing was so bizarre.And I’m so tired of hearing about this fucking monarchy. It’s all bad—throw the entire royal family in the trash! All of the perspective characters, Amari, Zélie and Inan, have just taken up residence in their respective blind spots and refuse to come out. If I was rich enough to afford a new one, I would have pitched my Kindle at a wall. The romance—I don’t want to even get started on, but I will out of a misplaced sense of duty. I feel like Adeyemi was going for a Kylo-Rey type of relationship between Zélie and Inan. Simply put, it doesn’t land. And Tzain only appears when Amari needs her love interest present; otherwise he might as well not be in it at all.One of the most popular subs on Reddit is called “Am I The Asshole?” Users recount a situation and ask the community if they are the asshole in it. The possible responses are:  - YTA (You’re The Asshole) - NTA (Not The Asshole) - NAH (No Assholes Here) - ESH (Everyone Sucks Here)Basically in regards to just about all of the characters in this book, it’s a big ole’ ESH from me.I don’t want to end on such a negative note. I’m still invested enough in Orïsha to want to read the final installment. The world-building, the magic, all of it is so enchanting that I will trudge through bad character backsliding in order to continue exploring it. In those two years, I forgot how readable and consumable Tomi Adeyemi’s writing is. You rip through the pages desperate to get to the end, just like with her debut. I want to see more of the Tîtáns and Iyika. I want to know what happens to Zélie and her friends. But I also want the story to gain back some of the nuance and craftsmanship it had previously. I’m going to keep hopeful that like divîner magic, eventually it will return to us....more

title: Throne of Glass        (Throne of Glass, #1)
author: Maas, Sarah J.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm really into this series already. Having read some other s I was a little apprehensive, but most of the complaints levied didn't bother me. II'm really into this series already. Having read some other s I was a little apprehensive, but most of the complaints levied didn't bother me. It's a well-paced fantasy revolving around a young female assassin. What's not to like? I will concede that yes there's a bit of an Edward/Jacob vibe that's groan-inducing, but I just pretend like those parts don't exist and everything's fine!The book sets up the world of Throne of Glass really well for those that follow. I'm excited to see the rest of Erilea. Celaena seems formidable and capable enough to carry the series. Nehemia is great. Chaol is great. Dorian is the typical pompous prick we're supposed to initially dislike but then grow to love inexplicably. So, naturally he is the worst. There's several villains who live through to the end with major potential. Plus ancient magic, which is always fun.Biggest issue was that Celaena was almost unbelievably daft at times. The conclusions she reached after being presented with circumstances and suspects were just...dumb. It kind of suspended believability more than the magic and demons. Hopefully that lack of common sense is left behind for the next book. Can't wait to continue on!...more

title: The Kingdom of Copper        (The Daevabad Trilogy, #2)
author: Chakraborty, S.A.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I only read The City of Brass near the end of last year, but it took a minute to get back into The Kingdom of Copper until I read an in-depth summary I only read The City of Brass near the end of last year, but it took a minute to get back into The Kingdom of Copper until I read an in-depth summary of the previous novel. The prologue, kingdom descriptions and character backgrounds included in the book were also helpful, and I recommend anyone not immediately reading one after another in this trilogy to take the time to go over them. Reading on my Kindle has been a godsend since it saved me from having to flip back and forth between the glossary and the page. Just highlight the word and the definition comes right up!Once I was able to get my bearings, I fell right back into the dazzling world of Daevabad. While the majority takes place in the city itself, other more rural locations are explored too. Seeing how members of the same tribe spread out from each other physically had radically altered their own core philosophies added another element to the already incredibly intricate political climate in the realm. Ghassan is obviously one of the baddest of the bad guys in the series, but as far as Jobs I Definitely Wouldn't Ever Want go, being the King of Daevas is waaaaay up there on that list. One think I loved about S.A. Chakraborty's characters is that level of complexity runs through all of them. There's opposing views and ideologies between characters, yes, but they also are having the same battles within themselves. From Dara's prejudice against shafit with his feelings for Nahri, to Ali's devoutness verses loyalty to his family, or Nahri wanting to fight oppressors when the people who are oppressed seems to be constantly changing, they experience as much conflict internally as they do externally.Nahri, Ali & Dara also harbor a lot of anger and resentment. There's never any completely clean hands between them. It's hard to be frustrated with those three especially for very long because most of their choices, even when they're certifiably dumb, are simultaneously understandable. Can you be mad at someone for killing you when you killed them first? (Questions like these are part of why I will never give up fantasy) Their personal interactions imitate the larger scale disputes in the city, culminating in a heart-racing climax that drastically changes the future of the daevas.Everything I loved about the city of Daevabad in the first book is present in this one, and its raw brutality is mercifully broken up by moments of levity and humor. I don't know what I'm going to do while waiting for Empire of Gold to be released....more

title: The Fallen Architect
author: Belfoure, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Belfoure's strength in The Fallen Architect is his ability to vividly set a scene for the reader. It was easy to see what he was describing to me, espBelfoure's strength in The Fallen Architect is his ability to vividly set a scene for the reader. It was easy to see what he was describing to me, especially with structures and buildings. Throughout the book it felt as though I was sitting in the rooms as things were unfolding.What really held back this book for me was the meandering pace it takes through what should be a high stakes mystery. There's just a complete absence of any urgency, despite the main character having several imminent threats throughout the story. Despite the bang the book starts out on, it's a slow burn that really never comes to a full boil. The characters are also very British. I know this because I'm constantly told how British they are. How they Britishly speak and britishly drink and have British moods--seriously, is there a quota for number of times one must explicitly mention Britishness that British authors have to meet by law? I don't mean to just pick on this book, I've noticed it in several others I've read recently, but it's an interesting quirk I haven't seen really from authors of different countries. If you're interested in the location (London) or time period or subject matter (architecture & theatre), I think the story will have an extra enticing element. It was compelling enough for me to want to finish, but not read again. I'll probably pass it on to my cousin who majored in architecture to see what she thinks![I didn't really let this factor into my feelings on the whole with this book, because it could be just that I don't really know what's considered 'normal', but I found some of the terms and attitude towards other cultures, orientations, genders, etc. rather jarring. It's clearly reflective of the time period (early 1900s), but I guess I'm just unaccustomed to it. I think I'll try to read more books set 100+ years ago and see how they compare; I'd like to be able to tell when language of a time period is appropriate or not. For now I'll just assume it was!]*Second ever  of a book, which I won in a giveaway here*...more

title: Tweak: Growing Up On Methamphetamines
author: Sheff, Nic
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I like to finish most books, even if I end up heavily skimming sections, so that at least I know I'm getting the whole picture. I really tried with thI like to finish most books, even if I end up heavily skimming sections, so that at least I know I'm getting the whole picture. I really tried with this one. I wanted to read it initially after I found out the movie A Beautiful Boy was based off of the memoir of the same name as well as this one, which describe the same period of time from dueling points of view. It's a cool premise around a dark and difficult time in both of their lives. It feels wrong to a lot of us to criticize a testimony of someone's struggle with something like addiction so negatively, but I'm having a hard time finding positives that don't sound pandering. I appreciate Nic's honesty here, and I think the depiction of drug addiction may be useful to those struggling, but I did not get much out of this book. I tried to take a step back to figure out if there was some overarching reason why I didn't like this memoir at all, but I think that's the underlying point. I just don't think I like him that much. The Sheff's are just not a family I can see myself in. I don't have anything against them, but the way they speak and operate in the world is just not compatible with me personally. These feelings are completely divorced from the addiction and all that's associated with it as well. In fact, his struggles as an addict were the only part of him I empathized with. The specific things that rubbed me the wrong way aren't that relevant, but many of them are also part of his father's memoir, so I'm assuming it's part of their family dynamic. I have a feeling of impending dread every time I 'force' myself to start this book up again, so I've just called it quits. Good luck to the author and his family....more

title: Beautiful Boy: A Father's Journey Through His Son's Addiction
author: Sheff, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: God this memoir was such a real gut punch. Sometimes I felt completely on edge, waiting for the other shoe to drop.Because this is a story about drug God this memoir was such a real gut punch. Sometimes I felt completely on edge, waiting for the other shoe to drop.Because this is a story about drug addiction, I expected there to be relapses. What I couldn't really prepare for was the frequency of them and just how devastating they are each and every time. Even when I was less than halfway through the book, I still held out hope that Nic would be better each time he promised he would. Until I didn't. Which isn't any less sad, but is just becoming resigned to that sadness. I found myself really empathizing with the Sheff family throughout the years laid out in this book.I also felt myself becoming increasing angry, along with David, at Nic. He had such an extraordinary amount of privilege at every single point of his addiction that others could only dream of. David Sheff does touch on this a couple of times, but it makes me even sadder for those who can't afford to be shipped off to half a dozen luxury rehabs across the country on a moment's notice. Addiction doesn't discriminate, but treatment sure as hell does.I ended up skimming parts, unfortunately. He's very descriptive, but sometimes it's like he's just listing things. There's a lot of time spent going into great detail on the environment or weather or location, which can feel somewhat gratuitous. It's the most obvious when he's discussing movies, bands, books or things of that nature. He wants to make sure that the reader knows how interesting and cultured he and his son both are. I think it might just be his writing style, and it does contrast well with Nic's fall, but for me it's a bit too much....more

title: Boy Erased: A Memoir
author: Conley, Garrard*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** I wanted to read this before I saw the movie, though I've heard there are some significant differences. I found Garrard Conley takes**spoiler alert** I wanted to read this before I saw the movie, though I've heard there are some significant differences. I found Garrard Conley takes a somewhat meandering pace through less relevant portions, while others, especially insights into much of the Love In Action program, were more limited. Chapters sometimes contained multiple time and location jumps, which left it a bit disjointed.But Conley really allowed the reader to empathize with many different people affected by rigid religious fundamentalism. The parts with his mom in particular were rough, man. Bouncing between their loving relationship to listening to her vomit after finding out about his sexuality is hard to reconcile. I kept wondering how she would have reacted if he told her about his rape; would she have been even more upset at the time to know he was a victim as well? I would have been to afraid to ask.The parallels between Smid, the ex-gay counselor, and Garrard's father, a baptist pastor, were really pointed. "Like my father, Smid was excellent at conversion, justifying whatever sudden mood overtook him." Both men seek redemption for their past actions by attempting to impact and improve the lives of people around them, possibly hoping to change themselves in the process.I wish we got more from the other LIA members, but if he was only there a week or two, I get why there wasn't more to share. This memoir was heartbreaking, but so, so necessary in understanding the damage done by trying to "fix" a person's identity. Now off to watch Lucas Hedges and Nicole Kidman tear my heart out.....more

title: Dare Me
author: Abbott, Megan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a book about cheerleaders. Does that come off as a derisive statement? I can’t help but feel like it does. How many people reading the descripThis is a book about cheerleaders. Does that come off as a derisive statement? I can’t help but feel like it does. How many people reading the description for a book would take one look at the word “cheerleaders” and immediately move on? Is there the same level of dismissiveness for books about male athletes, like the hockey players in Beartown or the football players of Friday Night Lights? I don’t think there is. And I wonder how much of that has to do with the status and infamy that cheerleading retains in our popular culture. I wasn’t a cheerleader. I don’t believe I have any negative feelings towards the institution either. But I do fucking love Megan Abbott, even though Goodreads ers do not appreciate her for whatever reason. She writes the absolute best unlikeable characters, particularly unlikeable women. They are some of the most layered characterizations I’ve ever read, and it’s usually hard to root for anybody. There’s no heroes, no villains, no real anti-heroes, even. Perhaps that’s why her books are typically falling on the lower end of 3 stars, because they’re so unbearably human. Dare Me follows a high school cheerleading squad and their new coach, Colette French. The narrator, Addy, and her teammates are immediately drawn into Coach French’s almost gravitational pull. The established hierarchy is turned on it’s head. Friendships are tested. But these aren’t typical female friendships as depicted in most books and movies. These friendships are complicated, uneven and at times deeply uncomfortable. They can be vicious—not in a catty sense, but in an animalistic one. These are not moving relationships, they are ones that make you squirm in your seat.This novel is taut and quietly intense. Despite not knowing what’s going to happen, a wave of overwhelming inevitability hits you at the end. That’s Abbott’s signature, for me: the sense that it couldn’t have ended any other way. If you’re looking for another Megan Abbott book to read, I highly recommend You Will Know Me, which features female gymnasts....more

title: The Toll        (Arc of a Scythe, #3)
author: Shusterman, Neal*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Once again, Neal Shusterman proves he’s still the same dynamic writer and a master of YA Sci-fi/Fantasy in a way most of his contemporaries can’t toucOnce again, Neal Shusterman proves he’s still the same dynamic writer and a master of YA Sci-fi/Fantasy in a way most of his contemporaries can’t touch. I still ruminate over the first book of his I read, Downsiders, and I remember him visiting my middle school some time around 2004/5 to promote The Schwa Was Here. He’s just an author that I’ve consistently enjoyed from childhood into adulthood, and I know I’m not the only one. The Arc of a Scythe series has been a highlight of my reading over the past several years. From the driving characters to the absolutely fascinating concept and setting, Shusterman crafted a vivid environment for this trilogy to thrive. The success of these books is even more impressive considering the reported “decline” of the YA dystopian novel in the back half of the decade. Burnt out on young heroines and heroes fighting back against a tyrannical government set on controlling them, books like The Hunger Games, Divergent and The Maze Runner have been loved, lauded, adapted and then mocked for that consistent message, depending on the current mood. So what makes these books different? I’m sure the current geopolitical and *literal* climate are contributing factors. You don’t have to stretch the imagination much to see the way humans are progressing scientifically but stagnating or regressing on social policy has become worrisome. I was picking up more on some of these parallels while reading The Toll than I might have been at a different point in time. Some are broader, like authoritarian leaders who give in to their own cult of personality and scapegoat the fringes of society as ‘undesirables’ that don’t deserve to live with the rest of us, if at all. While others can be nothing but specific call outs like, “Greatness is overrated” or “Only idiots built walls.”One of the strengths of the series was how well-plotted they all were. It’s nice to have a great premise, but if it all falls apart once you start world-building beyond that set-up, then it’s not going to be able to carry that momentum to the end. I was blown away by the unfolding of events in Scythe at the outset, torn apart by their development as it all crescendoed in Thunderhead and expertly put back together by deft hands in The Toll. The entire series is thoughtful and cleverly constructed, asking ‘what ifs’ to some of our society’s most looming questions. This is a type of speculative fiction that I don’t think YA gets enough credit for, because it’s typically starring teenagers, but is undeniably smart and compelling. The final installment of the trilogy is just as satisfying as we could hope, and as unflinching as its fans have come to expect. ——————————————————Accidentally returned this to the library before finishing it—OOPSSent back to the end of the holds line..[image]...more

review: I think the best part of this book for me was the time Garvis Graves took to really explain Annika as a character and human being, through both her owI think the best part of this book for me was the time Garvis Graves took to really explain Annika as a character and human being, through both her own eyes and the eyes of those around her. I was nervous that she would end up being a caricature of someone on the spectrum as opposed to a fleshed-out individual who is different in some ways, but I was really pleased with how she was handled! It was extremely easy to empathize with her as she confronted some difficult situations.Annika is a really compelling character, which was crucial since I'm not typically into romance books. The intimate scenes in particular were a highlight when paired with her blunt candor and I found myself audibly cackling and snorting at some of the social interactions she tried to maneuver. And as a Chicago girl, it was nice to see locations and local references sprinkled throughout the text! Can you be nostalgic for a place you're currently at?For me, where the book fell short was in the last 50 pages or so. A lot happens, which granted I did not see any of it coming, but compared to the earlier and more deliberate pacing, it feels very rushed. I would have said it is almost entirely unresolved if not for a couple of callbacks that happen on the last few pages. I really did enjoy exploring aspects of Annika's life from 1991-2001, but I wish the last year would have gotten as much attention as the first.*I've never written a  before, but I got this book in a giveaway and Goodreads asked nicely to leave a , so here we are.*...more

title: Dopesick: Dealers, Doctors, and the Drug Company that Addicted America
author: Macy, Beth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was equal parts devastating and infuriating. Beth Macy has written a meticulous account of the opioid crisis our country has faced over the This book was equal parts devastating and infuriating. Beth Macy has written a meticulous account of the opioid crisis our country has faced over the past two decades. Mostly localized to her native Virginia, Macy uses her investigative skills to trace back this epidemic to its roots and follow it to its inevitable, disastrous end. The casualties, measured in both deaths and lives completely shattered, are almost too large to comprehend. So while relaying important facts and statistics about addiction and overdose, the author weaves in human stories of real people who have struggled and who are still struggling currently in order to give us something more to grasp on to than cold numbers.Though it may be presented as something more academic or anthropological, what Dopesick is over anything else is a call to action. It’s a call for the pharmaceutical companies and their overseers who over-produce and supply these drugs to the general public. It’s a call to doctors in small towns who are overprescribing and letting themselves be influenced by the sales reps who are pretty brazenly offering bribes. It’s a call for police and other law enforcement to change the way they pursue and classify addicts as criminals first and people second. It’s a call to legislators to seem reluctant to enact any programs to help the already addicted find their way back to society. And it’s a call to the communities affected, the ones who believe that by not acknowledging these problems they will simply go away. But unfortunately by the time anyone has really started to listen, it’s usually far too late for far too many.I can hear the weariness in Macy’s writing and her interviews with the families of those affected. Everyone just seems so tired. Hell, I was tired too. But it’s even harder to treat an already difficult problem when everyone is walking around like Sandra Bullock in Birdbox. I guess I, like Macy and the rest of her subjects, are just wondering if and when this will be taken seriously like the absolute crisis it is.(view spoiler)[And that gut-punch in the Epilogue. Oof. (hide spoiler)]...more

title: Columbine
author: Cullen, Dave*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was too young to remember Columbine. I was all of 5 on April 20th, 1999, so I would have been in kindergarten at the time. It’s weird to have no memI was too young to remember Columbine. I was all of 5 on April 20th, 1999, so I would have been in kindergarten at the time. It’s weird to have no memory of an event that has impacted every day of my education, from elementary to high school and beyond. We were doing school lockdown drills before we knew what they were for. This was even before they were more streamlined, and my school had been trying out different names: ‘Code Red’ or ‘Code Yellow’. We learned it along with the Tornado Drill, everyone curl into a ball near the bathroom, and the Fire Drill, everyone walk quickly outside and stand on the curb. This ‘Stranger’ Drill was different because we didn’t leave the room, we turned off the lights and hid in a corner. If you were in the bathroom, you had to stay there, pull your legs up on to the seat and try not to make a sound. We didn’t know what we were hiding from, but even then, even at that age, it was clear this was a different sort of danger.I also read Parkland before I picked up Columbine. Out of his two books I feel as though I’ve really only lived through Parkland. Despite alluding to his previous subject quite often in Parkland, this one struck quite a different tone. While much of the 2019 book is focused on the students of Marjory Stoneman Douglas repurposing their tragedy into a national movement, the students of Columbine are simply trying to grapple with their grief. Survival is enough of a victory, and even that feels at times out of reach.In Parkland Cullen also discusses his own trauma from spending years painstakingly covering the first shooting and rehashing such a senselessly violent attack. I can see even more now how someone in that position would end up responding that way. Anyone who hasn’t read either book yet needs to, but I would make sure you’re in a proper headspace to do so. Already knowing the story doesn’t make it any easier to consume.One of the most useful purposes of such a chronicling of events is that the myths surrounding this shooting and others like it are able to be addressed and dispelled comprehensively. The “loner” reputation has unfortunately not disappeared, but here Cullen clearly dismisses that idea multiple times. The lack of a motive or targets that we as a society can readily understand is not an easy pill to swallow, but it is a necessary one if we want to prevent more situations like this going forward. Also, the revelation that Columbine was “a bombing that failed” and just the sheer scale of the killers’ plans and goals were news to me. I can’t even imagine what that would have looked like—and I’m glad that imagining it is all we have to do.The author is noticeably moved at several points throughout his research, but maintains an ability to be diplomatic in the face of unfathomable loss. The area that I think his frustration is most evident is in how the Jeffco Sheriff’s department covered-up their own missteps leading up to, during and after the attack. The original mistakes could have been forgiven, but the attempts to cover their own asses after the fact is reprehensible. I don’t know about a legal definition for negligence, but in my view they more than met the moral threshold for it.I’ll wrap up this up with a quote from ‘The Boy in the Window’, Patrick Ireland. In addressing his graduating class as valedictorian he described that infamous moment as such:“When I fell out the window, I knew somebody would catch me. That’s what I need to tell you, that I knew the loving world was there all the time.”  ...more

title: Helter Skelter
author: Bugliosi, Vincent
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Whew, this was an exhaustive account of one of the most exhausting criminal trials in American history. At the time it was the longest and most expensWhew, this was an exhaustive account of one of the most exhausting criminal trials in American history. At the time it was the longest and most expensive ever undergone, with a level of dramatics and theater that would have been dismissed as too far-fetched if it had been a fictional courtroom drama instead of a real-life proceeding. Hats off to Vincent Bugliosi; he did not leave one stone unturned and hand-held the reader from the horrific crime scene discovery through to the end of the Tate-LaBianca trial and beyond.All that information and the personal overtone Bugliosi initially provided in the book should have clued me in that he was somehow involved with the case as more than a passive observer. I was, in fact, caught completely off guard when he disclosed he was the prosecutor assigned to both the Tate and LaBianca murder investigations. Perhaps in some instances this would mean he wasn’t an unbiased narrator, but Bugliosi more than proved his own credibility time and time again. He also may be the only person who could have accurately and completely recounted this story to the public.Is he a perfect commentator? No, not at all. Some of this is attributed to the time period he lived in, like referring to the Polanski/Tate housekeeper as “a black” and “the negro”. He also repeatedly labeled totally normal and expected emotional reactions by women finding out someone close to them was brutally slain as “hysterical”, where men were described as ‘understandably’ upset. And while the young plaintiffs of both genders were physically scrutinized to some extent, the young women were more likely to get specific remarks disparaging their appearance than the men involved. They’re part of a murder cult, Vince, can’t you find something to drive that point home beyond “ugly” or “unattractive”?I think the most astonishing part of the entire endeavor was the complete ineptitude shown by the LAPD, specifically those investigating the Tate murders. They went beyond incompetence into negligence. As an author Bugliosi was trying to remain neutral, but as the person who had to make up for their many, many mistakes you can tell he was pissed off. I appreciated him most when he gave pitiless indictments (that veered almost sarcastic) of both the initial investigation and the lack of any discernible form of follow-up, basic police work really. During the trial, while Manson and his followers were exactly as ridiculous and disruptive as one would expect, I was taken aback by what his lawyer, Irving Kanarek, was allowed to get away with. Most of his interruptions were mercifully excluded by the author, but even the sampling we were exposed to were excessive to the point of unethical. All together, with the disturbing Manson family, their obstructionist attorney, a ruthless press core and the cast of Police Academy, I am beyond impressed with how the prosecution kept their cool.If you have any questions, any at all, about the Manson trial, family or their numerous crimes, Bugliosi answers them in this (700!!) page book. If you’re interested, I’d recommend getting the print version, as the ebook I got from my library was stripped of all images apparently due to copyright abuse....more

review: I read this on vacation and wasn’t able to post a  at the time, but on the heels of finishing Cari Mora, I have a better appreciation for HarrisI read this on vacation and wasn’t able to post a  at the time, but on the heels of finishing Cari Mora, I have a better appreciation for Harris’ Hannibal Lecter series than I did previously.So much of Red Dragon feels like the last century, both in forensics (secretor) and era (print classified ads), but also with the storyline & protagonist: a lone, reluctant hero with brilliant, yet unexplained skills is able to nearly singlehandedly solve a crime (of course brutally targeting women), with nothing but “instincts”. He’s afraid of his own darkness. His wife just doesn’t understand. He has a connection with a killer that only he is capable of. This book was written in the early 80s, so I don’t know if this was cliche at the time or not, but I don’t think it would garner as much praise if released today.Basically, Will Graham is a throw-away character. Agent Crawford even more so. Molly and her son get very little to do other than filling roles that assist in Will’s character and plot development. They’re potential targets, victims, sources of personal conflict and “anchors” at home. You could copy/paste any of them with other rogue cops or worrying wives and nobody would notice.What I appreciated the most were the antagonists. Freddy Lounds is a skeezy reporter who gets himself in too deep while looking for dirt. Francis Dolarhyde’s descent into deeper and deeper mental illness is incremental and fascinating. He’s a loner that’s harboring mental, emotional and physical scars that result in a very specific manifestation of violence. Harris was said to have consulted with John Edward Douglas on the psychology of serial killers, which he helped pioneer the study and tracking of at the FBI. (Check out Mindhunter: Inside the FBI's Elite Serial Crime Unit for more) This is to say nothing of the eventual star of the series, Hannibal Lector (view spoiler)[who, unfortunately, was the only of these three to survive to the next book. (hide spoiler)]It’s easy to get entrenched in the psychology of these characters, and despite my panning of Graham, he’s an effective audience surrogate. Especially compared to the latest Thomas Harris novel, Red Dragon is totally worth the read....more

title: The Bad Seed: A Vintage Movie Classic
author: March, William
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Before there was an entire genre of murderous children, before even the term “serial killer” was coined, there was The Bad Seed by William March. I waBefore there was an entire genre of murderous children, before even the term “serial killer” was coined, there was The Bad Seed by William March. I want to say it was Gillian Flynn who first put this book on my radar years ago, when I was desperate to find something to fill the place of Sharp Objects after finishing that cruelly brilliant debut. In a premise that might sound familiar nowadays, a typical 1950s mother and housewife, Christine Penmark, has growing concerns about her daughter, Rhoda, as bad things continue to happen around the child. She’s well-mannered and charming to adults but children her own age are spooked by her presence. Though she always seems to know exactly the right thing to say, her parents have noticed a calculating quality to her actions and words, as if she’s learned this behavior and is simply mimicking it. Christine’s husband is away for work for almost the entire novel, and so she must decide how to handle the concerning behavior of their child completely on her own.As an almost 70-year-old book, The Bad Seed does it’s best to pathologize Rhoda as well as it can. March, to his credit, writes the two female characters at its center with more agency than I was expecting. The way Christine acts, dismissing her own thoughts and feelings, reducing feminine traits as inferior to masculine ones, is probably not too far off of how some women of the era would think. I’m sure a modern interpretation of both the psychology of Rhoda and Christine as well as their socialization would be more incisive and accurate, but even outside of the time period the book was set in I think March was very thoughtful in his analysis of both of these characters.I haven’t read many s of this one yet because I didn’t want to spoil it for myself but I loved seeing the starting point of many popular horror tropes of the past several decades. I was afraid there wouldn’t be any surprises in a book that’s been part of the lexicon for so long, but that was not the case here. I was still shocked by the way the story turned out, even if it feels inevitable once you know. Though a lot of what was revealed about Rhoda may be expected by readers, the biggest twists for me centered around Christine. Their relationship is a big answer to the classic ‘nature or nurture’ question that writers have loved to explore in their works. Thanks to Chandra ( @wherethereadergrows ) who sent me this book last Christmas (oops)—I’m sorry it took so long to get to! I’m interested in watching the movie adaptation from 1956 now, and hope it lives up to the source material![image]**For more book talk & s, follow me on Instagram at @elle_mentbooks!...more

title: Bossypants
author: Fey, Tina
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had some stuff to paint, so I decided to put on the audiobook version of Bossypants to pass the time. Having Tina Fey narrate her own book really adI had some stuff to paint, so I decided to put on the audiobook version of Bossypants to pass the time. Having Tina Fey narrate her own book really added to the Tina Feyness of it all. I haven't listened to enough books to know what makes a good and bad narrator, but I feel like the author reading it with the proper inflections and rhythm is a plus. This may be even more important in comedic works where timing and tone are crucial.Since I'm getting to it so long after initial publication, I've heard some of the jokes and stories before on various late night shows. That's not really a problem, since there's plenty of other material included. Even if it wasn't literally her voice filling the room, it still reads reliably in her 'voice'. A few jokes might have played better a decade or so ago, but comedy changes with the time period and atmosphere. Nothing is cringey the way other comedians' stand-up sets from years ago posted to YouTube are now. It's aged pretty well all things considered.Maybe I've read too many similar books by comedy-writers-turned-big-celebrities, but I was waiting for a resonating moment to tie it all together. I think I was expecting something a la Trevor Noah's brilliant and at times profound Born A Crime or even the flawed, but authentic The Last Black Unicorn from Tiffany Haddish, but they both had vastly different experiences from comedians like Fey. What holds up best for me was the stories and advice around working in a male dominated field, especially while in the spotlight. It's like a more practical and less patronizing Lean In (I mean this in a good way).She's an incredibly funny lady and this was a great representation of her humor and skill set. Also makes me want to follow it up with Amy Poehler's book....more
